reviewText:
How many times is the same plot going to be used over and over again?

This is the same old story of a crazy woman spirit seeking revenge.  The main character in these types of stories does some research, finds a body, and gives it a proper burial, only to have the spirit remain at unrest.  Remind you of any other movies???

The movie was very slow and featured things moving in front of the camera followed by a loud noise.  No chances taken and very few interesting story elements make this movie run-of-the mill.  The settings were amazing, but don't seem to be fully utilized to make this a really thought-provoking film.

Overall, it's just the same thing we've seen before and offers nothing new or exciting.  What a let down.

Most people who go to see James Watkins' "The Woman in Black" will be perfectly satisfied with it. This lushly filmed ghost story, set in a remote English village in Edwardian times, does precisely what it sets out to do, which is to provide a steady stream of gasp-inducing thrills to its audience. Daniel Radcliffe is a few years too young to play Arthur Kipps--grieving widower, failing lawyer and father to a four-year-old son--who goes to sort out the tangled estate at creepy Eel Marsh House in a last-ditch attempt to save his career. But Radcliffe gives a solid and convincing performance nonetheless, as do Ciaran Hinds and Janet McTeer as a local couple who know more than they're saying about the mysterious title character, who appears in the cemetery next to the house at unexpected moments. The thrills, when they start coming, come pretty much nonstop, and Watkins & Co. deserve credit for remembering a cinematic truth too often forgotten these days: what you don't see is scarier than what you do.

As good as the new "Woman in Black" is, however, I still prefer the old TV version directed twenty-odd years ago by Herbert Wise. The basic story of the two versions is the same, but the details are somewhat different. In particular, the older version is bleaker, more hypnotic, and ultimately more tragic than the newer. The story in the older version builds more slowly, and the shocks are fewer, which many viewers undoubtedly wouldn't like. But the slower buildup allows the story's horror to creep more firmly into your bones, and the shocks--when they come--are the most powerful I can think of in any horror movie.

Unfortunately, the studio that made the new version has withdrawn the old one from distribution, so that it cannot be exhibited or sold anywhere. The old DVDs, when you can find them, fetch $100 or more apiece. Fans, however, are still willing to pay that. It may be that many viewers, seeing both versions, would still prefer the newer. All I hope is that soon the studio will re-release the old version and allow viewers to judge for themselves.

As I type this, I've got the book sitting in my house. I'd purchased it before the movie came out, but held off because I knew how much of a literary purist I am when it comes to book to film adaptations. So here's a warning: I'm not sure how true this is to the book, but I know enough about the book to know that they did change things here and there. OK, now with that disclaimer, on with the review.

I loved this movie, but it helped that I saw it with a good audience. (Sometimes screaming teenagers can really help bring the tension up.) Radcliffe does a pretty good job in this movie. I was a little afraid that I'd spend much of the movie unable to distance him from the character of Harry Potter and also unable to see him as someone who had a kid, but he did pretty well in this and was able to carry the film. (Which he'd have to since a huge bulk of the movie is Radcliffe by himself.)

The real gem to the movie are the costumes and surroundings. I hate to say that I was more enchanted with the house and "island" that the Woman in Black haunted as well as with the excellent costumes. Someone put a lot of time and thought into these and it shows. Everyone looks fantastic here. If you're a costume or setting fan, you'll undoubtedly love this movie.

If you're a horror fan? Well, you'll probably enjoy the film for the gothic atmosphere and the jump scares (ie, the scenes where a ghost jumps out at someone). It's not the greatest gothic horror film ever made, but it's still good enough to where you'll probably walk out of the theater loving it and wanting to see it again at some point in time. The only thing that disappointed me is that I just got the feeling that there could have been a little more to it and that it relied a little overly much on the jump scares to push the tension along. Even the screaming teenagers eventually got a little quiet after a while. They were drawn into the movie but after a while they, just like everyone else in the theater, got somewhat used to the Woman In Black jumping out at people.

Overall though, this movie does what it set out to do: entertain. It's incredibly entertaining and I have no doubt that it'll end up getting various fan awards because of it. It's also just enough to push Radcliffe out of his Harry Potter box to where it'll make it more likely that people can see him as someone other than "that Potter kid". This is a great little film and I had a blast watching it. (I'll probably buy it when it comes out on DVD.) In my opinion, it's worth going to see in the theaters.

"The Woman In Black" is great! This is how the story goes: Arthur Kipps is a widowed lawyer whose grief has endangered his career. When he is sent to a remote village to sort out the affairs of a recently deceased eccentric, it soon becomes clear that everyone in the town is keeping a terrible secret. Although the locals try to hide the town's tragic history from Kipps, he soon learns that his client's house is haunted by the ghost of a woman who is looking for someone and something she had lost, and until she finds it, no one is safe from her vengeance.

The cast led by Daniel Radcliffe (as Arthur) is great. The directing by James Watkins is great. The screenplay (based on Susan Hill's novel) by Jane Goldman is great.

The music by Marco Beltrami is great. The cinematography by Tim Maurice-Jones is great. The film editing by Jon Harris is great. The casting by Karen Lindsay-Stewart is great. The production design by Kave Quinn is great. The art direction by Paul Ghirardani is great. The set decoration by Niamh Coulter is great. The costume design by Keith Madden is great. The make-up and visual effects are great.

This is a great slow-build of a scary movie that will keep you thinking and on the edge of your seat with your heart racing. Daniel Radcliffe is great as Arthur Kipps and proves that he does have a career outside Harry Potter. This is one of the best horror movies in a while and another interesting return to form for Hammer Films.

Daniel Radcliffe is on screen most of the time in this movie.  He is alone much of the time, too.  The haunted house in question is the quintessentially spooky house that is inaccessable parts of the day or night due to the tide washing over a swamp.  The eerie atmosphere is well kept and Daniel's really good in the film.  As one review said above, how many ways can this kind of scary movie tell the same story?  For those who expect decapitations and lots of gratuitous blood, I'm sorry, but this movie isn't that kind of movie.  Some of the thrill moments are standard, but if, like the other reviewer above, the only thing you're doing is counting the number of them, then you obviously should not be reviewing this movie. The brief glimpses of shadows moving or figures moving past a mirror get to you almost at once. NOthing is scarier than shadows that move.

Being indelicate, Daniel Radcliffe's not a tall person, and in this movie that doesn't matter at all.  Still he didn't have to have a love scene with a taller woman or have to out-yell someone who is a foot taller.  It was a wise choice, because now we can just concentrate on the good job he does.  (There are long moments when there is no dialogue, and they don't drag - not for me, anyway.)

Is it perfect? No. But it certainly is preferable to me over those slasher movies (in which I lost interest years ago.)  It isn't quite as surprising as "Sixth Sense", but the ending was not expected.  My real complaint, not addressed by any others, is that the dialogue in some places is slightly muffled.  I have some hearing problems, but this wasn't in that category.  The dialogue was simply not clear in places, notably Daniel Radcliffe's first conversations with his boss and with the man who eventually helps him (whose son has also died.)  Dan was fine, but the others were muffled, relying on the British mumble to get through.

I'm glad I went, and my reservations are minor.  There were moments when I had reall chills from fright.

At the tail end of the 19th century, Arthur Kipps (Daniel Radcliffe) still feels like the wound is still fresh when it comes to his wife who died four years ago after giving birth to their son. Arthur is drowning in a depressive state that even his son notices. As a lawyer, Arthur is forced to travel to a secluded town to take care of the work of the now deceased Alice Drablow as a last ditch effort to save his job. Arthur is expecting to be buried in paperwork until the weekend, but the odd occurrences that transpire are a bit out of left field. Everyone in town practically begs for Arthur to return to London immediately as children continue to die gruesome deaths left and right. Ignoring their pleas, Arthur decides to confront the problem head on and stay at the Drablow's menacing house where his constant run-ins with the supernatural eventually take its toll on him.

The Woman in Black is a horror film that I wanted to be good. It's Daniel Radcliffe's first movie outside of the Harry Potter franchise and he's been pretty enthusiastic about it in interviews, but every bit of promotional material seemed to point at the movie being your everyday, generic, run of the mill, "scary" movie. The Woman in Black does provoke your interest at first. The strange opening is a little hokey, but kind of intrigues you at the same time. The atmosphere the movie tries to setup is its strongest asset though. The heavy use of fog and old fashioned feel of the town does make the town feel like it existed in the late 1800s and the ominous score does its best to try and bring you to the edge of your seat. The Drablow house is the key to that atmosphere as it's absolutely gorgeous in this hideously grotesque kind of way. Everything is so dusty and creepy while the Victorian design only adds to that uneasy feeling the movie tries to stir up in the pit of your stomach.

In the meantime though, everything else in the movie is working against it. It's extremely uneventful. Daniel Radcliffe reads papers, walks through a house, holds a candle, and gets a little dirty. That's the entire movie in one sentence. The Woman in Black also resorts to relying on nothing more than jump scares to try and scare its audience. There are four in the first twenty minutes; two from the same sequence and there are at least ten throughout the entire movie. Jump scares can be fantastic in small portions, but come off as incredibly weak when you can see them coming a mile away and are strung together haphazardly for a cheap effect. There isn't much dialogue while Arthur is in the Drablow house either, which is practically the entire movie. This was probably done to try and make the audience more absorbed with what was taking place on screen, but seems like a bit of a copout overall. Radcliffe has proven that he is an extremely talented actor, but he's pretty bland here. He mostly wanders around in a daze with a frazzled look on his face the entire time. His hosting gig on Saturday Night Live was more impressive in comparison.

The Woman in Black will still be a very successful film as nearly everyone who was or still is a Harry Potter fan will be lining up around every street corner just to be able to see this movie, but the fact of the matter is that it just isn't a great movie. Its representation of the late 19th century is pretty good, but the writing, the "scares," and (most of all) the entire conclusion are all just extremely disappointing. The Woman in Black is a watered down version of last year's Insidious that will more than likely gain a lot of praise it doesn't deserve.

Lots of opportunities for jumps, but all pretty standard cheap scare stuff. Honestly, for the first hour or so I began to wonder if anything was actually going to happen outside of the standard make you jump devices. Radcliffe was pretty good I thought but a couple other things really bothered me. They never recovered the body of the kid? Lazy slackers. Come on, I think I could have got a group of locals together and accomplished that. Then there's the ending. In my opinion, this ending really ranks among suckie endings as one of the suckiest. Even after the horrible ending, I could have ended it better. After the credits even. In fact, I wrongly predicted that the filmmakers would correct that stupid ending before the dvd ended. All in all, I kind of enjoyed the movie as not a waste of time, but that putrid ending was an unforgivable way to end a decent movie.
It was a really good movie !
I thought it was a very good movie.
i'm not a real fan of ghost stories; this was typical except for the twist at the end.

I wasn't expecting much from this. Everything I had heard was this is a cookie cutter horror film. In a lot of ways it is, but that doesn't really cover everything.

The rough sketch is a ghost wants revenge for a hurt inflicted in life. Man shows up, stirrs up the evil, bad things happen.

However when you look past that at the actual details of the story, the character motivations of both the living and the dead, the film has much more nuance.

I'll admit I was a bit thrown, not having expected it to take place in the 1800s. Once I got used to that however the story flowed nicely.

Daniel Radcliffe has grown up into a fairly talented actor. After this and Horns I look forward to seeing what else he does. That said I do feel they made one questionable bit of direction. There is a portion of the film near the beginning where the main character waits for a train and then rides a train. While perfectly suited for the film... Well, it certainly reminded me that the actor used to play Harry Potter. That said Daniel Radcliffe never broke character and certainly never felt like his old character. In other words I feel he did a good job.
this was really good movie!
This could have been good if so much time weren't spent waiting for something meaningful to happen.

have no idea how this movie is, I am JUST beginning to watch it, never heard of it, BUT after looking for a good horror to watch for a good five minutes I settled on this one; I was just watching the beginning credits roll and HAD to make a comment, if I had KNOWN that this was a HAMMER production, I would have jumped on it right away; HAMMER has ALWAYS been makers of the best HORROR movies
Its a great film with clich horror through line but well worth a watch! Its actually awesome as far as the story line goes.
Great product and service

Daniel Radcliffe  clearly carries this otherwise dull horror  movie through his skillful acting I enjoyed the suspense he conveyed to me as a viewer  as he walked  through this flick's' whimpering plot twists. The house on the fog shrouded moors was clearly spooky and I was glad to see the actor who played the Wildling king on Game of Thrones lending some much needed support. Mr Radcliffe has clearly evolved out of his Harry Potter days as a good actor. By the way watch out for those evil doll things in the playroom!

This was a creepy one, just the way I like them.  At times it seemed to move a bit slow, but the thrills and chills are there.  I've read some reviews that complained that the effects weren't good.  Well, I guess I run a bit deeper than that and have a good imagination so the slightly less than perfect effects didn't bother me at all.  I simply enjoyed the creepy factor.  While it doesn't top my list of favorite scary movies, I think it's worth a watch.
Well done, in both the acting and the script.  Radcliffe is great.

Sometimes it seems like horror movie makers are having a contest to see who can come up with the sickest, most disturbing story.

Which is why this film is really a breath of fresh air. No freakish, clown mask wearing monster psychopaths, no torture chambers, no cannibals. Just a slow burning scare fest with gloomy, gothic atmosphere and a well crafted story. This film also has a clear, understandable ending, not of one of those cop-out ambiguous you-figure-it-out endings. Well done and worth your time.

Come 

Everything about making this is what makes film making hard yet worth it.
I love it.

I am quite the horror fan.  I own this movie.  I watched it 5 times before buying it.  It is one of the most scariest movies I've seen, in my opinion.  you don't need great sound effects (the weak point) to know how to scare.

Sad and tragic. Vengeance taken out on little angels is pathetic. Only humans can think of such bad ideas, ghosts will never do any such thing. Its a waste of time for anyone who has kids. Parents should avoid it because it may give them a cardiac arrest

I've watched this movie twice and have to say it's a pretty scary movie. Scary in dark/suspenseful/spooky ways, not gory. Very dark in all ways, production as well as theme. A sad story that has a sad ending but I'll say no more to avoid spoilers. Radcliffe and Hinds were very good. It's basically a ghost story/horror story without gory bits. I like movies set in prior eras, I like the settings and costumes. I think I may read the book on which it's based now.

I love good ghost stories.  By "ghost" stories, I mean ones where there's supernatural phenomenon that is attributed to a non-corporal being that may or may not threaten humans.  I DO NOT mean slasher snuff stories/films that just use a spirit as an excuse for killing people in gruesome ways.  Unfortunately, The Woman In Black belongs to the latter category.  The plot of a deranged late 1800's mother indiscriminately offing innocent children is unimaginative at best; disgusting at worst.  The fact that there are plot holes, inconsistencies and tonnes of tired cliche's doesn't help. I found myself frequently checking how far I was in the movie an being tempted to just skip ahead.  The special effects are cheese and the dialogue uninspiring or even remote period accurate.  The climax is not only expected but welcome if only because I wanted the movie to be over.  Just because it ends doesn't mean the ending is in any way satisfying.  I just couldn't suspend disbelief which made this unfrightening and boring. Admittedly it was occasionally funny even though it wasn't trying to be.  Honestly the plot isn't really even good enough to warrant a half hour TV episode much less a feature length movie.

The only reason it gets 2 stars is that Daniel Radcliffe gives a stellar performance.  I'm one of those rare people that is not a real fan of the Harry Potter movies, but still enjoys all Mr. Radcliffe's character portrails.  True to his talent, he almost saves this train wreck.  ...Almost.

It moved slow, plot is same old stuff ,
pretty boring

I don't know where the positive reviews are coming from but this movie was incredibly stale. I do not know why Radcliffe chose to star in it. If i were him I wouldve rejected the role upon reading 10 minutes into the script. It is EXTREMELY formulaic which here means that it introduced very little original elements and instead resorts to the cookie cutter horror film recipe which goes something like, protag arrives at haunted house, realizes its haunted after strange events, goes up against apparitions, attempts to solve problem to purge said apparitions.

Heres out it plays out: first 40 min of movie we are given vague introductions and an unclear plot. Daniel radcliffe plays hide and seek with apparitions when he arrives at the apparently haunted house (shocking). A series of events unfolds as children start to die as they did and have done after the events regarding a deceased mentally ill woman comitted suicidemany decades ago after her son is carelessly left to die in an accident from his adoptee parents. After Radcliffe is convinced he works with a friend by trying to reunite the vengeful lady in black apparition by reuniting her with her dead son... (Poor choice here because he basically just trials and errors on this one with no basis on how this will actually satisfy the lady in black). The apparition seemingly disappears. But then there is a twist: lady in black doesnt care. She comes back this time killing Radcliffes son and him in the process.

Radcliffe and son are reunited with his long deceased wife and they walk off into the mist. So not only does the story leave an unresolved plot but it also errors in making one of the worst sins in horror cinematography imo with that stupid ending wherein the audience is supposed to feel happy for Radcliffe because he and his son are now dead and reunited with the mother but is supposed to forget that there evil lady in black is still lurking in the shadows of the haunted eel marshes house. Just distasteful storytelling that didn't know how to end it so why not kill off the protag in the most cliched twist ever.

Do not watch this, youd be wasting your time.

this horror movie set in an older period of time,reminds me of the old classic horror films made at hammer and pinewood studios what a treat much better then american  horror story with a major cast...

I thought this was a great movie! I love scary movies, horror in particular. Being a scary movie buff, I rarely get scared or jump from a movie. BOY did The Woman in Black get me. Great movie! Great acting from my guy Daniel. Definitely a must see!
good movie
Very eiry and well done
I think this movie is highly suspenseful and terrifying and love it! Dont pay much attention to the plot line though cause you won't find one.
I watched this as a one man play and then tried to see this as it was meant to be seen; I am not supper impressed, but it had it moments, and you have to be patient.
Borderline boring
the ending was a surprise, but annoying. it was great overall, very scary and gory, and very well suited to the time. still a very unsatisfying ending.
SUCKED. NOT SCARY
Your average run of the mill horror story. Not oscar material but watchable.
I loved this movie. It has an amazing story line and keeps one's attention.
Good solid movie for a rainy day. Daniel Radcliffe is wonderful!
Moderately spooky
Strong old-world Gothic theme, and enough thrills to make it a worthwhile watch.
Really enjoyed the movie, and it is actually appropriate scary movie for 13+ kids who's parents monitor appropriate content.

Not disappointed.  Good build.  Good lines.  Better than average cinematography.  I'm glad for the ending.  The hesitation of the townsfolk for the solicitor is not over dramatized.  The director did a good job of making every behavior, at first, questionable in intention.  This uncertainty adds to the emotional reaction of the audience.  The use of mixing real situation fear with paranormal situation fear is nice.  I also like that it is clear that it is peoples reactions and behaviors towards paranormal fear that puts people in real threatening situations.

The scarey-factor and acting in this film is good, however, in my opinion the 1989 version (free on YouTube) has a far superior story.  The current version leaves you with the open ending that modern movies too often have.  It feels as if screen writers these days simply lack the skill to create a complete story.

a typical Gothic ghost story with all, and I mean ALL of the conventions! Fun if you want some suspense but otherwise predictable. I liked Daniel Radcliffe in this performance, it's too  bad that the plot and writing did not offer more for him to work with. Overall, this is extremely disappointing, but I still recommend it for a bit of fun Victorian Gothic shudders to pass the time. Also, if you are curious about the tropes of Victorian Gothic fiction this is a good one to watch.
I love love love this movie. One of the scariest films I've seen in years and had me sleepless a few nights after watching it, which says a lot because hardly anything scares me anymore!
Good movie, didn't make me jump as I expected but was entertained.

Definitely one creepy story set in old England at the turn of the century. It takes place in an old village full of ancient history of rich people and a village full of paranoid parents.  Arthur Kipps sets out to close the affairs of an old widow who passed away, but still haunts a local village.
Well done but boring.
Good story, creative plot and Daniel played the part well. There were certainly a few too many jump-scares that contributed little to the plot. Worth watching on a lazy day.

Watch Not Harry Potter as he walks sloooowwly through a DARK HOUSE, which might be fun except it's SO dark you can't tell what's going on, an-duh, when he gets to wherever the funny noise is, it's nothing. (Dark rooms, dark forests, dark caves are a recurrent technique in horror films, note to directors: it isn't horror unless you can SEE what's so horrible.) Watch Not Harry express not a scintilla of emotion. Watch as the movie crawls along with all the pacing of a Bergman film and you realize, to YOUR horror, that grass grows faster than the velocity of this flick. Watch as the grossly overused characterization of insular and suspicious people of the SMALL VILLAGE stare at Not Harry with INTIMIDATING GLARES.
Watch IN HORROR as you realize some poor souls actually paid money to see Not Harry do Not Much.
liked the theme and technique as well as the story.
Well done Victorian Ghost story. Highly recommend it if you like the style or period, and a couple jumps along the way. Twist at the end, but well worth watching on a dark and stormy night :)

Three stars. Creepy. Good premise. Good acting. Overall, clumsy execution. Way too many "jump scares" and cliched "scary movie" things. Too many holes and uncertainty left in the story. Still, this film has redeeming value, especially since the ending is not typical.
Creepy, spooky, atmospheric Victorian horror.. Love it!
Loved it!
dummmbbbb
Surprisingly a solid 3 1/2 star flick... Harry Potter was very good. Check the 3/4/5 star reviews for more info.
Not as scary as I anticipated.
It was well acted and directed. The story was unoriginal. The writing was average. His easily recovering the body that couldn't be recovered was not credible. The town denizens were annoying.

Daniel is proving himself as a very good actor....Adult Actor. This is a simple little ghost story
with a surprise ending.  Ciaran  Hinds, the co-star, is of course one of the great actors of our time
A very well made horror film that is mildly scary.  Like eating at an Outback Steakhouse after going to McDonald's for several years.

Overall a decent movie, not very scary but fun to watch.  Having never seen Radcliffe beyond Harry Potter I believe he did well in movie, it's hard not to think of him as Harry Potter, but as the movie went a long I soon forgot.

Brilliantly Gothic! Daniel Radcliffe has transitioned well into a true actor. This movie was eerily scary & thought-provoking. I love period movies & this one hits the mark. It's definitely worth watching.
Cool movie. Scary, but not gross.

Terrible sound mixing, most likely done on purpose: everything in this movie is super quiet, but the jumpescares are horrendously loud! And there are a lot of them. When I first saw this movie in theatres, I counted the number of jumpscares, which was 17 (maybe off by one or two in either direction). That means there's at least one jumpscare for every 5 minutes of movie.

The story is also incredibly silly, the ghost effects laughable and modern cliches, feeling almost like one of those awful Insidious movies, and the "scares" are far too elaborate to the point where they have far surpassed my suspension of disbelief.

If you can find a copy, watch the original 1989 version. It's not perfect (what movie is) and there are one or two cheesy moments, but it's subtle, simple, and terrifying.

This one.... This is just trying way too hard. It's very noticeable.

The use of CGI fog is almost unforgivable, but on the whole this was a pretty good film.  Where it really fails is in the absence of religion, with only a few minor exceptions (including one character FINALLY making the Sign of the Cross).  English villages c. 1900 were already religious in the real world, and the events in the movie's background would tend to make the villagers zealously religious.  Speaking of zeal, they would have intervened much more decisively (that is, violently) in preventing an outsider from stirring up the trouble we see; they would probably have tried to burn down the haunted house at some point, probably decades in the past.  There seems to be a rule, though, that characters in horror movies do not behave like real people would.

On the other hand, the element of mystery is well played, and both the motivation of the ghost and the ghost's behavior at the end of the film follow a kind of traditional logic -- she may not have been reasonable, which is probably too much to ask of a vengeful ghost, but she was at least consistent.

Definitely reminds you of the old Hammer classics, great spooky ghost story to watch in the dark.  Daniel Radcliffe plays his role.. and the time period.. very well. I would recommend this movie to anyone who likes ghost/supernatural stories.
Do yourself a favor and do some volunteer work rather than watching this movie. Please!
Phenomenal
this is a really good flick - the setting and photography is great

As a horror fan I come into any ghost story with an air of skepticism ready to be disappointed. Thankfully this movie delivers. I thought the casting was excellent, the drama suspenseful and not overly predictable. The scenery and the sets were outstanding in so much that just being in those places and rooms would be spooky enough to give one shivers down the spine. The story lends itself to some typical horror tropes but not in such a way as to cheapen the whole experience that much. Given today's heavy use of cgi its to be expected in movies such as these but in this case often I felt it was understated and it was more the content of the scene that made it scary rather than a frightening monster so to speak. I don't want to give anything away but the swamp scenes were deliciously horrific and scary good fun. The over all melancholy tone and sinister bite of this story line have all the makings of a good horror flick that made me keep watching.
In all honesty - I just liked the ending.  Had that "Somewhere In Time" ending to it.
I'm confused about the end of the movie. I need answers!
I've never seen the other Harry Potter movies, but after this I don't want to. I don't think I saw magic used once, just Harry Potter wondering around reading books. 4/10

I saw The Woman in Black when it was in the theatre. I know that was years ago but the disappointment it left me with is still fresh lol.

The Woman in Black is one of those movies you want to love because the cinematography, acting, and atmosphere are perfect... but you can't because the movie overall is dull. The only good parts are the few jumpscares and the ending didn't make much sense. Maybe it just wasn't my cup of tea? (See what I did there? *laughs* Hey, at least I didn't crack a Potter joke!)
Really suspenseful. Scared me too. Ordered the sequel also.

This is a traditional ghost story in the Victorian style. Very atmospheric. I enjoyed it because I like that kind of thing, but if you are a fan of slasher style horror movies (which I hate), this is probably not for you.

The acting is pretty good, for the most part. Daniel does a decent job of portraying someone in pain, without overdoing it (which many would do).

It is a trifle predictable at times, in ways that go along with a Victorian type ghost story.

The woman in Black is a very interesting story idea and has all the right pieces but to all the wrong puzzle. The short synopsis is this, a down-on-his-luck man goes to the country side to complete one final job for his work, at which point an evil spirit starts to haunt him and the town. Should be an easy horror movie to make, right? It has an easily eerie pretense and a lovable main character; and yet the movie is flawed with long pauses, terrible plot explanations, and not to mention a long list of unanswered questions.

I gave the movie two stars because I liked the house. Stop here if you don't want anything spoiled.

So let's start on our down-on-his-luck here, Daniel Radcliff. Besides giving a performance that was exactly what we expected from Daniel Radcliff, the director goes into WAY too much backstory. In more minutes than were needed, we learn his wife died during child birth and he sort-deeply loves his son (sort). Not to mention apparently he is really sh*tty at his job and so this is his last chance to get it right, so you know he's going to try harder. Oh, and he has to take a train where they again show way way way too many flashbacks of a wife who holds way way way too little importance to the rest of the film (we'll get to that later).

The town is sort of creepy, what with little children staring out the window at the newcomer, but what I thought was really haunting was the lack of talk between Daniel Radcliff and his driver. I mean really, who goes to a countryside village and sits in the passenger seat silently? In the movie sense, they are trying to make a creepy town but I thought it was an excellent time to have Daniel learning the backstory of the town while seeing creepy children looking out of windows.

The house and items that filled it, the location, and the general flow to the house was all well done with a haunting atmosphere. Like I said, I liked the house and that's why I gave the film two stars. However, once in the house (when ghostly stuff should be happening), the director chose to force the viewer to see hauntings instead of letting them naturally progress or evolve. This was a major flaw since most of the movie is about passive eeriness. In fact, the haunting screech noise they play to try and jump scare you was probably the least scary part and the most annoying thing. Instead of capitalizing on new horror techniques (which don't work), the direct should have focused on atmospheric haunting and psychological terrors.

Yet none of this even begins to scratch the surface of why this film fails. The ghost, as scary as she is, has a purpose that doesn't align with her backstory. She's killing children of the town, but why? The town did nothing to her, it was her dead family. And her dead family is dead, so at most she could haunt the property, but why kill the children? They never answer this question nor do they answer why she will never be happy even after her son is returned to her. Once you come to this realization, the whole film falls apart. For one, why is Daniel Radcliff bringing his only child to the countryside where he's working when most people would have left the son at home with the faithful nanny? What did killing both of them really answer with the ending? And more importantly, what was the point of the movie if they managed to do nothing with the ghost's soul? Overall it was a creepy idea but someone should have worked on the plot to fix all these questions.

So here's my idea, first of all have something where its the town that ends up killing her child by accident. Now she has a reason for a vendetta. Second, if you are going to spend so much time focusing on Daniel Radcliff's wife, why not turn her into a good ghost? Why does she only have to be dead if you are having an evil spirit. Maybe instead of the ending they had, they show his dead wife protecting his son. Overall, it's a really flawed movie and not very scary.
It's refreshing to watch a more gothic take on the genre.  Thin on story and, like most haunting stories, never quite answers why with much depth, but who cares.  Chills nonetheless.

Well for a person who gets scared easily, I don't think I'm sleeping tonight. This movie was traditionally scary with lots of creepy and a dash of beautiful. The story, however, felt just a little flat. The main actors all did very well, especially the Mrs. Daily. The background action all seemed just a little bit aloof, if you can imagine. I'm not sure how else to describe it.
Overall, if you're looking for a good quality horror film to watch when you don't usually, this one certainly does the trick! The cinematography was executed well, and the colors, while conforming to the traditional, bleak scheme, were by no means dull. The plot kept you waiting for the next reveal, but it had loose ends as well. Probably so they could make a sequel.
If it takes a lot to scare you, this film may not do the trick, but personally, I was pretty tense throughout. I was constantly trying to distract myself with other things so that I wouldn't jump at the next cut. The scares all died down in the last 20 to 30 minutes to give the plot its time, so that part wasn't as hard to watch. As for the ending itself, not a big shock. Fitting to the rest of the story.
All in all, a well-made film.

A fantastic ghost story that will leave in with chills and a lingering fear of shadows throughout the night. I love scary movies but hate what they have been reduced to over the years. This is a classic haunting ghost story created with modern technology. If you loved shows like the Changeling, Flowers in the attic,  Stephen King, this is an absolute must watch. I watched it several years ago and loved it. I rewatched it again last night over amazon prime and it was just as fantastic if not better. I enjoyed it the first time so much that I even found the original classic novella written by Susan Hill. The original story is classified as "written in the style of a traditional Gothic novel".  The novella is quite different in some regards and stands as a must-read in its own right.  Although there are differences in the story line, the two seem to compliment each other well, which alone itself is a mystery. Too often one belittles the other.

Boring horror that's paint-by-the-numbers typical ghost film, with noting really scary. The acting is sub par at best, and the special effects are just cheap ghost children in makeup. The ending and it's idiotic plot hole just basically makes Arthur's(Daniel Radcliffe) attempt to reunite son and mother to pass on completed dumb and pointless. Instead of being at peace with finally having her son's body returned to her to move on in the afterlife she decides to still get revenge on him and his kid?!?! Okay...even if they were going for a Grudge like thing with her spirit and curse, it's dumb! Why would her spirit get him and his boy killed, then let them reunite and leave with his wife who died during his kids birth?? It's like the spirit said, "I'll do him a solid, he misses his wife so much I'll kill them both so they can live together in eternal peace.....I'm so nice."

She keeps the souls of all the other kids she's forced to commit suicide, but lets them stay together and leave? That breaks the spirits MO, and it is a bad way of saying "Thanks!" See how dumb that is.....that's basically the train of thought for this plot. Why not just let them live a normal life with a close train scare, or the ghost of Arthur's wife saves them. Something other then that nonsense ending would've been much better.

It's the old "I'd give it zero stars, if I could." All the recommendations proved false: NOT visually striking, NO suspense, and the film committed the unforgivable sin: absolutely ZERO understanding of the late 19th century. Period films, even dumb horror films, are not simply authentic costumes and sets; dialogue has to be written with an understanding of how people spoke, and especially that human behavior may not change, but social mores and customs do. When I saw that one character, was referred to on paper as "Ms." I knew it was time to write this one off. One clue was that dialogue was largely absent; apparently because the story was so weak, there was no way to write a credible narrative. I don't know how old the authors of the screenplay were, but I'm guessing under 25. I would recommend a 50 year old Hammer horror film any day of the week, over this!

The plot is, for the most part, boring and, unless you just want to look at Daniel Radcliffe, the acting is pretty bad, too. As Radcliffe wanders, alone, in this large, haunted house, the dog that accompanies him only, occasionally seems upset by some unseen forces. It growls on cue once in a while and seems content to lie around while Daniel encounters noises and disturbances in other parts of the house. If the dog doesn't sense more than the human, what good is he? There are too many other things that are not logical to make this film worthwhile, whether it is his having no food or water at this house, diving into black muck to retrieve "something," then having more clothes than his tiny suitcase could carry. The list just goes on and on.

Awful. The story line had huge holes.  If children were being killed off, why would villagers lock up a children still alive as if that would protect them rather than leaving the village?  How could the ghost's dead child's body show little sign of decay when it's mother's remains were nothing but bones?  Why after spending the last almost half of the film reuniting the ghost with her dead child's remains and thereby putting the ghost at peace and everyone else at rest that the curse had been lifted, does the ghost suddenly take violent retribution against the main character and his child?  The movie had plenty of the typical scary cut-aways, but with the incongruities, and particularly an ending that leaves the viewer wondering "what the . . .?", I can't recommend this to anyone.

I'm convinced this movie was created simply to make Daniel Radcliffe suffer even more on screen than he already has. Because he is just so good at it.

The setting is gorgeous.
The characters are interesting.
The concept is compelling.
But the way it all played out was just so cringingly bad that at the end I was left with such a deep feeling of dissatisfaction I had to immediately watch something else to wash away the taste.  There's so many strange plot holes and elements that seem to serve no purpose. While the ghost has in interesting motivation, we never have any flashbacks of her when she was alive, which takes away a major emotional aspect. At the same time, we never see any tender moments of the main character's wife when she was alive either. The movie relies almost completely on jump scares, screaming, and sudden loud music.
Perhaps it is just because I am too young to want to contemplate my own mortality just yet, or the fact that I have no wife I am eager to reunite with in the afterlife, but I cannot not say I enjoyed my decision to watch it. All the elements to make it a haunting and horrifying story of strong love and strong loss were there but it was missing something that might have made it the kind of story that stays with you and tugs at your mind long after you've seen it.

Lets get one thing straight from the start: Woman in Black is only as well reviewed as it is because of all the Daniel Radcliffe fangirls (and boys) who, still fawning over his performance as Harry, would have liked this film even if hed adorned blackface and acted like a chimp. There is nothing that could have sunk this movie at the box office. NOTHING. The only confusing bit about Woman in Black is that people haven't since come to their senses about how painfully uninspired it is now that the Harry Potter furor has died down (as much as it ever dies down, anyway).

Make no mistake, folks. Woman in Black is as cookie cutter as horror gets. (Minor spoilers follow)

Without spending too much time recapping the plot, the gist of the movie is this: Danny-boy is sent to handle some lawyerly papers (which he never gets around to) to do with a deceased womans estate; once in town, everyone tries to get rid of him without telling him why, and when he goes to the estate to handle that business he never handles, he encountersget thisstrange things, every single one of which youve seen in multiple other horror movies. Its not even worth recapping what they aretheyre the same worn out devices and jump-scares you get with seemingly every modern horror flick, and theres no fresh spin on any of it, either.

To the films credit, I did make it to about the 1-hour mark before I realized it did not have any redeeming value and was unlikely to develop any, a realization that the last third of the film confirmed. So at least I can compliment the filmmakers for camouflaging how boring the movie is halfway decently. But if thats the best I can say for it

The Woman in Black, is the best known version of a story which began as a novel and was made into a 1989 TV movie and a play, and has been followed by a sequel film.  Starring Daniel Radcliffe of Harry Potter fame, and featuring Ciarn Hinds (Mance Rayder in Game of Thrones) and Roger (DI Fred Thursday in Endeavour,) The Woman in Black is an old fashioned Gothic horror story, set in a creepy house in a remote weird village, where the disconsolate ghost of a woman who had lost her child takes vengeance by killing the children of the village.  Radcliffe plays a young lawyer sent to sort out the affairs of the house's deceased owner.  The film is a mixed bag:  the early 20th century atmosphere is very vividly realized, and the film gets its effect from well done continual menace rather than gory special effects.  It's been criticized for going through every horror film cliche in the books -- mysteriously hostile village yokels, a haunted mansion, furniture moving with no one in it, etc. -- though these standard characteristics are very well done.  My main dissatisfaction personally is that the film sets us up for a basically happy ending which it then fails to deliver. All in all, I'd give this three and a half stars if I could.  You'll want to watch it if you are a real fan of ghost stories.  The  CBS Films Blu-Ray disc is of excellent quality.  Advisory: rated PG 13, the main caution is that some people (not everyone) say they find it genuinely scary.

Strictly a Horror Movie for the popcorn brigade! While the director prates on about not being "exploitive," he loads the soundtrack with sudden LOUD noises! Sudden scary images THROWN up on the screen! It's about as subtle as screaming "Boo!' at a 4 year old! Save your money!

I liked the movie. It was eerie and had some nice jump scares, but if I was going to compare it to the book I'd say it missed the original feel and tone of the town and of its characters. In the movie the town folk are all aggressive and intolerant of Mr. Kipps arrival and continued presence. In the book they were wary of him cause they didn't want to talk about the house or it's ghostly occupants. They were a town of scared people. They tried to encourage Mr. Kipps not to go to the house and did everything they could to be hospitable. Also the plot of the movie is different than the book. I understand the reason because the book is a slower paced Gothic tale that may not interest viewers.

With that being said, if you enjoyed the movie you will like the book more. If you enjoyed the book like I did, this is more of a re-telling of the novel not an adaptation of the book and it has really nice scares.

Good rebelling of the legend of "The Woman in Black." Daniel Radcliff plays an attorney who lost his wife during child birth and is still grieving the loss, while attempting to raise his son as a single father. His law firm sends him to a small village in England to settle the affairs of a recently deceased woman. Once in town he is made aware of numerous deaths that have befallen the children of the town. I won't say the movie is terrifying, but the story is good and keeps you wanting to find out what happened. I would recommend this movie for a rainy weekend.

This is a pretty good movie. You have Harry Potter as an adult with a young son. He moves to some crazy scary mansion, and he starts seeing ghosts. I liked Ed Gibbs review of the movie. He said: In true ghoulish fashion, the emphasis here favours chills over gore, with a tense, imaginative treatment from British director James Watkins (of Eden Lake fame), adapted by acclaimed screenwriter Jane Goldman (aka Mrs Jonathan Ross), who's better known for co-writing the likes of Kick-Ass, X-Men: First Class and The Debt. Horror music specialist Marco Beltrami (a frequent collaborator of Wes Craven's) completes the package, with a shiversome soundtrack that resonates. Dark, damp and drenched in mud and fog, Kipps's destination is the quintessential Hammer house of horror locale. You almost expect Christopher Lee's Dracula  a favorite of the Hammer stable  to appear at any moment, to offer his seal of approval. (The film begins with three young girls fatally distracted from their toys in a dank, creepy attic.)

The Edwardian ghost story, "The Woman in Black," directed by James Watkins, is an extraordinary film.  Daniel Radcliffe, no doubt fortified by his stage work, has become one of the finest actors of his generation.  Diminutive, melancholic, quietly intense, he is superb.

One hopes some enterprising director mounts a film of Goethe's "The Sorrows of Young Werther" for him.  And would not Mr Radcliffe make an ideal Hamlet?  Or as the star of a biographical film of Paul Morphy...

Enveloped in a romantic sadness, with beautiful cinematography, this is the finest Gothic-horror film I have seen in quite some time, with an extraordinary apotheosis, and a fine score from Marco Beltrami.  It reinforces the astonishing potential of the cinema, so seldom realized.
Excellent movie! I highly recommend watching it. Fair warning, you will have nightmares.

Ahhh...Hammer Films. How we have missed you.
From the 50's to the 70's,  Hammer dominated the horror scene, mostly by using characters that the world was already familier with, made famous by Universal. In the early 80's, the studio folded, due to the over saturation of horror movies being released. In 2007, the studio was purchased, and in 2012, this gem arrived.
From the opening scene, this movie drips with a sinister and ghastly aura. Three young girls, suddenly and without apparent reason, synchronize dive their way out of a attic window. Any movie that starts with multiple child deaths, is setting the standard very high.
Authur Kipps (Daniel Radcliffe) hasn't been doing so well since his wife died. His career at a law firm is in danger, and he is sent on a two day assignment to
Eel Marsh house, to sort through the affairs of a recently deceased woman, to search for her final will. If the job goes well, he retains his job. If he fails, he adds unemployment to his list of miseries.
The story is a familier one, with Authur being a stranger in a strange land, rejected by the locals, with the exception of Sam Daily (Ciaran Hinds, who if you don't know as Julius Caesar in Rome, you are living your life wrong). However, despite the lack of originality, this movie has such a bleak atmosphere of darkness, that it easily sits high on the list of creepy ghost stories.
Scare Factor 10/10 From the opening scene, to the final credits, this movie is genuinely scary, even when nothing in particular is happening. Yes, there are jump scares, but they never feel forced, and they never take away from the sense of foreboding.
Gore 2/10 There is very little blood in this movie, but it is in no way missed. To have made it visceral would have cheapened it, and taken away from the well crafted horror that it prevails in.
Acting 10/10 Radcliffe has become a master of the art, and he plays his character to perfection, so that you feel his grief, but he never crosses the line to whiny or annoying. Also Ciaran Hinds is an acting God.
Recommended 10/10 While there have been many ghost stories that have succeeded in being scary by showing us nothing, there have been many more that have failed by giving us too much. This film perfectly balances the two, and keeps the tension so high that even the slightest shift of shadow can make a heart rate quicken. The score is amazing, going from subtle to crashing in a second, and perfectly highlighting every second. Every tiny tinkle of sound is meticulously placed.
Aside from being scary as hell, it also has one of my favorite endings in all of movie history, bringing to a close a brilliant ghost story that deserves to be in every horror fans collection.

Good film version of the story by Susan Hill. Daniel Radcliffe (who has grown into one of the best actors of his generation) assumes the role of the young Solicitor Arthur Kidd (first played in 1989 by Adrian Rawlins...who played Harry Potter's dad, James Potter in the well known series based on the books by J. K. Rowling). The rest of the cast is also quite good. In my opinion. though, it is the 1989 version that is the superior film even though IT was made for television. Perhaps because it was made for British Television which, when it is good, is awesome. And that version, directed by the legendary Herbert Wise, was awesome indeed. It would have five stars but this one gets a solid four. Definitely worth your time.Woman in Black (the 1989 version) isn't currently available anyway but you should watch for it in case they put out a new DVD

I'm not a big fan of horror movies these days, with the exception of Ghost stories, Werewolves and Vampires. Most horror films are too gory, sexually explicit and disturbing for me. But I do love the macabre and the classic Gothic tale. I would say this is more the type of story I enjoy. Plenty of suspense and unease, and an interesting twist at the end, which did have me weeping and was totally unexpected. I'd say if you appreciate subtle horror, you will enjoy this slow paced, atmospheric period tale. The cast is stellar, as well. Daniel Radcliffe breaks his Harry Potter mold completely and is believable as a grown up with a child of his own and a sad past that haunts his present. An under appreciated gem.

I love British mysteries and gothic horror stories. This film had all the ingredients for an excellent movie and did not disappoint.  The acting was spot on and wonderful. Daniel Radcliff has indeed grown into a fine actor with sensitivity and distinction. The other actors were also wonderful, including, the "Twins" (so cute) and the other cute little dog. I love dogs and especially in this movie because none of dogs became casualties like other movies manage to stoop to. This movie was so visually gorgeous. Beautiful cinematography of the English countryside. The old mansion was so realistic with all the antique furnishings and architecture. I could tell that the antique toys were real and that lent a spooky aspect to the story.  The ending was quite a twist.  Great! Highly recommended!

SPOILERS TO SOME DEGREE - STOP READING NOW IF YOU DON'T WANT TO KNOW!!!

Hopefully this is far enough down for some spoilers. No details... just my complaint with this film. Up til the end, I was enjoying the minor jump scares and intense build up of the danger and fear of what the woman in black wanted. Then they seemed to find the answer and dealt with it. All wrapped up in a nice neat package at the end, cue the happy family reunion and roll credits.

But that isn't how it ended. They didn't actually figure out what the Woman in Blacks motivation really was. They gave her what they thought she wanted and she still did her thing. This is where I stopped liking this film. I'm OK with leaving an open ending and making you want to see whatever sequel they cook up... I get that Hollywood needs to do this for money. However, in this film they just dropped the ball entirely. There was no closure at all with this film. You still don't know the Woman in Blacks motivation, she will still continue killing kids in the village, and where they go in the sequel (which I will not watch now) odds are good you still won't get closure nor even the basic understanding of what this pissed off ghost wants.

Summed up, they introduce a pissed off ghost, give you the reason it's pissed off, offer a VERY plausible way of calming said pissed off ghost, reveal that in fact that did not work and it's still pissed off and they gave no others reasons why its pissed off.

Two stars are for the acting and set as well as the build up of the plot. Any other ending and I would give it more stars

I skipped my way through this story. There were unnecessary long, dry, boring spells which were supposed to heighten the sense of dread, but only caused a snore to erupt from me. This story could have been told in less time, but if stretched, could have had a side story. Neither of these happened. There's a man who has to prove to his tired boss that he can handle a lousy lawyer's job in the country in England. He's a widower who needs his job, so he goes with plans to meet his son and the nanny in the countryside when the job is finished in a few days.
In the meantime, he sees a woman in black.  She comes and goes. Kids die when she's been seen. Nobody in town likes the idea of this lawyer going out to this haunted house to go through the late owner's papers, but no one tells him why, even though telling him wouldn't stop him, and it would sure help the viewer, by condensing some of the obviously pregnant stares, and giving us information we really could use, if only to stave off boredom.
Eventually someone tells him, he's annoyed that he wasn't told before, and he realizes his own son is coming to this place where kids are forced to commit their own deaths. The ending is like one of those internet videos.."you won't believe what happens next:" Yes I would. I didn't expect it, but I would.

This is a solid ghost story. It doesn't rely on the typical gore and bloodshed that typifies Hollywood horror today. It actually has a REAL PLOT! Imagine that! Not only is the story good (and decently true to the book on which it's based; I recommend Susan Hill's novel as well), it's scary. This movie is, to me, more terrifying than the Exorcist. I honestly screamed the first time I saw it (luckily my friends and I were the only ones in the theater!). And I'm a total skeptic in real life--I don't believe in ghosts in the least, but when watching this movie, I was as scared as if it were all actually happening to me. I loved this film.

I found it to be a good, old-fashioned Gothic ghost story with great atmosphere and tension. It might unfold a bit too slow for some, but I enjoyed the slow buildup. It had a few jump-scares with one or two 'cheep (false) scares' but others I thought were quite effective. A worthwhile view in my opinion for anyone who likes a good ghost story without a lot of gore or a barrage of special effects assaulting the storyline & senses.

It is rare to find a smart horror movie where people aren't tripping on dead branches and aren't screaming their head off for no sensible reasons.  In this Woman In Black film, Daniel Radcliff is convincing and smart as a widower who goes to a small town and witnesses mind-boggling tragedies of children dying.  The more he visits a haunted house, the more tragedy grows around him.

As time runs out, Daniel Radcliff makes a brave and logical choice in the hopes of saving his son's life as The Woman In Black draws nearer.

Can he put together the pieces of the puzzle in time to prevent the next tragedy? Will the curse of The Woman In Black ever stop?

This is a movie in the traditional haunted house style with mercifully-few over-the-top special effects and CGI. It relies on an a eerie atmosphere of dread and suspense. Set in the 1920s, the back story revolves around the unending grief and eternal revenge that lay dormant in spirits that once lived at Eel Marsh House. The manse can be reached by a ribbon of road winding from the village through a sea marsh to a rocky island, but accessible only at low tide. Good performances all around. The abandoned mansion is place with no redemption. Never any chance that this place might someday be turned into a B&B or wedding venue. If you like ghost stories in the traditional mold -- empty English manor house, foggy graveyard, people in the village exchanging knowing glances but saying little to "outsiders," an intense crescendo of suspense -- this is your kind of movie. Scares aplenty, very little gore relative to most paranormal movies.

If you're looking for a truly suspenseful old-fashioned type thriller, this movie delivers and then some. It may not appeal to the younger generation because it doesn't fulfill the horror, blood and gore that many newer movies showcase. Instead it offers edge-of-your-seat suspense along with a lot of noise and visual thrill build-up to keep you engaged in the storyline. To get away from the violence and doldrums of most computerized technology based movies, this one fits the bill. Radcliffe fulfills his role in his shy, yet overly inquisitive character who seeks out to find the answer to the many puzzles of the story. 5 Stars!

While I wasn't particularly impressed with the story, nor did I find this movie particularly frightening, I feel that it deserves a high rating for what it contributes to the horror genre: child death.  In much of the horror genre children are given a sacred space.  Generally speaking, children don't die.  If they are put into danger they are quickly rescued from it.  If a monster comes it backs away from the child, granting hi or her immunity.  When a child does die it usually happens outside of the film story line, just revealing that one of the adult characters is bothered by the loss of a child elsewhere.  This child worship was recognized and manipulated to create a series of films in which children are the monsters as well, raising the moral dilemma of killing a child character on-screen or letting the child monster succeed, usually favoring the latter.  When a child monster is killed it is usually under the premise that the child is actually an adult (human or other) disguised as a human child.
Then we introduce "The Woman in Black".  This film challenges the idea of children as protected in dangerous situations by creating a monster (ghost) that ONLY KILLS CHILDREN.  By the end of this film a viewer is likely to realize that even though there were some jump scares, they can still go home feeling safe because odds are they are outside of the age range of the monster's demographic.  My friends who have children claim a different experience because it expresses the vulnerability of their children and  plays into their own fears of losing a child (which probably makes this film more effectively frightening for parents).  With this barrier being broken I hope that future horror films will recognize the vulnerability of child characters and juxtapose our expectations of children being safe characters in the film with child death in order to create more terrifying films- ones that make you realize that nobody is safe.

My husband and I got in an argument over this one. While *The Woman in Black* was flawlessly acted, I had trouble suspending disbelief enough to enjoy the ride. I don't always expect movies to obey the rules of my reality, but I expect them to have consistent sets of rules in the context of their realities. I felt that *The Woman in Black* lacked that consistency and at times relied too much on jump-scare horror rather than the atmosphere it seemed to be trying to create.

It's worth a watch, but I'm not looking to share of with friends or make it a permanent part of my collection.

That being said: if you have Amazon Prime, therefore making this movie free, go for it.  It's not a horrible movie, and therefore might be fun to watch with friends and drinks.  Especially if you're of the movie snob/theatre type.

This movie tells the story of the woman in black who had to give up her son to her relatives. I am not sure of the reason. While under the care of these relatives, the son dies. She appears to the children and the children then commit suicide while in a trance like state. Daniel Radcliffe's character is an attorney hired to go through the papers in her house. He has a son who he is raising himself as the son's mother died in childbirth. Do Daniel's character and his son survive the woman in black? You will have to watch the movie to find out. Before I get to the review, first let me say congratulations to Daniel Radcliffe for shaking off the role that made him a household name and moving on with a surprisingly solid performance in this picture. As I watched the movie, I actually forgot all about his previous character, and was drawn in by this NEW character. Radcliffe is a young man now, and he did a splendid job in this dark ghost story. I must shamefully admit that I almost didn't watch the movie because, I too, could not imagine Harry Potter all grown up and having the audacity to try to pass himself off as anyone else BUT our hero from Hogwarts!  Well, he deserves some serious recognition for his acting skills...Because he CAN act in other roles. He CAN make you forget about the young boy that was a famous wizard! Maybe he will NOT suffer the fate of so many others that were forever doomed by playing such a popular role. It's happened time and again and the young superstar tragically fades away into obscurity. And not only did  Radcliffe do good work in this movie, ALL the actors involved did very well. As a matter of fact, I have a hunch that if more people KNEW how good this movie was they would have watched it. But, they were probably still grieving the end of the famous series by JK Rowling! Anyway, I am confident that we will be seeing a lot more of Radcliffe. ***Here's a short summary on this haunting movie: A young and upcoming lawyer is on the verge of losing his job. The depression brought on by the death of his wife during childbirth is beginning to affect every aspect of his life. He gets one more chance to snap out of it before he loses everything. He is sent to settle the affairs of an old estate. But from the very moment he arrives, he is shunned and avoided by the small towns inhabitants. He is warned to stay away from the house, because if he persists, he will bring about the wrath of a vengeful spirit. ***
  This was a pretty cool watch. I thought I'd check it out before watching the recently released, The Woman In Black 2... And I am glad I did. Watch this, it's worth the price of a rental.

I am a huge horror fan. I like the old school 80's ghost stories like "The Lady in White" and I love the slasher films, too. There's hardly a horror film I don't find some value in.

With this film, I agree with a lot of the four-star-rating comments, but I think this film moved along way too slowly, for one. Secondly, I love large, scary old houses, and since this house was actually one of the main "characters" in the film, I was very disappointed for one reason - the film was shot WAY TOO DARK, so that you could hardly enjoy or even see in most scenes what the layout of the house was like.

Yes, I understand, most of the movie, he's traipsing around the house with only a tiny candle and an axe, but dear god, people! There are things such as The Red Camera that exist and can make the darkest rooms visible! Darkly shot films can be effective and do have their place in cinema, but not when I'm getting a headache trying to see what little black shadow in a sea of black just flickered. For me, this effort in trying so hard to see through this dark lens turns into boredom and I admit I have watched this movie probably 3 times because I kept falling asleep.

I am disappointed because I really thought for once in a long time, I could be watching a very good ghost story. The ending was nice, so I am glad I finally pushed through the entire film, but the rest was just foreboding music, and vague figures and a bunch of screaming. 3 Stars for "It's Okay" is bordering the rather generous..

This is one of the most disappointing movies I have seen in a long time. The filming angles completely predicted what was coming next (e.g. the close up of the protagonist, the sound track builds, he turns, and oh no! Horrors!). Ho hum. There basically was no plot except to display the cliches - the movie started nowhere and ended in a similar fashion. A waste of my time.

I love this movie. It has a wonderful Gothic setting and is very well acted. This is the first film I've seen Daniel Radcliffe in since his "Harry Potter" days, and he does a very good job in this film. It is different, somewhat low key and not so much "in your face scary" the way some movies are. With "The Woman in Black" there are scenes that you have to watch closely to see all of the little things that are hidden in the shadows. For a horror movie, I find it rather relaxing to watch. I've watched it several times and STILL find things I've missed in earlier viewings. And, I really love the ending.

Very traditional, classic ghost story (i.e. scary not gory) that is really well done. Radcliffe's London based lawyer character is sent to close out the affairs of a dead woman in a small coastal town, and of course that job proves much more difficult and much deeper than presented. DR does a great job as a slightly discomfited, fish-out-of-water in a town that goes to great lengths to hide its secrets. Hauntingly shot, the visuals and musical score contribute to the near constant tension and some truly "made you jump" scares. That said, I found the ending to be very disappointing...a deus ex machina that comes from left field to tie things up too quickly and neatly. I enjoyed the film greatly, but the end left me feeding cheated and deprived of a truly satisfying resolution.

Excellent, classic ghost movie!  The music and atmosphere had me riveted on the screen.  I kept scanning the background for something, anything.  But I was stilled surprised when I actually saw things appear or flash by at the corner of my eye.  It made me jump with some well placed surprises which, as a horror movie lover, is no easy feat.  I was also pleasantly surprised by Daniel Radcliffe...he does an amazing job and I had to remind myself that he is the same boy who got his start as Harry Potter.  I plan to have everyone I know watch this movie...just maybe not alone in a dark house like I did, lol.

I enjoyed this, for the most part. Jumped a lot. Liked that it was a different time period. Good quality. Loved that there was nothing Harry about Arthur. They tried to write an original story line (which is much needed these days) and it was creepy but made no logical sense.  At one point I said to myself "if he goes back to that house, I'm turning this off." also, *kind of a spoiler* the "climax" ended up not helping; which i found to be dissatisfying and ironically anticlimactic. Maybe if it had been longer (or more scares) with less explaining and more left for the audience to figure out--It would have been the horror film it was intended to be and less on the thriller side. IMHO

I'm probably being a little critical only giving it 4 stars.  On a 1-10 scale I'd give it 8.5 or close to 9.  In the hands of some directors, photographers, and actors...this could have been another cheesy horror movie.  But in the hands of those here, everything was elevated and worked together to create a beautiful, haunting movie.

Daniel Radcliffe did a heck of a job as the main character, displaying proper emotion throughout.  Ciaran Hinds plays the eccentric and knocked it out of the park from the moment he opened his mouth, I didn't even know he could act like that.  And they even managed to have the child actors fit perfectly in their roles.

Some stuff must not translate to the screen, so I may never know the motivation behind some of the actors.  But they all had backstories to their characters you could tell they knew, and it gave real depth to what could have been a few roles as extras.  For example, why was the lady of the Inn so empathetic to Radcliffe?  Why was Radcliffe's boss such a jerk?  What had Radcliffe done wrong to be given this "warning" when sent to process this event?  Why was the nanny on the severe and cold side?  Why didn't the local lawyer just pretend to move things smoothly along instead of basically instigating the participation from the big city guys?  None of it really matters, but I mention it to point out they all took their roles seriously and you could tell there was more than just surface involvement in the film.

Add to that the great use of the visuals and you elevate what could have been an average story in the hands of someone else.  I have to the give the director credit for allowing all of this to be pulled off.

And yes, I'll admit I did think about this movie when I woke up in the middle of the night last night...which was a little scary.  Usually it's not a big deal to watch a horror, they are easy to forget because they so often disappoint.  But this one left me thinking, so job well done in this case.

Gothic yawns abound in this oh-so-traditional tale of the supernatural that could just as easily have been made (minus the color) in 1935. No surprises here, as ghostly faces appear on cue in top story windows, macabre toys seem to turn themselves on, and what looks like a scout troop of "Children of the Damned" show up in cemeteries. The blood-red scrawls behind the wallpaper should have read "Why bother? This is one boring film."
strange movie, but held our interest
It was a movie that kept my attention. The ending was a surprise. I will purchase the Woman in Black II.

The return of Hammer Films. Hammer was/is a British movie studio that made fantastic horror films from 1957-1974 and then they just faded away. I was reluctant to buy "The Woman In Black" starring the "kid" from the Harry Potter movies. This movie was a period piece as were most Hammer Horror movies. I almost stopped watching it a couple of times and am so glad that I didn't .

The movie slowly builds showing tidbits of ghostly visions. The viewer slowly gets sucked into the story nd you find yourself wanting to know more about what's going on. So many times we have all been told that the ending will surprise you and it doesn't. I was not expecting the way that this movie ended. I hope we see more from Hammer in the future

This will not end like you expect it to, so watch it all the way through, it's worth the slow bits to get to the end. Kept waiting for Lon Chaney to walk out of the shadows.  Only a bit of gore but not too bad.

A modern ghost story written in the style of a traditional Victorian Gothic horror, The Woman in Black ticks all of the requisite boxes; spooky house, spooky children, bereaved lawyer dealing with the affairs of the recently deceased sole occupant of aforementioned spooky house, grim weather, dour Yorkshire folk. The list goes on

With an excellent cast & locations and an experienced director there is loads of Gothic atmosphere and some excellently unexpected jumps I really rather enjoyed this classic Hammer horror. There is, however, a big but. Poor Daniel Radcliffe will never escape his Harry Potter persona. Eel Marsh House might as well have been Hogwarts and the eponymous woman could have easily have been Lord V for all the difference it made to Harrys, sorry Arthurs, performance and this seriously undermined the necessary suspension of disbelief required to enjoy any horror story.

Overall, an enjoyable, well written, acted and directed traditional British horror with a nice twist just spoilt by one thing. Shame really

The original film was excellent and different. This film is also excellent and different. There is absolutely nothing wrong with using an older film as long as it is treated with due respect. Both were eerie, suspenseful and beautifully atmospheric movies. The British seem to excel at these atmospheric films for reasons of history, culture, and fabulous locations. While both films had different endings, they were both very enjoyable for my wife and I. By the way, there is nothing wrong with a "happy ending". Modern horror film makers seem to often make pessimistic, nihilistic, and even depressingly dark films. Good over evil, is a theme that should be returned to. As a Christian, we are well aware of evil and its inevitable demise. Moderns alas, have a strong anti religious bias and absolutely no concept of evil as seen in theological terms. G.K. Chesterton's Father Brown mysteries have the good Jesuit priest/amateur detective solve crimes in a different way than Sherlock Holmes. Father Brown uses his knowledge of human nature and especially the evil that exists to solve crimes rather than by purely deductive reasoning. Father Brown not only solves crimes but he tries to save souls. He is one up on old Sherlock there.

This is your great Gothic mystery-thriller-horror film. Set just after the turn the 19th century in an isolated mansion (Eel Marsh House), on the northeast coast of England, presumably northern East Anglia or Northumbria which is Osea Island, Maldon, Essex) north of London). Arthur Kipps (Daniele Radcliff) plays his part as a representative of a London law firm very well. Having to spend nights sorting out papers to sell the old mansion entrusted to his law firm for sale he experiences more than he cares to. Radcliffe must spend these nights in Eel Marsh House due to the tide washing over the causeway (actually Osea Road) twice daily, not allowing travel otherwise. He experiences many occurrences of the supernatural while there.

You'll need to give this a go. If you're a fan of Gothic horror and mystery, you'll like this production.
