We picked up this movie on Amazon Instant Watch because we've been considering heading out to the theatre to see the sequel.  On the whole, I think we were pretty glad that we did.

The nutshell view on this is that our protagonist is sent off to a spooky house to tidy up some probate paperwork after the death of the house's last inhabitant.  When he arrives, the townspeople do everything in their power to get rid of him and refuse to explain why they're acting so oddly.  The rest is left as exploration for the prospective watcher.

To the positive, the imagery in the movie is, at times, extremely creepy.  At various points old toys are shown and I found these delightful for their historical background and as a motif for the film.  Lots of wonderful images in this movie.  Further, the whole story didn't succumb to the standard pattern you typically see in these movies.  I can't really say much more without spoiling it but suffice to say that you don't get what you expect in the end and the final twist is shocking and delightful.

To the negative, many of the horror details were very cliche: lots of doorknobs turning and when the door is opened nobody is there, briefly glimpsed faces in mirrors or in windows and mysterious shadows.  This is all standard horror movie fluff and while well done is was just like every other horror movie in the world.

In summary, this movie is heavy on imagery, setting and narrative arc but many of the details are rather blah.  As horror movies go it was high on my list simply because it didn't run the usual course of 'good, then bad, then even more bad, then better, then REALLY bad, then yay, rainbows and unicorns!'

PS: I hope my review was helpful.  If it was not, then please let me know what I left out that youd want to know.  I always aim to improve.

A very interesting and enjoyable little horror film, almost a throw back to those old haunted house thrillers from a few decades ago.  While definitely in color, the lighting scheme almost suggests those old black and white films.

A young solicitor still getting over the death of his wife is sent to a lonely house to finish up the paper work of a recently deceased woman.  He is alone in the house - or is he?  Most of the villagers avoid him, but is it because he is a stranger in their little community or do they know or fear something?  Is there something supernatural going on here or is the young man losing what's left of his sanity?

There is minimal blood and gore here and much more of an emphasis on creepy atmospherics and the occasional shock appearance.  Actor Daniel Radcliffe, stretching his acting wings after all those years as Harry Potter, does a fine job as the central character, and the supporting cast is well chosen.  The film is bathed in period detail and spooky darkness where things are barely visible or might be glimpsed off to the side.  I am not surprised to see that the famed British horror studio Hammer had a hand in this and it is good to see that venerable company back in action again.

Why four stars instead of five?  The film has a melancholy one note from the opening frame to the last, with little variety, and the story takes a little while to get moving.  But this film is not going for the blood stained effect every ten minutes.  Instead it slowly builds toward some genuinely creepy moments.  This film doesn't want to gross you out, but gradually unnerve and disturb you.  It's a more old fashioned approach to the horror genre, but fans of this type of film will enjoy "The Woman in Black."

To be honest, I wasn't sure what to expect from this movie. I was pleasantly surprised, however. It is a wonderful, atmospheric ghost story, with all the trappings of a good gothic horror, that really sucked me in. Rather than going for gore or cheap scares, this movie sets up a spooky atmosphere in a superstitious, rural small town, far removed from the modernism of the city, and adds in a creepy local legend for added creepiness. People who liked movies such as What Lies Beneath or The Others will probably like this. I will agree with other reviewers, it does move a bit slowly, but makes up for that in really setting up the atmosphere and story line.

Perhaps I shouldn't have read the book before I saw the film. As is usually the case, the book is far better than the movie. The film would have been more frightening and suspenceful if the screenwriter had kept with the story in the novel. The film doesn't reveal the "Woman in Black" all that well. The film is dark, and, when she is to be seen, she is mearly a darker shadow. In the book she is fully seen even to Kipp's detailed description of her. The book begins on Christmas Eve with Kipp and his family sitting around the tree, and the children want to tell ghost stories. The children beg Kipp to tell one, and, with much pleading, he agrees. Hence the story of the woman in black. The kicker is that the story is true. If the screenwriter had stayed with the story in the novel the movie would have been great.

Ok. So heres my review of the movie, which I originally saw in the movies when it was first released in 2012.

WARNING: SPOILERS.

As an aside, let me say this: I kind of wish I had gone to see it during the week, between the hours of 8:00 AM and 3: 00 PM, or to a very, very late showing on the weekend.

Why?

Two words: Daniel Radcliffe.

Yes, it seemed that every single teenage and/or barely-teenage girl (and boy) in central New Jersey wanted to see this flick. Im not kidding. The Harry Potter fan base came out to this movie in DROVES. I first went to the East Brunswick Mall in Central New Jersey to see it, and the 7:40 PM show was 9 tickets shy of being sold out; the only available seating was in the front row. So I left, and drove down to the Loews Theater in Freehold for their 9 PM showing. I had my ticket in hand by 8:15 and literally stood in line outside theater #7 to make sure I could get a decent seat when they finally began letting us in. By 8:45 the theater was jammed, packed to the gills, and it looked (and sounded) like a high school auditorium before a pep rally. It seemed that the crowd which had been there for the previous showing were rowdier than the theater management liked; once we were seated  but before the movie started - two ushers came into our theater and basically gave a speech explaining that the audience had to behave, or people were going to be ejected (they had had some problems with the previous horde of prepubescent Potterphiles). It worked; the crowd at our 9 PM showing was very well behaved indeed. Which, as anyone whos ever been to the movies with me will tell you, is a very, very good thing.

Right, so on to the film then (sorry, Im still thinking in Edwardian English). If you are already familiar with the original novel by Susan Hill, OR the extraordinary stage play adapted from the novel, then there will be very few surprises for you in the movie, at least in terms of the plot structure. Since Ive read the novel AND was lucky enough to see the London stage production of The Woman in Black in the West End, Im going to review this movie from the point of view of someone who has a certain frame of reference already; your mileage may vary.

The basic story is the same as the novel. Daniel Radcliffe plays Arthur Kipps, a young solicitor in turn-of-the-century England who is sent by his firm to a remote coastal village called Crythin Gifford, there to settle the estate of the recently deceased elderly widow, Alice Drablow. Ms. Drablow lived alone in an aged, isolated mansion called Eel Marsh House, which is situated on a sort of island out in the middle of the tidal marshes, only accessible by a long narrow winding road from the mainland (at low tide; the road is underwater at high tide), known as the Nine Lives Causeway. When Kipps arrives in Crythin Gifford and begins digging into the life of the deceased Alice Drablow, he experiences inexplicable and terrifying phenomena, punctuated by the appearances of a spectre known as the Woman in Black; and he uncovers the story of a tragedy that has left the town  and its children - cursed.

Most of the primary elements of the novel are here, as are all its main characters: Kipps, Daily, the local taxi-driver Keckwick, even Keckwicks dog Spider (though the dogs name is not mentioned in the film). Familiar plot points are faithfully reproduced from the novel  Kipps first meeting with Daily on the train to Crythin Gifford; the sea fret (fog) that sweeps in over the Nine Lives Causeway, out of which Kipps hears the ghostly sounds of what sounds like a tragic accident involving a horse and carriage; the tiny graveyard on the grounds of the sprawling, decrepit hulk that is Eel Marsh House; and the ghostly manifestations of the titular ghost. The acting is solid throughout. The costume design, sets, and visual/sound effects are absolutely top-notch; and the music is - if not particularly memorable  at the very least, unobtrusive. That said, this version of The Woman in Black has stripped the original story and characterizations down to their absolute bare bones, while making some pretty significant changes (and adding numerous embellishments which were not present at all in Susan Hills novel).

But of course, the question is: how is the movie?

And the answer is its OK.

Daniel Radcliffe got some flack for his performance in this film, and while I can understand how difficult it is NOT to constantly think of Harry Potter every time Radcliffe appears on the screen (which is about 99.999999% of the time), I don't think the criticism is entirely justified. Radcliffe does his best with what hes given to work with - which is not a whole lot. Its obvious about ten minutes into the film that this isn't going to be a character-driven story. He has remarkably little dialogue in the film, and the scenes which develop his character are short and somewhat perfunctory. Also, since Kipps starts off the movie already in a morose, depressive state of mind (saturated with grief over the having lost his wife in childbirth four years earlier), theres not a lot of dynamic to how his character reacts to the ghostly happenings later on.

Actually, now that I think about it, NONE of the characters had much dialogue (there was more talking going on in The Artist, and that was a silent movie). The thing about The Woman in Black is that its primarily trying to generate suspense  and that it does, mostly with long, drawn-out scenes of Kipps walking around Eel Marsh House in the dark. Theres build-up after build-up; unfortunately, the payoff isn't always worth it. The movie starts off strong, with a creepy, disturbing little vignette involving three little girls, but as it goes along the script resorts far too often to boo type scares which feel cheap and somewhat predictable. You can see most of them coming a mile away. Im not sure why the filmmakers chose to do this  perhaps they felt the original story was simply too quaint and old-fashioned for todays movie audiences, and so they said Hmm, okay, nothings happened for about five minutes - lets have something jump out right here, and make a loud noise on the soundtrack, etc. etc Not that this is anything new in horror movies, but it was not the kind of thing that made the novel - or the play  so effective.

The changes/additions which have been made to the original story are significant. When Kipps arrives in Crythin Gifford, the townspeople reject him outright, with the exception of the Dailys. At one point, the men of the town practically form a lynch mob with the intent of driving Kipps out of town, since they believe he will be stirring up trouble by going to Eel Marsh house. Theres also a Mrs. Daily in this version, and she also happens to be a medium (groan) who can channel the spirit of her dead son; this, apparently, so as to provide us with important exposition. During the course of the film, there are multiple deaths, all children, all victims of the Womans curse, all quite nasty. Speaking of the Woman, shes not alone in this version; shes got ghostly company. The lands around Eel Marsh House are also haunted by the ghosts of her victims (which doesnt quite make sense, but there you go). Theres enough of them that the movie could have been called The Woman in Black - And Friends.  Other changes are simply inexplicable: the aforementioned phenomenon where Kipps hears the ghostly carriage crash in the fog out on the causeway is depicted but once - and then the filmmakers actually SHOW the accident as it happened, thus trashing any suspense or mystery involving the source of the sounds.

The biggest change of all, however, happens towards the end of the film, when Kipps thinks hes figured out a way to put the vengeful ghosts to rest once and for all (think the American version of The Ring). Theres a bit too much suspension of disbelief involved, which I won't get into here; suffice to say its a pretty big detour from the original plot, and while I understand the desire by the filmmakers to put some sort of exclamation point on the story, it just feels like it comes out of nowhere.

The movie does look incredible; indeed, the production design really is the star here. The short glimpse of 19th century London in the beginning looks fantastic and it makes you wish there had been more of it in the film. The village of Crythin Gifford is a vision right out of an H.P. Lovecraft story. The costumes and props (check out the cars!) are as good as it gets in a period drama of this type. Eel Marsh House is an absolutely amazing creation, surrounded by brambles and weeds like Sleeping Beautys castle by way of Charles Addams. Its interior is spacious yet oppressive: dark, festooned with cobwebs, and tarnished with a patina of black soot that seems not entirely a product of the candles that Kipps is obliged to carry with him as he traipses the halls. Think the visual stylings of Sleepy Hollow MINUS the weird, funhouse distortions and unrealism, and youll have a pretty good idea of this films accomplishments.

Note to Tim Burton: THIS is how you do a period piece, bro.

To sum up  the film does have its genuine frights, but sadly it also has far too many jack-in-the-box type scares, which ultimately don't stay with you. Daniel Radcliffe does an okay job with what probably amounts to about two whole pages of dialogue, and since most of the movie centers on him, it makes for a fairly quiet two hours (unless you count the music and sound effects). Theres never really enough character development or exploration of the relationships of the various characters (like, for example, Alice Drablow and Jennet Humphrye) to get the viewer all that emotionally invested in the film. The Woman in Black is eerie, and atmospheric, but its probably not going to give you nightmares. It doesnt get under your skin like the West End play (which was also adapted from the novel) does.

Which makes one wonder; how on earth can a stage play be more frightening than a movie?

But thats a topic for another discussion.

Relies heavily on "jump scares" but they will keep you on edge throughout, especially in the final act. Fair warning: don't watch if you cannot tolerate dead children/kids in peril. I hear a sequel is coming, probably with a different cast and director, but I will be eager to see how this ghost story evolves.

Daniel Radcliffe's character "Arthur Kipps" saying "I think I'll work through the night", seemed ridiculous to me after all he had already come to find out about the house and "The Lady". For so many frightening things going on, Radcliffe seemed to be quite indifferent to it all. Like he was there, but his mind wasn't.  I also would have chosen someone else to play "The Woman in Black".  Someone who would have blown people out of their seats when they finally saw who was playing her. Like Catherine Zeta Jones, Tilda Swinton, Rebecca De Mornay, Monica Potter, or Sarah Douglas. I hope the director does a better job if he is planning on filming a sequel.

I'm glad I watched this over Halloween weekend. This is a well-made traditional ghost story and while it doesn't have the reputation of Ju-On it has quite as dire a situation, perhaps even more frightening. The locations and cinematography deliver a fantastic spooky and menacing atmosphere and Dan Radcliffe perfectly delivers a solid performance of a man stunned by his encounter with the supernatural, not quite believing, not quite daring to believe, until he can't deny the evidence of his own eyes.

Two stars for his stunning eyes and great trailer, which induced me to watch.  I'm a chump for a potential thrill.  And this movie did NOT deliver.  Let me sum up the movie (spoilers)

A.  I'm sad.  Everything is dark.  B.  Why is everyone looking at me like I'm a ghost?  C.  Creep creep creep....ITS a GHOST!!!  Oh wait, no it's not.  D.  What's THAT????  Oh it's nothing.  Just a trick of the light.  E.  Camera pans up behind him.....WHOS BEHIND ME?!?!??!??  Oh no one.  Never mind.  F.  Senseless unrelated deaths.  G.  Let's fix a tragedy as the ghost tries to stop us blah blah blah.  H.  We're dead.  Yay!!!!!

I was so excited to see they've revived  "Hammer Horror", if not the actual studio at least we get a releasing arm with the moniker. Based on Susan Hill's novel of the same name is the first mainstream film Daniel Radcliffe starred in post his "Harry Potter" series, and he does a good job of stepping away from the lightning bolted wizard he's associated with.

"The Woman in Black" is the atmospheric tale of a widower, Arthur Kipps, struggling with the death of his wife and raising his young son. Kipps is in debt and in jeopardy of losing his job as a lawyer. His boss assigns him the task of selling an old estate, and organizing the papers of the deceased owner. Upon arriving at the dreary town, Kipps finds himself ostracized by the townspeople, and the people he does meet, try to hurry him out of town. Kipps soon learns that there are stories surrounding the old estate he is tasked with selling, and that the town fears the vision of a woman dressed in black, who when seen, causes the death of a child.

I like the atmosphere of this film, and the way the film is shot. Living up to it's namesake studio, this is a gothic horror tale with all of the bells and whistles. There are a few frights sprinkled here and there as Kipps explores the huge estate, but the fear in this film lies more with the mood than with the jump scares.

I think this is a semi-successful blending of classic Hammer Horror with newer "Paranormal Activity" type jumps tossed in occasionally. Radcliffe does a good job of making us forget "Harry Potter", but his Kipps is such a dull character, almost sleepwalking through the first 40 minutes or so of the film. I think the biggest problem with "The Woman in Black" is that every character is weird or mysterious, from the grieving mothers, to Kipps, to the inn keepers, there's just no one here to relate to.

If you're in the mood for a slow-burn horror film, give this a shot, it's a creepy movie with more depth than the latest "Conjuring" or "Paranormal Activity".

This brilliant, old-fashioned ghost story has the type of dread and tension that's hard to come by these days. Don't let the PG-13 fool you, this thing gets intense. Sure, there are some very classically slow moments of drama and character, typical of traditionally gothic horror and not for short-attention spans. But when things get going, it doesn't get much more frightening. There's one extended sequence in the film that ranks among the classics in terms of pure terror.

Most of the best frights are of the "walking slowly towards a spooky thing" variety, but there are still some fantastic jump scares that benefit from having the volume scream from 0 to 100 in a blink. The production design is fantastic too, with lots of great effort put into the house, pictures, landscape toys and ghosts to make everything as creepy as possible.

Throw in solid performances, a quality script, good sound and score, nice cinematography, and perhaps the film's only flaw is the sometimes brooding pace. Indeed, this film is a modern masterpiece in the horror genre.

I was drawn to watching this movie for several reasons.  I love the Harry Potter films, and therefore love the actor Daniel Radcliffe.  Also, the movie takes place in England, my favorite place.  The time period is around the very late 1800's, where candles light a dark house and cars are a recent novelty.

This movie begins in London where the main character accepts a work assignment to travel to an abandoned estate in the country.  His career with a law firm seems on shaky ground and this appears to be a do or die task for him to execute.  His wife passed away four years ago after giving birth to their only son.  He still mourns her loss and has sightings and dreams of her.

The journey to the estate is frought with bad weather and frightened stares from the residents nearby.  The general tone is that these people want him gone, but he's got a job to do.  The house is clearly haunted and hints of this build gradually from the getgo.  There isn't a boring moment in this film.  The evidence of haunting and the story behind it builds deliciously as the film progresses.  It's scary, interesting and touching all in one.

I wanted to see this film when it came out in the theaters a  year or two ago, but never got around to it.  I think it did well but not great when it was released,  This is a Prime Instant Video offering, so as a Prime member I got to watch this for free.  This movie was stellar and I highly recommend it.

For atmosphere and intrigue, this is a definite 5 star. I truly love a good Ghost Story and this has a great ghost story. But THIS ghost  story somehow lacked depth and emotion. I attribute this to the miscasting of Daniel Radcliffe, not because of his prior work as Harry Potter, but because he did not deliver a performance worthy of the story being told. You will notice that his performance is stilted and "one-note". If he is not terrified or bothered by the unsettling events taking place, how can we? By the end of the movie we should either be applauding or in tears.  That being said, there are some creepy moments and chills throughout the film and I do recommend as a "G" rated Halloween movie for all ages.

Based on the Susan Hill book of the same name, this is actually the second version put to film.  The first is the BBC production from 1980, which alas is only available on R2 dvd (although it has been on youtube for awhile, so if you get a chance check it out)

I am a big fan of Daniel Radcliffe. So, my admiration for his work led me to this film. It was reminiscent of the genre I grew up with, such as 13 Ghosts in 3-D, The Twilight Zone, and The Outer Limits. I am also a fan of movie music scores and this score was brilliant. I am an old movie buff of age 62 and for a movie to actually scare me at this age, is a testimony to its excellent script and the strength of the talent of  Daniel Radcliffe and his supporting cast.

While I will admit this film did have a fair amount of creepiness, it just didn't have a good plot or conclusion. The history of the Woman in Black is not expanded on very well. This is part of why I'd watch a thriller or a gore-fest horror film, for the background story. Radcliffe does alright as Arthur, the lawyer/ bank employee, something along those lines that comes to settle an old creepy estate. While the film is slow, that isn't the part that bothered me the most. The ending did not have a shred of resolution to it. Maybe I should say that the film just ends a bit abruptly with so many questions left unanswered. It's an alright film, but don't expect you'll want to own it or even watch it again.

Don't waste your time. There were holes in the story. Many holes. And I still don't understand the concept of the woman in black. I mean if she was so angry about her child drowning why would she take it out on other kids. Wouldn't that oppose her anger? It would make more sense to kill their parents in my opinion. But I'll admit the settings were pretty nice. So for that it gets one star.

This film is predicable and lacking in any real style.  It can best be summed up as a very poor imitation of Hitchcock's masterful style.  Where Hitchcock keeps the viewer on the edge of their seat this film has a clumsy and heavy handle interpretation of the style of Hitchcock.  Where Hitchcock would have the viewer holding their breath wondering what was coming next this film by 30 minutes into the film has the viewer going here we go again another "scary" moment.

The acting is also lackluster and over the top performances with Daniel Radcliffe providing overacted clues which scream the plot of the film prior to the action having actually taken place.  The film is sadly not the best performance of any of the actors of the production.

Even free with amazon prime streaming not worth the watch.  If you want horror in the classic sense versus the currently popular gore and guts do yourself a favor and get yourself a good Hitchcock - perhaps one you haven't seen before.

By the halfway mark I was more focused on the program I was working on than the movie, it just kinda faded into the background and I wasn't even remotely lost when I would re-engage the movie, because as I said, the story is so familiar. If the setting and atmosphere are important to you when watching a movie, this one will charm you.  The long shots of the marsh and the lonely road that must be taken to get to the house that is the main setting, are wonderful.  You know that someone already alone as Arthur's character, is; will spend more time alone.

The house he explores while looking for strange sounds and the like, is wondrous, each room is different and filled with Victorian/Edwardian clutter, and more papers for him to go through. His job there is to go through all of the documents in the house to make sure that the will on file is the newest one.  He keeps finding cards in bundles, and a series of letters.  He is also distracted often from his work, by the sounds of toys and periodic things that go bump in the night.

If you want a gory, bloody mess of a movie, please look elsewhere, this is more of an old-style movie where the story carries the sense of unease instead of pools of blood.

Some folks have said it moves too slowly.  I don't think it does.  A movie moving "too slowly" is very subjective, and depends some on what generation a person is from, too.  The suspense is built up really well, with the traditional Gothic elements of the big house, stairway, lots of shadows, sheets over the furniture, and statues and dolls appearing as though they will come to life at any moment.  The silence in the film, along with exaggerated sounds of Arthur moving through the home and the sudden loud noises, add a lot of mystery.

Another criticism I read from a viewer is that Daniel Radcliffe is "wooden".  I don't think he is wooden!  He is a very good adult actor.  You can tell what he is thinking and feeling throughout the film, without him saying anything!  Plus, it is not uncommon for a character in a movie or a book to appear as an "empty vessel" because they are still grieving the loss of a loved one.

I watched this up to the point where Arthur discovers a huge secret within the Drablow family, from reading letters he had found.  So up to this point, I thought it was a really well done movie, with great acting.  I also like the message that Arthur's friend gives him, to "not chase after shadows".  It's something worth considering in real life.

Someday, I hope I can finish this movie, but it won't be today!  Too scary.

Entertaining Gothic horror in the vein of The Others, The Woman in Black never really aspires to be more than it is, which is why it works so well. It relies far more on mood and atmosphere than jump scares (of which there are some) or gore (none), which I think makes for a more enjoyable movie. Its one real problem is the casting of Daniel Radcliffe. He's a capable enough actor, but it's just nearly impossible to believe Harry Potter as an adult, let alone a morose widower.

The plot is fairly standard, as these things go: main character with some sort of personal tragedy for a backstory has, for some reason, to go visit an overly large and creepy home where some other tragedy occurred. Hauntings ensue, main character goes exploring when he should be running, et cetera, roll end credits. It breaks no new ground. Still, it's immensely enjoyable all the same, and not a bad way to spend a couple of hours in a dark house one evening.

I love suspense movies, but  this one did not have enough dialogue to move the story on a a good pace. It isn't until the last third of the movie that we get any real details as to the cause of the trouble. The actors are fine in their roles I just don't think they had enough to do except look pensive or distressed. There were a few good scenes to make you jump and plenty of creepy atmosphere, but this movie never was riveting for me.

Pretty much a disappointment, all over. Radcliffe was wooden. Didn't necessarily fit his apparent character, either. For example, when stuff going on in the house was particularly mind shattering, he walked around at his normal gait and looked around at everything. No sense of fear, although we get the idea that inside he should have been frightened enough to extrude the proverbial fecal brick. (pardon the perhaps crass, altho perfectly apt, allusion)

There was supposed to be a psychodramatical link between him and the title character, although that was made apparent through what seemed a terribly cheap motif that repeated throughout the film. This added to the unbelievable nature of it.

At its best, this was a B-grade horror movie. Most of the time it rated C and D. Don't bother.

As for the plot ... as I said, this is not my genre, but even so, the plot seemed pretty thin and repetitive.  The same sense of suspense, the same apparition, the same result ... I was really losing interest by the end.  And the ending ... just seemed wrong.  Dumb, in fact.

Sorry, Daniel, but I wish I could get those two hours of my life back.

From the moment I saw that this was available to view on Prime, I went back and forth on whether or not to watch it. I've been burned by so-called horror movies so many times that I have become very, very wary. Truly frightening ghost stories are few and far between. Why is supernatural horror so hard to get right? I suspect that the temptation to go over the top becomes too great for directors, whereas in my opinion as a viewer, it's slow and subtle that get it right.

This movie gets it right, and Daniel Radcliffe is brilliant in his role. He's come a long way since Harry Potter. There are scenes in this movie that are so thrillingly spooky, I think this could become a regular for my Halloween night viewing. How I wish more writers and directors would take note of how to tell a proper ghost story.

The final shot alone makes me ever so glad I have my cats to watch over me while I sleep tonight. If I can sleep...

So glad I watched this during the day. Definitely scary but I love how the tale unfolds. A lawyer still in grief over using his wife at childbirth is sent from London to a village to "sort the papers" of a recently deceased prominent lady. The inn keepers and village solicitor try to get him to leave as quickly as possible without actually visiting the house, but this job is on the line. Once he goes out to the mansion, set far from the village past the marshes, children in the town begin dying through tragedies. He is blamed--because he went up to the house. As he sorts through the papers and has some paranormal experiences he pieces together the facts behind a local legend that whenever anyone spots the Woman in Black who haunts the marshes looking for her son, she will appear to "spell" the town's children into tragic behavior. Now, to protect his own son, he feels he must put an end to the curse by reuniting the woman with her child.
This movie was creepy-scary without all the latest "Hollywood" special effects. Just a good fright with a twist!

The Woman in Black is one of those screamer movies that will startle the beejeezuz  out of you; it can't be helped unless of course you have trained yourself to be a completely inert being, in which case there's little hope for you. This appears to be a remake of a movie of the same name about a grieving young lawyer who goes to a small village to sort through the legal papers of a recently deceased in a house and small town haunted by a woman in black.  He has a small son and the town's children are mysteriously dying in strange ways.  If it were not for the wonderful acting of Ciaran Hinds who played a sympathetic villager and kept me watching until the end, I would have rated the movie a one star.  Although I often prefer a slower paced movie, this one did not seem to be moving at all.  Not particularly scary, just sad.  I was not drawn into the inner world of the main character, which could have made it more interesting.  If you want to watch a movie about a ghost getting revenge with some of the same story features (e.g., dragging a dead body out of a lake/swamp and bringing old secrets into the light), try Ghost Story.

I suppose that this is like a theatre production, so poetic license comes into play.  It is well acted.  However, the story is completely implausable.  One of the scenes involves lifting a corpse of a small boy out of a quicksand bog.  Problem, there should not be anything left of the body except bones.  Time has passed.  It is also difficult for me to buy that a man would love his deceased wife so much, that it would be ok with him  to die with his young son to be with her.  How about just loving the son, and bringing him up to become whatever he was meant to be.  That is enough dream for anyone.  To paraphrase Dumbledore, "It does not do to dwell so much on the past, and forget to live."  That kind of thinking should actually do in the evil ghost lady who wants to kill other people's children.

I read the 1 stars and the 5 star reviews.  What I like most about the 6 star review is that most "get it".  70's era horror based on classic Brit novels.  This reminded me of the 1981 Ghost Story, but was much more.  Scottish or Northern English type horror.  One of the bad reviews stated it was linear.  Yeah, it was.  And at the end when you thought the ghost was going to be satisfied, it wasn't (of course) and then when it takes it's most recent victims, it is satisfied and shows mercy. A weird twist but OK.  But you know it isn't done killing.  To dog this film out and compare or criticize it compared to the Potter series is off-base and pretty stupid.  Kinda like comparing the Vietnam war to any of the Gulf Wars. The comments come from an utter misunderstanding of the genre and an over abundance of feeling like you just have to say something and you vomit from the mouth.  Useless.  I'm not overly impressed with the film, but I had some raised hairs on the back of my neck, was entertained and was engaged, which is why I'm writing a review.  I just gotta say that the people that were overly critical might want to switch back to watching the movies Hollywood wants you to watch, and stop watching these independent-type films, because you obviously know what you like.

Very dark! Nothing like Harry Potter! Daniel Radcliffe plays the lead of a young solicitor troubled by his wife's passing. He needs to do legal work in a house inhabited by the ghost of the woman in black whose child had died and whose body had never been found. She was behind the deaths of a number of children from the town. Surprise ending.
Finally, a good old fashioned suspenseful scary movie that gives you goosebumps and makes you jump, without gore, violence and bloodshed. Bravo.

There is a subtle genius to this movie.  Initially when it ended the group I was watching it with all said, "Wait--what?  That's not right!"  In other words, it elicited a very strong reaction from us.  As I thought back on it, I realized that this movie was brilliantly done.  The acting, lighting, cinematography, etc worked together in a way that is more subtle yet powerful than the horror films I am used to seeing.  For instance, it starts out slow, and just when I was about to feel bored, something happened that made me jump out of my skin.  For the remainder of the movie, I focused more on the shadows and reflections in the background than I did on the characters' faces.  THAT is brilliance on the director's part!  Now, without spoiling it for anyone, I will say that we reacted as strongly as we did because our expectations were not met--and that is also a bit of brilliance.  This is a movie that I will recommend, and that I will watch again--not so much for the entertainment value of being frightened, but just to appreciate the genius involved in creating it.

Living out on an eel marsh where the sea mists blow, back in 1880's, in a big sprawling English mansion, was apparently a very bad thing.  However, for filming, it sure does create an interesting backdrop to "Harry Potter" actor, now adult, Radcliffe.  He is cast as a widower with debts and a small son (wife died in childbirth, naturally), and if he cannot straighten out the latest will and testament, his job at the law firm is over.  So off he goes to Creepyvillage, where everyone wants him out of there, yet he persists in digging into the past.  The past is hanging all around him in this dusty and cobwebbed mansion.  Doors slam and empty rockers rock.  Windows open and curtains blow.  Ghosts in old dresses (no male ghosts) appear here and there, up stairs, down int he garden, then vanish.

The widower character, Lawyer Mr. Kipps, is not a believer in ghosts.  That is a critical reason he can carry  on his spooky investigation through piles and piles of old papers.  He is fortified in this belief by a local man who offers to  drive him out across the marsh in his horse and carriarge, reassuring him that it is all nonsense what the locals say about the past and some daughters who killed themselves.

It is a pleasure to see former Harry Potter star Radcliffe all grown up
And dressed as an English lawyer of 1880's.  The boy playing his son is his own godson.  It is the story itself that May rancor a bit.  It is naturally all impossible to those who don't believe in the dead appearing as ghosts.  Nonetheless those who do or those who accept at least the premise, can enjoy a frightening, dark, misty, decaying and abandoned mansion and its former inhabitants rattling around and trying to rattle our lawyer Kipps.

His own dead wife is also a ghost and has a part to play in this.

Do the dead live on?  They do at least in the minds of those who
Knew them, loved or hated them.

Now that robin williams  is no longer with us, perhaps his ghost will appear as Mork.  I had always wanted to offer him
A part in a film I  am planning about San Francisco tourism.  He would
Be the driver of a big double decker bus as we'll
As the tourguide and he would crash into Eddie Mirphy. Driving a cable car of course.

This is an average horror film that takes its name and a few of the plot points from a really superior Gothic novella.  THE WOMAN IN BLACK by Susan Hill is one of the scariest ghost stories I have ever read.  This 2012 film THE WOMAN IN BLACK while atmospheric and foreboding does not come close to the source material and some silly changes are made to the original for reasons that are inexplicable to me.  Daniel Radcliffe does do a good job as the hero, a young lawyer sent to an eerie, remote house in a well portrayed Edwardian Britain to settle the estate of a recently deceased woman.  Radcliffe's character in this version is  a widower and the father of a four year old child another plot change I didn't particularly appreciate.  If I had not read Hill's original novel I probably would have been much happier with this film that does have some merit but I feel it would have had a much better movie if it had been  more faithful to Susan Hill's original vision.  Apparently there are a 1989 made for British TV version that was well received as well as a long running West End play that are entitled THE WOMAN IN BLACK and follow Hill's work somewhat more closely.

The only sense to be made of the ending is that we are not dealing with a mere Ghost or vengeful spirit but an entirely demonic thing.  The amends Radcliffe's character attempts to make to what he believes is a grieving spirit of a mother, is highly implausible in it's execution and successful retrieval. Truly a self-sacrificing act that no Demon would care about. Read how this movie begins and ends on Wikipedia before watching. Uses very little from the book.  Makes radical changes.  The earlier movie makes some, but is closer to the story and has many startling moments.  Apparently the director of this newer movie thinks darkness and semi darkness equal suspense and horror;  here, they equal only eyestrain and boredom.

GREAT PRODUCTION VALUES  and 'atmosphere' but this Movie version based on the book doesn't quite pass the brilliant 1993 Television version ... which is far superior  thrills, chills and a somewhat different and devastating ending.

Odd glitch though  ... when risking the dreaded quicksand our hero has a rope solidly tied around his waist ......yet when the doomed carriage and the decaying charges are located - the rope has mysteriously been attached to the carriage frame - not our here ....... a superhuman 'switch' in pitch dark under the suffocating sands?

Daniel Radcliffe gives a memorable performance as Arthur Kipps, a London solicitor (attorney) and widowed father of a 4-year-old boy who is on thin ice with his firm due to non-productivity because of grief over his wife's passing. He is given one final chance to prove his value to the firm and keep his job: Go to the remote village of Crythin Gifford and settle the probate affairs of the rambling, secluded mansion of Eel Marsh House, whose tenants recently died. He soon discovers and becomes immersed in the macabre secrets of the house and village in this carefully told story.

THE WOMAN in BLACK is the sort of thing I didn't think could still be done these days, a gothic horror story about a haunted house with a clever, original plot and mythos, disturbing images but no schlocky gore for its own sake, and above all, genuinely frightening qualities. The question of whether or not Kipps will keep his job adds to the suspense. The cinematography is first-rate, with bleakly striking views of the English countryside and village. The early 1900s time period is captured most convincingly. Excellent acting by everyone else as well, particularly the various child actors and Ciarn Hinds as local resident Sam Daily. Finally, a beautifully unexpected ending.
Love this movie. I'm not the biggest horror movie person out there, but after seeing it in theaters, I ended up loving it and just had to have my own copy!

A strong 4 to 4 and 1/2 star movie. Not the scariest, not the most original, but a fine addition into the horror/thriller genre.

The Woman In Black is a very dark, atmospheric horror. Beautiful settings are used to great effect in creating an unsettling mood throughout the picture. The acting is good (but might require some subtitles at times for some deep British accents) and the special effects are also well done. The lighting was also appropriate for each individual scene. It was dark enough to create an uneasy mood, but light enough to see what was actually happening. Lighting is one of my pet peeves, but this movie pulled it off.

So I have to mention the flaws..... The story is good, but is mostly recycled ideas taken from other previous titles. I don't take away that many points for that though as it is rather difficult to scribe a completely original story in this day and age. It also changes these ideas up just enough to make the story its own. The only other knock against this film I could think of would be that it is rather slow at times. This is used to ramp up the mood in some areas, but can become rather dry in others. Still, the movies pace is pretty reasonable, which is why I still gave it such a strong mark.

In all, a surprising entry into the world of horror. It won't scare the pants off of you, but you'll get tension and, possibly, a few jumps!

This movie scared the wee out of me.  I've seen a lot of the old scary movies (aka "The Shining"), the ghost movies (aka "Poltergeist"), and the suspenseful movies (aka "The Others").  This movie combines the best features of all of those movies.  I don't like bloody/horror movies like the old Freddy Kruger movies or movies like "Saw" where you're scared because someone is being victimized by another person, and this movie definitely didn't have any features like that,  It was just suspenseful and creepy.  I think it would be a good movie for teenage girls to watch at a slumber party (if they didn't want to sleep after!) or for a family with middle school-age kids to watch (if they were all going to be crashing in the living room afterwards!). My husband and I watched it with my college aged and high school aged kids, and all 4 of us were jumping out of our chairs!

The special effects on the ghostie were pretty cool. But other than that this movie is pretty average. Good performances, some decently scary parts, the overall plot is okay too and the ending is fitting. Not great, but not terrible. Don't go actively looking for this one, but I'd watch it if it was on T.V and I had nothing better to do.
Very good ghost story with a good storyline.  Dark and intense.  Moody. I really enjoyed the whole movie and appreciate no bad language.

If you want an old fashioned haunted house story without gore, this is it! Anyone know of other movies similar in tone and quality? Well done!

This is a dark tale of a ghost who is hell-bent on pure vengeance.  Normally, a ghost takes vengeance on those who have wronged him/her, and not on other innocent victims.  This ghost, however, doesn't know when to quit.

For some reason it's really hard in this day and age to find a good Victorian ghost movie, and this one did not disappoint in the slightest. The atmosphere was terrific, it didn't rely solely on jump scares and really let the location and the circumstances build the suspense and dread. Definitely recommended in this age of shaky cams and bombastic music cues.

Had I been able, I'd have given this three-and-a-half rather than four stars -- but it's closer to a four than a three.

As other reviewers have noted, this adaptation of the popular novel and play steers clear of "slasher" stunts (guts and gore) and instead focuses on atmospherics. Certainly the production design is decidedly Victorian Gothic, and the general tone is moody and disquieting. As Arthur Kipps, a young widower swept up in a haunted house, really a haunted village, mystery, Daniel Radcliffe acquits himself pretty well. His strongest scenes are those in which he has no dialogue. I don't mean that as a backhanded compliment; he shows an expressiveness through his body language that makes speech unnecessary. The rest of the cast is also solid.

This film is not consistently sure-footed. Unlike, say, "The Sixth Sense," a ghost movie that always seems to know what its doing, "The Woman in Black" sometimes seems to toss out scares just for the heck of it, and some of them are predictable. A really rigorous analysis of the plot would probably reveal some holes and thematic inconsistencies. On the other hand, this IS a ghost movie. How demanding should we be? Particularly when the ending (again as other reviewers have remarked) manages to be ingenious, shocking, and ambiguous all at once.

The director said that although he set the film in Victorian England, he didn't want it to have a period feel; only a period look. To that end the dialogue is, depending on one's view, either jarringly or refreshingly modern. This is taken to a rather comical extreme when a woman is referred to in writing as "Ms." a prefix that didn't come into use until decades later. (It would be like referring to "Ms. Jane Austen.")

This edition includes three bonus features: a making-of featurette, a piece on Radcliffe, and audio commentary with the director and the screenwriter. The making-of is short and moderately interesting; the Radcliffe bit is worthwhile to hear some of his insights on the character (and why on earth he stayed in that house, for goodness' sake!), but the commentary is a disappointment, consisting mostly of self-congratulations and the filmmakers "wowing" over their own creation.

But for all the minor criticisms, I certainly recommend this for anyone who likes old-fashioned spooky stories without the gore and profanity that mark modern horror.
Full of atmosphere and spooky gothic themes without the gore and blood, but with a few scary spots. The ending is a surprise.

I enjoyed The Woman in Black--if that is the word for a movie with a heart-wrenching ending. I thought it was an accomplished modern replica of a dark Victorian story, with touches of HP Lovecraft and Dickens.  The period look was absolutely fabulous--and what fun to see good old Hammer films involved in this marvelous British production! They always knew how to make a scary movie with a spectacular in-period "look." The stark sets of the haunted town (Wales?) and the engulfing tidal bogs are real places which the inquiring sort of tourist can still find. There was nothing here that would be taken amiss by any Time Travelers from the 19th Century. Many of them, in fact, would doubtless see the ending as a happy one!

First off, I didn't want to purchase this movie. But I did. It wasn't available for rent on iTunes either. My rating is because of the movie though, not because of that.  As far as the movie goes, I knew it was a "thriller" and not a "horror" movie. Big difference, I normally don't like/watch horror movies. I do love thrillers. This one had a bit of the horror aspect though. The movie itself was very slow. Was waiting for something to happen, and when something did it was just the same thing over and over again and at some point I just started rolling my eyes, waiting for something different to happen or a turn in the plot. Something. With the real antique toys and everything, it could have been SO much more! Could have been a lot better. It only really got better starting near the end as sad as that is, and then the very end had my eyes really big. (Although at the same time it didn't make sense to me why it ended so.) It's not one of those movies that leaves you hanging at the very end, at least not totally, which is something I really hate. The ending it great. I had thought I had definitely known how it was going to end out, but I was only partly right. There was a lot more there than I would have imagined. The movie will surprise you. I would say watching is worth it, for an experience. Purchasing it, definitely not... Besides, it is not one of those kinds of movies that you would want to watch over again anyway. Radcliffe was absolutely wonderful here. And it being a "period" thriller is a big big plus! He was perfect for the part and hope he does more movies in this genre.

I hadn't read the book before watching this movie.

As an author, I wanted to see how this subject was handled. I was interested in the pacing, the plot twists, the setting, and so on.

As a fan of Daniel Radcliffe, I wanted to see how he handled this kind of role.

In general, the pacing was slow, exactly as you'd expect from a classic gothic tale. The setting was a visual delight, and I recommend watching the movie with the commentary turned on (after seeing it, start to finish, without the commentary) to get the most from the way the movie was designed and produced.

Radcliffe's performance was remarkable.  Large portions of the movie focus on him, alone, in a mundane (but creepy) setting.  He has no dialogue in many (perhaps most) scenes.  Despite that, he's able to convey the emotions of the character, and maintain interest.  Frankly, his performance is so compelling, it's almost hypnotic.

Unfortunately, the movie isn't completely worthy of Radcliffe's efforts.

One major problem was: the movie didn't convey a solid enough "character in his normal world" foundation at the start of the film.  We're too quickly thrown into his grief. Almost from the start, Radcliffe's character is a haunted man. (No pun intended. ) We see him living his life in the shallow, by-the-numbers manner that many grieving people adopt while they recover from a stunning loss.

This film also falters due to some frankly cheesy visual elements.  I won't spoil the movie with details, because I think this IS a movie well worth watching, and owning for the special features included in the DVD.  However, the very last scene was such a cliche, it spoiled much of what had come before.  I couldn't help laughing when I saw it.

I feel that the director tried to be all things to all moviegoers.  If he'd remained more faithful to the book, or to a classic "hero's journey" plot, or committed to making this a date-night horror flick, the movie would have been more successful.  Instead, it's part art film, part horror, and it's not full satisfying on either count.

I'm reminded of the movie, "The Haunting," based on Shirley Jackson's novel.  The 1963 version was a classic -- now a little dated -- and inspired Disney's "Haunted Mansion" attraction. However, the 1999 remake tried to be an updated, more socially relevant tale, and it failed badly. Like "The Woman in Black," it lapsed into cliches at the end.

After seeing the movie, "The Woman in Black," I read the book by Susan Hill. It's a modern classic and follows the well-worn traditions of gothic horror novels.  The tale is slow paced and reflective. The book is also very different from the movie, from start to finish.

All in all, I think devoted fans of gothic-style horror will enjoy this film enough to want to own a copy.  Just be sure it includes the special features.

And, for authors, this film is a good study of pacing, plotting, and what can make a story compelling, despite other shortcomings.  While part of that is a credit to the director and screenwriter, as well as the movie's visual design, I'd give most of the credit to Daniel Radcliffe. He portrays a man numbed by grief, with surges of frustration and plunges into apathy. It's never a one-note or two-note performance, though it easily could have been.

If the producers had committed to making this an artistic, classic gothic tale, and incorporated more of the "hero's journey" structure, this could have become an enduring, five-star, must-see movie.

Fans of Daniel Radcliffe will be impressed with the subtleties of his performance. And, it's still a good movie, if you're a fan of gothic tales or horror films.  But, it falls short of being a success for either audience.

Get the DVD and make sure to see the movie with the commentary on, to get the most from this. The special features on the DVD make a world of difference. If I were to see just the film itself, this would have been a three-star review, at best.

I haven't read the short story upon which it is based, but it was too much a rip-off/too derivative of Japanese horror. Except for time and place, the opening scene was almost identical to The Suicide Club. I always dislike Japanese ghost stories because they're so hopeless - although they can be effective social satire they epitomize Asian fatalism to me - while in Western ghost stories, if the protagonist rights the injustice that's causes the haunting then he's saved (i.e., Ghost Story, The Haunting). In most American ghost stories good old Western individualism and ingenuity save the day - the protagonist isn't just hung out to dry by forces beyond his control while the viewer is subjected to the protagonist being terrorized and tortured for 2 hours. The ending was just such a Ring-like bummer, although the concept of being reunited with your family seems nice. Although I guess that depends, since that could be some people's version of hell.

The movie is scary enough.  One scene even made me jump in my chair a little.  The ending left me puzzled, though.  It was difficult to tell who won in the end.  Movies (or stories) often set up in the beginning and reinforce throughout the story the rules of the story's universe, i.e., how things work and why.  It seemed like all the work the main character went through, the whole movie, to try to reconcile the old haunt, believing he understood the rules, was for naught.  And so, it seemed like we spend most of the movie learning the rules of the universe but find out at the end they were all wrong.  To me, that is dissatisfying.

The Woman in Black is a spooky old fashioned Gothic ghost story where faces and footprints appear from nowhere. The creepy old house has a tainted, tragic past. The property has grave sites and it is surrounded by marsh land that is flooded by the tide each day which makes it even more eerie. The villagers don't want anything to do with it or the vengeful woman in black who continues to seek revenge even after her death. Daniel Radcliffe does a fine job in this role as do the other actors.
Picture was so dark , hard to see what was going on and kind of boring. I was disappointed with this DVD.

4 Stars = Classic

Good old fashioned haunted house ghost story, like they don't make many anymore! I've always liked Danial Racliffe, whether he's Harry Potter, or the grown to a man actor he is now. There's a vulnerability to his performances which makes his roles like this very believable.

"The Woman In Black" delivers through in a steady build up of story. Beautiful cinematography which adds to the thick foggy atmosphere of dread & bewilderment. A fine soundtrack that is there for all the right moments, & a impeccable cast of English actors. Here you have a movie that delivers what it promises, fear of the unknown, tickling & prickling the hairs on the back of your neck, just enough to get under the skin.

Everything comes together in this movie to qualify as the kind of scary movie you can't watch by yourself!  A very mature Daniel Radcliffe is Arthur Kipps, an attorney hired to go through paperwork at a dark, gothic, lonely mansion, with its own cemetery, out in the swamplands of England.  The only road to this home is flooded regularly, so Arthur is at the mercy of the  tides.  The time is the early 1900s, and the only means of lighting are candles & oil lamps which help set the mood.  The movie sets your nerves on edge with perfectly filmed movements behind Arthur who is completely focused on his job.  It is frightening when the fur on the back of the dog's neck raises and he begins to growl at movement down the hall.  I definitely recommend watching this in the dark...but not alone!

I thought this was one of the best "ghost story" movies I've seen in a long time.  I was surprised at how many times they were able to make me jump!  The atmosphere is classic gothic horror; lots of suspense, and plenty of shivers!  Fire up the popcorn, and turn out the lights, you're gonna LOVE this one!

The Woman in Black stars Daniel Radcliffe (handling his own pretty well in his first post-Harry Potter role) as Arthur Kipps, a struggling lawyer in the United Kingdom's Edwardian era who lost his beloved wife during childbirth and has never quite gotten over it. Arthur is on the verge of being fired by his law firm but is given one last chance to keep his job. The assignment should be simple enough - just travel to far-away and remote Eel Marsh and handle the estate of its recently deceased owner. However, as you might expect, not long after Arthur arrives at the home, he starts hearing things, inanimate objects inexplicably start coming to life inside the house, and he sees a creepy woman in black roaming around the grounds. Oh, and did I mention that the children in the nearby town also start dying all around him at an alarming rate and it may be at the hands of the ghostly woman in black?

It is very rare for modern mainstream horror movies to depict children dying or being murdered, and I applaud The Woman in Black for being so bold as to kill off young kids in some interesting and horrific ways. I cherish the 1980 classic The Children so much because it is one of the only horror movies I know of that goes balls to the wall and kills several little children in some of the goriest and most humorous ways imaginable. Don't worry, though, unlike the children in The Woman in Black, the kids in The Children were monstrous zombies and they had it coming. But I digress.

Hardcore horror movie fans such as myself will not find The Woman in Black scary at all, but young teenagers and fans of Daniel Radcliff's Harry Potter may be sufficiently creeped out and find themselves jumping at a few points during this movie when the obligatory and garden variety non-threatening things such as birds, dogs, or townsmen jump out at our main character and make noise at the most inopportune moments. The theater my husband and I saw this movie in was packed to the gills with young kids and teenagers and I had to endure countless screams and awkward laughs during the "scary" parts of this movie.

Hardcore horror movie fans will find a few things to enjoy in this movie, though. The film looks amazing and is beautifully shot, and the opening scene, involving a group of young girls who suddenly jump out of their attic window and plummet to their death, is haunting. The marsh, the woman in black, and the ghosts of her deceased victims also provide for a nice and eerie ambiance. It seems like more than a few movies released over the last year have employed a haunted house theme and the use of ghostly old women with evil intentions. Insidious did it flawlessly, while The Inn Keepers failed miserably. The Woman in Black, however, does a decent job in presenting a scary and ominous woman in black.

You'll also love the wealthy landowner named Sam Daily (played by Ciarn Hinds) and his eccentric and possessed wife (played by Janet McTeer) who befriend Arthur and inform him of the history of the town and the woman in black. There is one particular scene where Arthur has dinner with Mr. and Ms. Daily and learns of their son's tragic death that is both terrifying and hilarious at the same time, and I would have liked to have seen a lot more of this couple. I also would have liked it if the movie went on about 10 minutes longer than it did so we could have seen what became of the couple and their son who was taken from them too soon. I genuinely liked these people and would have liked for them to have found some closure or been reunited with the ghost of their long lost son. The movie would have been better if it had a little bit less of a confused Arthur walking up and down long hallways with a candle and a little bit more of the Daily family.

This movie definitely isn't even close to perfect, and there are a few holes in the plot (e.g., Arthur's sidekick dog initially barks loudly at a few unseen ghosts in the house, but then completely disappears when the shit really starts to hit the fan, only to miraculously reappear in Arthur's car when it is time to flee the scene). However, overall The Woman in Black is a beautifully shot and well-acted little haunted house movie.

It's not easy reviewing movies as we all have our individual tastes.  I love scary/creepy movies, especially those that don't have an excess of special effects. Movies like "Paranormal Activity" and "The Conjuring" get 1 and 2 stars from me.  My taste runs to "The Others" and "What Lies Beneath."  More psychological, less CG.  My husband doesn't usually care for this genre at all, but he really liked this movie.

After watching the movie again on cable, I started to appreciate the little scenes more and more and really was impressed by how well designed the sets were and the clothing. Of course Radcliffs performance was well done.  Too bad he's so small...he still looks like a kid.  No matter, I recommend this movie and I'm buying the BluRay.
Will be trotting this out on a regular basis for my Halloween viewing.  Danial Radcliffe is an excellent actor becoming better with each role he takes on.

Loved this movie and love Daniel Radcliffe's filmwork.  Wish he would do more movies.  I like the dark and dreary atmosphere of the town where he is sent and the spookiness of the house.  It is also more appealing as he is desperate to keep his job and provide for his son. Wish they had shown more of the woman in black herself and a little more detail into her son's life before he died.

The movie, "The Woman in Black", will undoubtedly become another of our horror classics. Although its story line is simplistic, it has just the right twists and turns, and, of course, unexpected shadows lurking in the right places.

Daniel Radcliffe is an extrodinarily good young actor. this movie was a very dark and at times creepy movie but it kept your interest. recommend it for anyone who like Radcliffe and enjoys a movie that keeps you interested.

I like that the film is extremely creative and it has its own unique twist to it! The only the thing that I would advise is that there are some aspects of this film that can be disturbing but over all its an AMAZING film you MUST watch it!! :D
Not a very well written story to me, it lacked depth, except for Daniel Radcliffe. Not one of my favorites. Otherwise it was well filmed and I had no problems with audio or video.
I got this at a great price, and it came very quickly and in great quality. It works perfectly and looks as good as new, even though it was used. Love it!
I have enjoyed Daniel Radcliffe in everything that he has done.  This was scary without being grotesque with unnecessary blood and gore.
There are only two movies that ever really scared me and this is one of them. I screamed in the theater and was too scared to watch most of it at home.

I suggest choosing between the book and the movie because the movie takes enormous liberties that are hard to ignore. Some change is inevitable in an adaptation, but the changes here stray too far from the original. Also, the changes don't add anything of value to the story, rather they detract. The end result is melodramatic and clichd. It relies on dreariness, hostility, sadness, and various shades of grief (some mildly insane) to create an ambiance, but it misses the mark. Some of the clichs, like the derelict abandoned house, simply don't make sense (Mrs Drablow was living there until very recently; the house might be terribly shabby but it would still be livable). Even if I hadn't read the book I wouldn't rate this film higher. There's worse out there, but this film is neither atmospheric nor scary. It tries too hard when the original story was already very good.
I love scary movies and most of them aren't very good anymore. This one had a lot of great parts to make you jump and I liked the ending a lot.

If your cinematic taste involves those old fashioned spook-shows of yesteryear (like "The Innocents" or "The Spiral Staircase"), this might be just the ticket. "The Woman in Black" practically oozes creepy, gothic, sinister ambience with its macabre mansion and fogbound countryside and cemetery.

The story was decent, and the ending was surprisingly poignant (I was expecting much more of a frightful climax rather than what actually transpired). Had the plot been more solid I would have given higher marks here ... the three stars are strictly for the ghastly trappings, which I enjoy; for more of that stuff, see "The Haunting" (1963), "The Changeling", and "The Others".

The Arthur Kipps with whom I was hitherto more familiar is the English character by H.G. Wells, who later inspired the musical, "Half a Sixpence".
 This one, played by a haunted yet stoic Daniel Radcliffe with relatively few lines and whose large, photogenic blue eyes are as wide as they were in the first "Harry Potter" film, is the creation of novelist Susan Hill, and also English.
  Performing in this 95-minute horror flick, which in some ways is not too much of a stretch for him, the former child star, rocking a pair of sideburns along with his short but athletic build, plays an Edwardian era  widower with a small son(Radcliffe's  sweet little real-life godson, Mischa Handley), and sometimes seems eager, at times overly eager, to proclaim his maturity to the world. The short, pert chin of that still adorably pinchable boyish face, which once buttressed baby-fat-filled cheeks as it lifted in awe to inspect a golden snitch is now stubble ridden as it inspects grimmer haunted surroundings. Certain camera shots seem to echo and overly emphasize the message, "I'm an adult now, and I have the body hair to prove it!"
  The tale begins with the inexplicable demise of the three Fisher Sisters(Emma Shorey, Molly Harmon,and Ellisa Walker-Reid), who suddenly, under mysterious possession, leave off from playing Tea Party with their dolls and jump to their deaths from the attic windows of their parents' inn amid the audible screams of their mother.
  Meanwhile in London, Kipps, a struggling  young attorney is sent to the costal area by train to settle a deceased client's estate, called Eel Marsh House where a vengeful veiled spirit haunts him  as it does the villagers, whose children also become possessed and engage in suicidal acts despite Kipps' frequent and futile attempts to save them. It is of some significance that his four-year-old has  drawn for him, a little calendar, marking the days leading to their scheduled Friday reunion.
  His most relevant acquaintance at this time is the prominent citizen, Sam Daily(Ciaran Hinds, who appeared with Radcliffe in the last two "Harry Potter" films), and his disturbed wife, Elizabeth(Janet McTeer)who still grieves the loss of their son, Nicholas(Sidney Johnston), who would have been the same age as Kipps had he lived.
  As the story continues, the young lawyer experiences a mounting level of social  castigation from the locals and is also haunted by a beautiful and benevolent woman in white, namely the spirit of his late wife(Sophie Stuckey) who died in childbirth.
  Scenes of him sifting through the correspondence that help him investigate the case with the malevolent spirit lurking about reminded me of  part of the following poem, "Antigonish" by William Hughes Mearns:"Yesterday, upon the stair, I saw a man who wasn't there. He wasn't there again today. I wish, I wish he'd go away."
  The apparition of this woman( Liz White) who won't go away is later joined by the phantoms of her many young victims. But after gaining in-depth knowledge of the situation, Arthur, with Mr. Daily's help, literally gets down and dirty to bring resolution to the previously unsolved matter. But the spirit remains unforgiving, and she will restore everything Arthur holds dear to him in her own cruel way, creating a very poignant ending.
  I can't say I found this horror flick to be too scary at all, really. But Radcliffe's personal charm carries the story, and Director James Watkins provides another showcase for its young star's fabulous talent.
Was so un scary and just one mess of a film. I cant believe D Radcliffe was in this movie! Was he depressed after Harry Potter ended? IDK

As modern scary movies go, this one is particularly creepy and chilling. There isn't an over abundance of special effects, so the imagery is actually scary. The story has a great pace and works up to being more and more scary, instead of diving into something grotesque like so many movies do now. The only draw back I see with this movie is that the story is not so engrossing that I'd want to watch it again. The interest rests more on suspense than any actual character development. It manages to be well acted while delivering a very superficial level of depth to any character, preventing any real emotional investment in what happens to them. I'd buy it again though, and since I don't plan on watching it again, I passed it along to a fellow scary movie fan who I know will get a kick out of it.

Hammer productions has eschewed modern concepts of the horror film and stuck with the traditional model for the Ghost Story. Not a horror story in the modern mode, but ghosts in a haunted house. In this case, there are grieving adult ghosts and lost children ghosts, all making themselves known to the hapless law clerk who has been warned that if he failed to settle the estate of which the haunted house is a major component, he will lose his job. Of course, he receives a cold reception from the townspeople, while his position is even more compromised by the fact that he, a widower, his wife having lost her life in childbirth, is expecting his own child to join him. What a dilemma.
While not a superior film of its type, it is well done and has its share of ghostly effects. It should constitute a good evenings watching for those who are fans.

It was nice to see Daniel Radcliffe, honestly a fine actor, land this dark role, and in a few instances the brooding interiors and misty landscapes did make for appealing eye candy, but it's an unfortunate commentary on The Woman in Black to point out that those were the best parts of the film. Toned down a few degrees this might have worked well enough in the classical sense as an English country house ghost story, but as heavy-handed as the movie wound up being, it suffocated under the weight of its own lurid efforts to frighten. I will not swing all the way into the camp of those who call this a bad film, because it isn't, it's merely a mediocre one that fell victim to its own ambition to be great. If you're curious about The Woman in Black, rent it, don't buy it, because I can't imagine you'll find much in it that compels repeat viewing.

Let me put it this way...

Creepiness: 3 out of 5.
Setting: 4 out of 5.
Plot: 1 out of 5.
Surprise twists: Zero.
Flinching moments: 2 out of 5.
Performances: 3 out of 5.
Overall effort and ambition: 4 out of 5.

Better luck next time, Daniel. Hang in there!

The Woman In Black is a disappointing horror/mystery film mainly for reasons that surround the confusing storyline.

Daniel Radcliffe of Harry Potter fame stars as a man who visits a castle out in the countryside for a few days.  The first thing that surprises me is how much older he's gotten.  Yes he's definitely reached the age appropriate to be a father now, rather shockingly.  Seems just like yesterday Sorcerer's Stone came out and I was enjoying it after high school graduation.

Anyway the biggest problem is that, well a combination of two things- weak, overblown writing that makes the entire movie seem artificial and too Hollywood, and despite a solid 15 minutes of actual hauntings *finally* taking place 50 minutes into the movie, overall the Woman in Black just isn't scary or interesting enough.

Perhaps Daniel himself starring in a movie like this is the Woman In Black's biggest downfall.  Most of us are familiar with the Harry Potter films and know what kind of magical creativity was used to make those films so rewarding and provide an unbelievable amount of eye candy using all the special effects you can imagine, but here... well, it's almost like it *tries* to recapture the same concept using horror elements but never succeeding in the same way so the movie ends up looking more like a weak imitation.  Also, a storyline that never really gets off the ground until it's too late pretty much holds down all the potential this movie could have had.

Had to laugh when Harry walked into a room frightened and jumps when mud comes squirting out of a nearby bathtub.  Come on Harry, you just seen horrific otherworldly monsters- a little bit of mud during uneasy atmospheric conditions shouldn't hold YOU of all people back from proceeding!

Oh, about those 15 minutes I mention above that is actually *good*.  This is when Harry, er, Daniel Radcliffe sees a rocking chair rocking by itself, apparitions walking down the hallways, apparitions roaming outside the castle, figures appearing in reflections and mirrors, shadows darting across the room, children lighting themselves on fire, toys making noises by themselves, etc.  This is REALLY excellent stuff however it all goes away due to the movie trying to tell a story involving the death of three children that jump out the window under mysterious circumstances.  I spent more time confused than I did satisfied.

The Woman in Black is clearly more appropriate for Harry Potter fans instead of horror lovers.  With that said, it's not bad by any means.  Basically the first half is disappointing and the second half improves in the atmosphere and horror categories, but fails in the storyline for the most part.  I like the ending involving a fast moving train, though.  I know what you're thinking- no, Daniel does *not* fly a car into the world of wizardry with Ron Weasley. :)
I love this movie because it succeeds in being very scary without guns and blood; just a creepy old house, ghostly figures and dark moody weather.
I found it to be a lot of nonsense, done mostly in the dark. I would not bother to watch it a second time or suggest it to any of my friends. To my enemies, maybe.
