This film is up with the likes of "The Uninvited" (1941) and "The Innocents" (1963), as far as being a classic, slow-hand-on-the-shoulder ghost story.  None of the blam!-out-of-the-blue crap like you see in Hollywood films, this is beautiful, dark, foreboding, and in the theater I giggled with delight as the audience reacted to it, even applauding at the end.

Is there another movie genre as maligned as horor? I don't think so. From gratuitous gore fests, silly slasher cesspools and remakes that rarely live up to the originals, Hollywood and even indie film directors have had their way with horror and they all too frequently don't deliver. Some directors even try REALLY hard, and offer up plot twists to make up for other shortcomings, and while I do enjoy a surprising plot element I didn't see coming, having seen so many horror films, I usually am not surprised as the filmmakers intended.

Enter The Woman In Black. Right from the first moment, you know that this isn't going to be your run of the mill, disappointing, predictable scare vehicle. In fact, if you DO go into this one trying to find some evidence that you're about to discover some crazy secret as a plot twist, you will be disappointed. Radcliffe's character isn't one of the boys the woman did away with, back for some purpose or any other devious possible surprise. No, the filmmakers decided that a simple, straight up story about a ghost imposing vengeance to the rest of the town's children after losing her boy was just the right amount of motivation they needed to inspire enough scares from the creepy old gothic house and surrounding area.

There are similarities to other ghost type stories such as the point when in order to hopefully put the woman to rest, he goes into a swamp/marsh to retrieve her boy's body to put with the woman in her coffin, highly reminiscent of 'The Ring' well sequence, but ultimately, similarities don't matter. There are enough genuine bone chilling moments to fluff the hair on the back of your neck for two movies, and the acting from all actors is far above the norm usually seen for horror films. As for Radcliffe and whether he's got the acting chops to move past Harry Potter and into more adult roles, rest assured he can. He himself is left to carry much of the weight of the movie on his shoulders for long periods of time alone, save for the woman and some of the ghosts of her victims keeping him company, and he does it brilliantly and believably.

I also particularly like that the filmmakers were not afraid to rebel against tying everything up into a neat little package where everyone is ok at the end, and they also left it without a real 'hey there's gonna be a sequel' moment as well. Oh sure, they could do another one, but the way the film ends, it can more than stand alone on its' own merit, and I for one hope it does. This film was so good, I wouldn't want to see a hacked up rehashed sequel with extra explanations etc, etc. Sometimes, as in this case, the one film is enough.

So, If you're sick and tired of the same horror song being played again for the umpteenth time and want a throwback to great old ghost stories, The Woman In Black is for you.

I picked up this DVD on a whim and watched it late at night...which turned out to be a mistake.  Normally, scary movies don't bother me, but this one actually spooked me a bit.  It can be slow at times, but I think the slow pace actually lets the creepiness of the scenes get inside you.

A lawyer is sent off to a run-down house on the edge of a marsh in order to go through the papers left there, leaving his young son at home.  This is his last shot at working out at the firm, due to his clear depression over the death of his wife in childbirth years ago.  Once he gets there, the townsfolk try desperately to send him right back to London and warn him not to go out to Eel Marsh House.  But, of course, he does...

The Woman in Black turns out to be a ghost with murderous tendencies and Daniel Radcliffe's character tries desperately to deal with fulfilling his charge as well as figuring out why she is haunting the place, and attacking the children of the village.  It was hard at first to see past "Harry Potter," but as the movie continued, the acting won me over.

The house itself, filled with Victorian oddities and old paintings, and the lonely marsh its set in provide a spooky landscape for the story.  When the tides roll in, the place is cut off entirely from the mainland and this makes the setting even more frightening.  Its very Gothic, but with enough touches of modern horror to engage a modern audience.

I'll definitely be watching it again, but not late at night, this time.

"The Woman in Black" is a short (138 page) British novel written in 1982. Hammer Horror returns in full force in the 2012 film adaptation of THE WOMAN IN BLACK, starring Daniel Radcliffe. A lowly young lawyer is sent to prepare the sale of a grand old estate, the Eel Marsh House, but unbeknownst to him, the house carries with it an ominous curse that has been plaguing the children of the small town for years. After settling in, Arthur begins experiencing horrific visions as the ghosts of the past return to haunt him! THE WOMAN IN BLACK is an excellent revival of the Gothic tradition that echoes the works of Jack Clayton and Alejandro Amenbar in their retellings of the classic novella, The Turn of the Screw. A constant sense of dread befalls the viewer as we are drowned in mists and shadows. Director James Watkins takes a timely approach to storytelling of his own which pays off entirely, and allows for many long, drawn out sequences to incrementally heighten the tension and suspense as we await the final shock in the end. THE WOMAN IN BLACK also focuses heavily on eerie effects which can be achieved in frame rather than destroying the fantasy through computerized scares. Daniel Radcliffe is amply equipped for the role as the grieving lawyer Arthur Kipps, and plays perfectly in to the Edwardian setting. One can only hope that this will continue to spark more ghostly haunts in the terrifying tradition of the Hammer House of Horror.

-Carl Manes

This is finely told horror story, set in last century's rural English countryside.  Daniel Redcliff plays a young attorney Arthur, a widower for several years after his wife dies giving birth to their first child Joseph.  His love for his wife was so strong that even time does not seem to be able to erase his memory of her.  It is as if the more time passes by, the more he misses her.  It is the young boy that keeps him going.

Arthur's employer is loosing patience with Arthur's melancholy mood that shows so well on screen with Redcliffe's dark hair and his pale, pale skin.  It is as if young attorney's sorrow is bad for business and only if young Arthur can close sale on the house of the recently deceased client, he can resurrect his career.  So the story begins.  Arthur finds himself in a remote village where everyone seems less than thrilled to see him.  With his arrival to the village, children die mysteriously in the most gruesome deaths unbecoming of their innocent lives.  Arthur is deeply affected with the experiences since he has a child himself.  So the story turns the ghost story of horror of sort.  A deceased mother separted from her child who also died (but without a proper burial) is reliesing her vengeance.  But what striked me in this film is the way she expressed her gratitude to Arthur once Arthur reunites her with her dead son.  The end of the movie made me cry.  I was both happy and sad and I just broke down.

For years I've been trying to get my hands on a copy of the 1989 made-for-TV version of The Woman in Black, which is both very expensive and very difficult to find on DVD, so when I heard that they were making another film version, I was initially excited to finally have the opportunity to see a version of The Woman in Black on film.  I was, however, also concerned that there would be changes to the plot and deviations from the original novel that would serve to "Hollywoodify" the story.  After watching this new version with Daniel Radcliffe, I can say that my fears were confirmed.  There were numerous changes to the story that took it in some wildly different directions than what the author Susan Hill probably intended, and these changes did not improve the story.  One of the best things about the novel is its restraint.  It is heavy on atmosphere and psychological tension and light on the stuff of typical horror stories, i.e. dead bodies, blood and guts, psycho behavior, possessed people, etc.  While this film does retain the spooky and ominous atmosphere present in the novel, there were so many changes to story that I often thought I was seeing a completely different story.

The novel begins with Arthur Kipps as an older, remarried man recounting the story of his dealings with the Woman in Black and how they led to the deaths of his first wife and young son when he was a young man working at a law firm.  His first encounter with the Woman in Black occurs at Alice Drablow's funeral.  He is sent there as a representative of the law firm and initially thinks the Woman in Black is a mourner.  I was really hoping to see this scene dramatized, but the film completely changes the sequence of events in the novel and adds a bunch of stuff that didn't need to be there.  The two biggest changes that I absolutely could not get past were the scenes where Arthur Kipps and Samuel Daily (Ciarn Hinds) manage to pull the sunken carriage containing the body of Jennet Humfrye's (The Woman in Black's) son out of the marshes (like they would really be able to do this), then take the child's corpse back to Eel Marsh house in an attempt to reunite Jennet Humfrye and her son (this never happens in the book and is completely unbelievable), and of course the corny ending where Arthur Kipps and his son are killed by an oncoming train after the son is lured onto the tracks by the Woman in Black, then they are both reunited with Arthur Kipps' dead wife at the very end in the afterlife as they walk away together into the mists.  This was the Hollywood shocker ending that I was afraid this film would receive.  In the novel, Arthur Kipps' wife and son are killed by the Woman in Black, but Arthur remains alive (because somebody has to tell the story!), and their deaths do not involve a train.  The ending of the novel is shocking, but there is no reuniting with anybody in the afterlife.  My mother and I both watched this film together and when it was over, my mother said to me, "It could have been so much more than it was."  And I agreed.
This movie was much better than we expected, but was a bit chilling for pre-Christmas viewing.  Daniel Radcliffe has definitely grown-up.

This is a fine and extremely suspenseful film adaptation of Susan Hill's stellar gothic novel of the same name. The setting of Hill's story fairly oozes with atmosphere, and the film captures the creepy yet romantic vibe really well. Radcliffe is near perfect in the lead role as a grieving widower and young father.  On a side note, I was disappointed with the way the screenplay departs from the novel in places, especially at the end, but this is still a film I will revisit as it is high caliber movie-making and I adore the setting and drama the film presents.  I also highly recommend reading Hill's original novel--one of the top gothic literary works in my book...

Enjoyed this slowly paced, well acted and beautifully filmed gem. Like The Others and The Orphanage of these modern day films , The Woman in Black serves up a well crafted take on the haunted house with Daniel Radcliffe lifting this movie up to a Hammer film worthy of its past works.  Its not great by any means but its well worth checking out, the eerie settings, the dilapidated house and the exceptional cinematograpy are especially well done and add in some chilling scenes with the dead children and the lady in black and a twised ending leaves you uneasy. There are a few stand out performances from a local sympathetic couple and  local towns people who want only to get rid of the intruder in their mist. It wasn't how many chills and scares they could deliver but how well they could tell this spooky odd story and let it get under your skin, these kinds of movies needs to slowly take shape,a genuinely scarey story,  well done Hammer.

The Woman In Black (2012). Rated "PG-13". Running Time: 1 hours, 35 mins. Directed by James Watkins. Written by Jane Goldman. Remake of Woman in Black [VHS] (1989). Three girls (Emma Storey, Molly Harmon, Ellisa Walker-Reid) are playing dolls and tea during the daytime in the attic. Suddenly, they all look at the windows and at the same time, in a trance, they walk to the windows and open them and fall to their death. A woman dressed in black funeral clothes is seen in the room. Arthur Kipps (Daniel Radcliffe) works for a law firm. He must leave his son, Joseph (Misha Handley) and the nanny (Jessica Raine) for a few days to go to the countryside. Mrs. Alice Drablow of Eel Marsh House died last month. He must go to the estate in the marshlands to go through much paperwork to find her final will. Every page must be examined. A Mr. Jerome (Tim McMullan) is not cooperating. Arthur's boss, Mr. Bentley (Roger Allam) tells him he must prove his dedication to the future of this law firm. It is his final warning. Arthur's bills at home are overdue. Aboard the train, Arthur meets Samuel Daily (Ciaran Hinds) who offers to drive him to the Gifford Arms Inn. It is raining hard. At the inn, Mr. Fisher, the innkeeper (Shaun Dooley), doesn't care for Arthur having a reservation and tells him he has no room for him. However, with the agreement of his wife, Mrs. Fisher (Mary Stuckley), he can stay in the attic. Yes! That very attic. The next day, he arrives at the old Drablow estate. Inside it is very dusty and with huge cobwebs. While going through the papers during the daytime, he hears the floorboards, maybe footprints and other sounds. He goes upstairs to see what it is (I'm not telling). Outside the fog is coming in heavily. In the woods, he sees a woman in black. Also in the cast: Cathy Sara, Daniel Cerqueira, Alfie Field, Janet McTeer, Victor McGuire, Roger Allam. Liz White played "The Woman in Black". Misha Handley ("Joseph") is Daniel Radcliffe's real-life godson. Filmed at Cotterstock Hall, Oundle, Northamptonshire, England. Osea island, Essex, North Yorkshire, England, United Kingdom. Pinewood Studios. This movie, starring Daniel Radcliffe, held my attention and while I am getting used to the use of CGI effects, the scary elements do not work so well for me on television and probably worked better for the big screen. I did want to see this movie originally at the movie theater, but was unable too. This was the first movie Daniel Radcliffe filmed after the "Harry Potter" film series concluded with Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows, Part 2 (Blu-ray/DVD + UltraViolet Digital Copy) (2011). If Daniel Radcliffe had not been cast in the lead of The Woman in Black (2012) I probably would not have seen it. It is a good role and motion picture for him. A familiar name is tied to this film...HAMMER, who have been a production company of many thrillers in the past. They are also developing a remake of Gaslight (1944). Option of subtitles in English, Spanish. English Commentary Subtitles. Audio Commentary with Director James Watkins and Screenwriter Jane Goodman. Special Features: Inside the Perfect Thriller: Making The Woman in Black. No Fear: Daniel Radcliffe as Arthur Kipps. Sequel: Woman in Black 2: Angel of Death [Blu-ray] (2015).

Set in the Edwardian-era England, "The Woman in Black" is an old-fashioned horror movie that reminds us of Victorian ghost stories. This is not surprising, as the film (based on a Susan Hill novel) is produced by the newly revived Hammer studio, once known for its "Dracula" franchise starring Christopher Lee and Peter Cushing.

Daniel Radcliffe is Arthur Kipps, a young lawyer on the verge of losing his position in the firm. As a final chance to keep his job, he is sent to a small British town, where he has to find a certain document at the Eel Marsh House on an estate that is cut off from the outside world. The people there obviously do not want him in their town, however. The local lawyer is not cooperative. Soon Arthur is to learn the reason - some terrifying things about "The Woman in Black."

The 2012 film version of "The Woman in Black" (the original book was made into a TV movie starring Adrian Rawlins as Arthur Kipps in 1989) benefits from the atmospheric photography and the production designs of the desolate Eel Marsh House that alone is worth watching. Daniel Radcliffe turns in effective performance a widowed father, still mourning his wife's death, though he looks a little too young for the role of a father, if not a lawyer.

What the film doesn't have is any new ideas to scare us. As to the film's scares, the best part is probably the "Ju-On"-inspired opening, which is creepy enough, but the film itself nds to depend on the hackneyed techniques like sudden big sound. Some of them are so predictable that you can see them coming from miles away.

Perhaps we have seen so many similar-themed thrillers since the original book was published, "The Orphanage" for example, films with more inventive and creative ways to surprise and scare us. Had it been made much earlier (by ten years or more), "The Woman in Black" would have been a more scary movie.
Interesting premise, but i just couldn't get into it. I don't know why but i just couldnt. They are making either a sequal or a follow up.
Great old-fashioned ghost story with tons of atmosphere and great performances that will make the hair on the back of your head stand up.  Enjoy!

Woman in Black is a pretty 'traditional' kind of horror flick that combines all the elements of horror (startling sounds, dark creepy houses, lonely location, etc.). What I liked the most is the photography and overall texture of the movie. Its BEAUTIFUL! the climate, the details in the interiors have been captured so well, it will please your eyes. The element of horror is not very different other movies, so this one will have average score when it comes to scaring you. However, the story is believable, nicely flowing and is worth the watch on a rainy day/night (may be that will scare you bit more). Most important part is, there is no gore, no bloodshed and no unnecessary screaming. Considering all these factors, this horror goes more in the line with "the ring", "insidious"  and such movies (though the plot is entirely different).
Overall scoring:
Plot, story: Pretty traditional, but nice.
Photograpy, location: BRILLIANT!
Element of horror: Average (or slightly above it)
If you are a horror fan, should this be in your collection? YES
Blu ray Audio/Video Quality: Excellent!

British authors have always loved ghost stories. They are inexpressively connected to England. In the early 1980's, another ghost story was added to the pile, and now comes to life.

Ghost stories are not my thing. They give me the creeps, and not in a way I'd like to repeat. So my feelings about this one are mixed. From a purely writing and artistic perspective, this movie is magnificent. It builds suspense quietly and then unleashes visual horrors on a nervous audience. The cast is terrific... Radcliffe proves that he can tackle far more adult, period pieces than his famous wizard counterpart. Janet McTeer turns up as the tormented wife of Mr. Daily, suffering from visitations from her dead son. The costuming, musical score, and setting are marvelous... it blends into a chilling state of events that range from doors that open and close by themselves to  the shocking conclusion that is both beautiful and tragic. I'm also happy to say that the movie can stand on its own two feet -- it doesn't need its famous lead to succeed, although it is a joy to have him there. It's the perfect ghostly horror film.

This is a great movie with just the right tone for Halloween.  It's not not bloody or gruesome, just spooky and chilling with some unexpected twists.  Daniel Radcliff turns in a really good performance in one of of his earliest post "Harry Potter" roles.
 Well worth a look and  for my money, (no pun intended), a purchase.

The Woman in Black is also truly amazing for the fact that all special effects are on-camera!

Daniel Radcliffe puts all thought of Harry Potter behind him with his performance in, 'The Woman in Black.'  His performance was highly impressive and the movie was too. `The Woman in Black' is pretty much a classic ghost story; lawyer Arthur Kipps (Daniel Radcliffe) is tasked with travelling to a small, tight-knit community to handle the estate of a wealthy woman who is now deceased. But while it's obvious his presence isn't welcomed, Kipps makes for the woman's isolated house and finds he has to deal with something a lot more sinister than paperwork, and in order to stop anymore innocent lives from being taken - and, perhaps, to save his remaining clean underwear - he needs to face a dark secret that the town is hiding.

It maybe a familiar set-up, but `The Woman in Black' is still a well-shot, spooky ride. Director James Watkins pulls out old tricks to scare us, but it works brilliantly as he keeps the whole film in a slow, tense, unnerving atmosphere. The story is shrouded in mystery, as they always should be in these films, and Watkins strings us along by handing out little clues throughout and the scares come more from the build-up, which keeps you on edge, and it really helps on the delivery. Daniel Radcliffe also proves he can shrug off the-boy-who-lived and, although a little young for the role, puts in a generally solid and emotional performance as Arthur Kipps. If you let it take you along for the ride, `The Woman in Black' is worth the watch, every ninety-five creepy minutes of it.

This movie is good and has a very dark vibe to it.  A man who can't get over his wife's death and whether or not if there is a heaven and she's there, you can't but feel sorry for him.  You can feel and see his tourment and his loneliness.  As you can see the acting in this movie is really good and it pulls you in.  Even though the movie is good it isn't super scary.  It does enough to keep you on the edge of your seat anticipating what is going to happen next.  I really enjoyed this movie and believe that if you like movies with a dark, creepy, and gothic vibe to them you will like this movie also.  Plus this movie does not use gore to try and scare you, its more sounds and shadows and brief encounters with the ghost.  I give this movie a solid B.

I admit it.  I only saw this movie due to curiosity about how Daniel Radcliffe would look as someone other than Harry Potter.  He does well, but it almost seems familiar settings to have him in old buildings lit by candles.

It's hard to say why this movie just does not entertain ........ it is visually rich - great sets, locations, wardrobe, etc ........ the actors all do well with their lines and all the characters are believable.  BUT the movie just NEVER draws the viewer into it.  All the "scary parts" rely on standard formulas - something moving in the background (that the hero never sees until it's too late) or something popping up suddenly (BOO!).

It is just totally flat - one note - no depth at all.  Maybe the book was more engaging - I hope so.  The ending is disappointing and predictable.

So, if you HAVE to see this movie - rent it.  This is NOT worth buying.

I'm a veteran horror movie buff, and my favorites are always the stories that are genuinely creepy, as opposed to gory and violent.  Creepy and atmospheric is what you get in this film.  I don't remember seeing any fake blood at all, even during the death scenes.  Also, I did jump, and I even squealed a couple of times, hanging on to my husband's arm for dear life.  Remember, I'm a horror movie buff.  Even movies that make me jump NEVER make me scream, but I found the images truly frightening.  If you're a person who needs violence and gore in your movies like, say, Hostel or Saw, you may not like this one.  But if you're a fan of vintage horror novels like Dracula, Wuthering Heights, The Woman In White, etc., this one might be up your alley.

The Woman in Black is a good old fashioned ghost story.  The story is solid and the atmosphere is ethereal.  Spooky but not gory.  Some unsettling scenes involving suicidal children but tame enough for teenagers.  I enjoyed it.

Arthur Kipps is a lawyer in London whose wife has died in childbirth.  He has a four year old son and a nanny for him. However, he is in danger of losing his job at his law firm because apparently he has done nothing but mope around for the last four years. He is given one last chance to redeem himself, to go to a remote village and Eel Marsh House, where the owner has died, and sort out her many papers.

He meets a man, Samuel Daily, on the train on the way there, and despite Arthur's very rarely opening his mouth to speak (ever), Samuel becomes his one ally in the town.  Arthur goes to Eel Marsh house to look for, and at the papers of this woman, and get them in order and locate her will.  How he is expected to do this, I do not understand, because even in the daylight, with candles, that place is dark as a cave.

The important papers (birth and death certificates, adoption papers) are placed conveniently on top so that Arthur finds out what he needs to know right away - about the ghost, The Woman In Black (what wearing black has to do with anything they don't say). Every time he goes to the house, there is always a lot of unexplained sights and sounds, which never faze Arthur in the least. He's still just so stunned from losing his wife four years ago.

The ghost, Jennet, really does seem to be taking her anger out on the wrong people. After so many deaths, you'd think they'd move away or hire an exorcist or something. As is usual in these movies, what the living person thinks/hopes/believes/is sure will appease the out of control ghost does not work. I didn't really care about any of these silly characters, and watching Arthur go from being covered in mud/dirt/or soaking wet to being dry and spotless wearing the same clothes, was irritating.

Something that perturbed me: on the adoption papers those involved are referred to as Mr., Mrs., and Ms. (the unmarried ghost). But from all the period British novels I've read, there was no use of "Ms." back then and periods after honorifics such as Mr, Mrs or Dr were not used, and still are not. Jennet should have been referred to as "Miss" on the adoption paper.

Janet McTeer was wasted, but I guess it's a paycheck.
If you like scary movies, this one has some great effects, nice moody, creepy atmosphere, satisfying resolution, little gore. Watch it tonight!
I love this type of movie! A classic haunted house type of movie. Creepy enough to keep you a bit on edge, nice dark filming. Perfect for the month of October. Not just full of gore. Fun!

I really, really wanted to like this movie because it had Daniel Radcliffe in it. I like gothic horror stories and had high hopes. Alas, throughout the picture I predicted what was going to happen next with complete accuracy--it was that predictable. The ending stunk. The Harry Potter franchise has left such lasting impact that, throughout the viewing of THE WOMAN IN BLACK, I half-expected Ron Weasley and Hermione Granger to apparate and lend a hand to their beleaguered old mate. A Hammer Films joint, THE WOMAN IN BLACK makes for elegant British gothic horror. It tells a dark tale of numbing loss and unholy vengeance. It's Daniel Radcliffe's first venture into cinema, post-Potter. And yet he's still dabbling in the supernatural.

Susan Hill's eerie 1983 bestseller had already been adapted as a television mini-series in the 1980s and as a stage play, but the rejuvenated Hammer Film Productions thumbed it up for a go on the silver screen anyway. Daniel Radcliffe, all of 21 years old during the filming, plays widower Arthur Kipps who after four years still grieves for his wife's passing. His inertness has adversely affected his career at a London law firm to the extent that he's a hair's breadth away from getting sacked.

Arthur Kipps gets one last chance to make good. He's dispatched to northeast England, to a remote village in which outskirts looms the creaky Eel Marsh House. In this ruined mansion, ringed by treacherous marshland and accessible only by a causeway, Arthur is to sort out a deceased woman's estate. But since this isn't an episode of SUITS, the spooky very soon emerges.

A curse holds the nearby village in thrall, or not a curse but rather a vindictive spirit. Arthur's arrival is met with instant suspicion from the inhospitable townspeople, most of whom fear what Arthur's meddling may further stir up. Faced with brusqueness at every turn, Arthur Kipps presses on. And while he's so emotionally closed off that he rarely exhibits a reaction to the alarming stuff going on around him, the film does a very good job of jangling our nerves. The scares are of the make-you-jump variety, cheap but very effective and more restrained than garish. THE WOMAN IN BLACK does well in establishing its ghost story ground rules. We find out that the menacing figure that fleetingly graces your peripheral vision - a veiled woman clad in black mourning garb - is targeting children, is forcing them to engage in gruesome self-extermination. So, right there, a measure of tension is lifted. We know Radcliffe's character is moderately safe. And there isn't a child prominently featured in the film for whom we have a rooting investment. Arthur's young boy Joseph (played by 4-year-old Misha Handley, Radcliffe's godson in real life) is barely in it.

Set in the Edwardian era (thus placing this story somewhen between 1901 - 1910), the film's biggest ace is the marvelously ominous set design of the Eel Marsh House. It's one of the spookiest haunted houses seen onscreen in recent years. As ever, in the auspices of a ghost story, children's toys very much become these creepy artifacts. I thought Radcliffe does okay. He plays a repressed widower and you may wonder why he doesn't panic more or just plain clear out when that empty rocking chair starts rocking or disembodied footsteps are heard or that distant window pane reveals a spectral woman gazing out. I think Arthur Kipps sees these unsettling events in another way, sees them as evidence of an afterlife in which he can reunite with his dead wife. One gets the sense that he deliberately seeks out the unrestful spirit. It's up to you whether this undertone exists and if it's communicated by Radcliffe's rather reserved performance. Also, with high tide closing off the causeway, where was he gonna go?

THE WOMAN IN BLACK is rich in atmosphere and broodingly gothic. It's a restrained but effective chiller. Certain moments made me clutch the armrest. Perhaps one knock is that while it does maintain a thread of steady suspense, I think it fails in delivering that big payoff. It falls short of that epic grand guignol. It's touted as the most successful British horror picture in two decades, and so were you at all startled when Hammer Films announced a sequel, the story set to take place during World War II?

The DVD's bonus stuff:

- Audio commentary with director James Watkins and screenwriter Jane Goldman
- "Inside the Perfect Thriller: Making THE WOMAN IN BLACK" (00:09:32 minutes)
- "No Fear: Daniel Radcliffe as Arthur Kipps" (00:04:05 minutes)

I had read mixed reviews and not a Radcliffe fan and the novel was a classic so I passed on this for quite some time. Never too late. I've watched it several times and it's well done in every respect. Radcliffe is excellent and the balance of the cast are equal to his lead. Liz White, oddly enough, "The Woman in Black" who was so perfect in Life On Mars: The Complete Collection (U.K.) is only seen clearly once and her voice is her biggest contribution but her, "Presence" is overwhelming. Several, "Jump" moments and a lot of carefully constructed suspense, a spot on eerie backdrop and nicely done SFX and it's an easy 5 star film, in my opinion. A lot of folks disliked the departures from the novel but I had no problem at all. Loved it.
I was ready for a good case of suspense and even scary night. It was slow going and a bit predictable.

A was blindsided with brilliance as I watched The Woman In Black. The cover art and title lent itself to a run of the mill ghost story that may be tolerable. And guess what? It is a fairly typical ghost story, but the film is presented with such rich grounding atmosphere and tight acting that the old fashioned haunted house story is revived without loss.

The blu- ray disc is solid and takes the viewer into the perfectly replicated misty past of the Old English countryside. I had no problem getting past any Harry Potter shortcomings that viewers may have unfairly dwelled on. This man can act, and he pulled out all the necessary emotions especially holding to an often sullen demeanor.

The film digs deep into haunted house history with creaky doors, spooky structures and amplifies it with modern film-making to create the epitome of the traditional haunted house. The ghostly figure of a female evil spirit lurks and she delivers real spine tinglers. Quietness becomes the enemy as the house has a creep fest around every corner.

Great evoking of British mannerisms and phraseology abound. The film stresses aura inducing scenery while you wait for the outcome to unfold. It looks like good old Hammer films are making a comeback as the films opening provides the said logo. It's great to see a ghost story, that really is a ghost story. Thoroughly enjoyable from beginning to end.
Kind of slow moving.  The story was very dragged out, to create effect, but it just made it boring.  Not impressed.

If you like the old fashion jump out and scare the bejeeesus ought of ya kinda movie, this is it! You think your one step ahead and then bam you get gobsmacked and nearly come flying out of your chair. I can't remember the last time a movie has scared me like this one. The end was brilliant and poignant and I highly recommend this movie to those who have tired of slashers, chainsaws and special effects.

This is an awesome movie. daniel radcliff is awesome in this movie. we all know him as harry potter but you just have to get past that in this movie. he did such a good job in this movie. he is going to be a good upcomming actor. this movie was not really scary it was creepy though. i liked the time they set it in. thats when this kind of movies are the best. the scene that got me was the crow flying in the window. that was the only part that made me jump. the creepy part was when dan sees that rocking chair go back and forth back and forth with no one in it. i would of been out of that place and never go back. this was a really good movie. if you have not seen this movie then i recommend you do

I really wanted to love this movie! I saw Daniel R. on the Graham Norton show promoting this movie, and Daniel seems Soo like-able. I was really rooting for him & the film ... But omg YAWN... such a sluggish film... slow starting and slow first hour. Seemed to me like a bunch of climactic music and dark corners and candle lights, all building up too... (wait for it) NOthing! Just my opinion.

was pleasantly surprised to see such mature acting.
well done! would recommend and would probably see it again! for sure.

My wife and I really had a great time watching this one. Certainly there were some holes in credulity like any horror movie, but the atmosphere and acting lifted the overall product. An unexpected reflection made me scream, to my wife's delight and laughter...

Daniel Radcliffe is great in The Woman In Black. It is written well, and shows a movie does not need blood and slashing to build suspense. Camera work, good acting and well lit, or unlit rooms can still stop your heart. This is a very good movie that delivers twists, turns, Daniel looking great and a very good plot.

When the movie starts the first thing that I notice is the logo for the new Hammer film productions. Hammer studios, if you do know, were a British film company that in the 40's and 50's specialized in film noir, science fiction and other modest genre pictures, but there great success and ultimate legacy would be built upon there gothic horror tales that they made in the late 50's through the mid-70's. Helping to cement the careers of stars such as Christopher Lee, Peter Cushing, Oliver Reed, Herbert Lom, Michael Gough, Hazel Court, Ingrid Pitt, Barbara Shelley, and directors Terence Fisher and Freddie Francis. Like the revived Eailing studios (droll British comedy) and Amicus films (anthology horror movies), the names alone have returned in an attempt to reclaim some of the past glories by using a signature still half heartily remembered by fans of movies of yesteryear, happily Hammer is still leading the way in quality fright films.

The Woman in Black is the most overt return to their gothic roots, telling a ghost story that lives in the morbid tell tale hearts and fractured minds of misguided youths from days of ole. In other words, this is my terrain, these are the scary stories we are told around camp fires or experience on a Saturday matinee television show, before we would find the more graphic shockers of late night. It's a return to innocence, while letting the goose flesh crawl up on our arms.

Set in the Edwardian era and starring former Harry Potter Daniel Radcliffe, here making a fine transition to more mature roles, and Irish character actor Ciaran Hinds, in parts that could easily have been played by Reed and Cushing a few decades back.  Based on Susan Hill's novel, previously filmed for British TV in 1989, with a sequel already in the works. I missed this one in theaters last February, but am grateful that I caught up with it now that it is out on DVD, other than an unnecessary sappy ending, this is good old fashion scary material. Just after seeing the pathetic Apartment 143, here's a scream fest to worm the cockles of my still beating heart.

Thanks to no undue gore or torture here, but there are a few good jolts and a nicely scary atmosphere, plus one of the creepiest, but simple final shots in quiet a long time. This is a nightmare suitable for the whole family, and it's well worth the sleepless night.

I found this movie pretty scary and the ending surprised me. It was a change to see Daniel Radcliffe in something besides Harry Potter.

I loved this movie.  It was brilliant!  If you get this, please take the time to watch the special features and especially the commentary while the movie is going.  It harkens back to an older era of film making and it is pure genius.  However, if you loved this movie, you're going to love the book even better.  I bought the audio book with Paul Ansdell as narrator and rapidly discovered it was similar, but very different from the movie.  The movie cannot do justic to the exquisite writting of Susan Hill and her descriptions of things that just are not in the movie.  So, get both and be prepared for a fantastic journey!

I always rent before I buy, and this one I will buy.  Reminds me of the old Hammer gothics, with much better acting.  Radclift does a great job getting out of the Harry Potter mold.  It's the best haunted house movie I've seen in a very long time.  It serves up the frights with suspense and without the use of constant blood and gore, which is wonderful.  I have the original Haunting (Julie Harris & Claire Bloom) which is good, and have aways thought if the same screen play were used in a remake it could be truely frightening again, given current special effects.

"The Woman In Black". Theatrical release: February 2012. It's a horror/thriller movie based on Susan Hill's book of the same title. It is a classical ghost story set in a village in the early Edwardian times (1901-1917) England. It lacks the fast-paced and gory scenes of contemporary horror films which I think is the strength of this motion picture. Although it's James Watkins' (director) second attempt on directing, he succeeded in frightening us and capturing our interest without splashing blood, displaying brutally dismembered bodies, or strong sexual content. Daniel Radcliffe (Harry Potter) as the lead, proved to be a successful gamble. Daniel brilliantly portrayed a mature solicitor which is a great departure from the mischievous adolescent Harry Potter we've gotten used to. Beside the evil ghost, the movie also deals with abstract human emotions such as the pain of loosing someone and cooping with the aftermath. So, prepare to be scared with class and eloquence with a hint of tragedy. I also recommend the book as it has a different ending.

My daughters wanted to see this film because Daniel Radcliffe stars in it.  But make no mistake.  This character is no Harry Potter.

However, this is an intriguing little scary film.  The pieces come together nicely in a fairly predictable manner, though the ending offered an unexpected surprise.

I found that the ratings of this show were a little harsh. No there wasn't some amazing mind blowing twist at the end of this movie, but it didn't need it. It was a good well contained family friendly thriller.if you haven't seen it I suggest you should.

Gorgeous and well done.  Well - acted, however, I would have preferred more spookiness.  Sometimes he seems less scared in a haunted house than one imagines one would be.  Very watchable though.  Recommend.
Very scary without being gory or cheap. Daniel Radcliff did a great job and I can see he will have a career beyond Harry Potter

I was not ipressed with this movie,it did not
 meet my expectations at all, The Woman in Black
 did not seem to be a thriller or horror type
 movie.

but d@mn was I hoping for more. It's been so long since there's been a legit scary movie and d@mnit if this one didn't have all the trimmings. It wasn't a bad movie by any stretch, but it fell short of what it could have been. The story centers around a young widowed lawyer who goes to some distant town in Britain to search for a last will and testament of a client of his firm. Problem is that the house in which the papers lie is haunted by a ghost that kills a young child every time it's seen. Let's stop right there: What? Every time the ghost is seen it kills a kid? How does the ghost determine what age is young enough to be a kid? Is a 16-year-old sufficient or does it have to be a pre-teen? I dunno, the whole must kill a kid angle was kinda lame imo. But whatever, the lawyer goes to the house and realizes that the house is an island when the tide comes in as the only road to it is covered in water during those times. Cool premise and it could made for some really scary stuff during the times he was stuck there. As is, the director opted for suspense over scares as almost nothing really happens until the end, and even then nothing really happens. It's not a bad movie, but I was hoping they would go for just a haunted house that someone is trapped in rather than what they did. Still, not a bad flick. Final scene was definitely unnerving, which made up for the horrible ending.

I went to see this one with my wife's family thinking that it actually looked like a decent horror movie, I was terribly disappointed. They completely failed to develop or deliver any plot which is made all the worse by the fact that the book is actually decent. If they had stuck to that plot this could have been a good movie.

This provided a good scare - the actual woman in black was super creepy and scary but the story "creeped" along a little slow.  Some of the effects were predictable and stale, but overall I thought the premise was good and the ending was great!

My husband felt that the movie had only 1 tone - bleak and morose.  While I didn't disagree, I thought that that well matched the book. I'm a fan of the multi-disc format, as there are times I want to be able to show a DVD as well as watch on blu-ray. This is one of the few movies that I feel is worth the investment of Blu-ray in my collection, vs. either just a DVD or (worse), an occasional Netflix view.

4 starts rather than five, as I would have liked more behind-the-scenes detail on the Blu-Ray release.

Best horror movie I've seen in years, limited gore but good effects and an ending Hitchcock would be proud of. Harry is definitely grown up and does an excellent job in this movie. Looking for more like this.

This is one of those old fashioned, traditional Gothic horror films that is sorely under-appreciated by modern audiences.  People are too used to gore and slashers that they no longer appreciate atmosphere and being spooked by the old fashioned and imaginative.  This is the sort of horror that sticks with you, that chills you to the bone and I think that's why a lot of people don't understand it or don't appreciate it. It's one thing to be made to jump by a serious killer, it's another thing when a horror film reaches you on a deep and personal level.

This is true to form, traditional Hammer horror.  There hasn't been a good, mysterious and haunting film like this since 1999's Sleepy Hollow starring Johnny Depp.  I miss horror films like these and it's a shame that so many people today just don't "Get" this type of horror.

Something that disturbs me about some fans of this film are the ones that think The Woman in Black character was doing Arthur a favor at the end. She really, really, wasn't.  He was depressed but death is never the answer and no one says "Never forgive" over and over again while helping someone.

Having read the book twice, and seen the BBC 1989 movie version several times,I was entertaining high hopes with this new version of one of my favorite Gothic-horror stories. I was hoping that a more generous budget would do full honors to this little jewel of  the Gothic-horror genre. Although the 1989 version proved that intelligent choices in directing can overcome many obstacles, including a low budget. On the other hand I also was a little fearful about this movie falling prey to today's curse on horror movies:succumbing to the temptation of drowning the story in computerized, cheap special effects, resulting in tons of cheap-gore and gallons of blood, and Disney-like ghouls and monsters.
As it has been mentioned here by other critics, changing the story a little is not a crucial problem when the essential elements are kept,and respected. The 1989 film version did a few changes, but the story plot was there, and it could be followed at a real pace. The script was intelligent and it worked. But this is another story...
I went to see this new movie at a classic movie house from the 50s,restored and with a big screen. I wanted to do full honors to this new version. But,as the movie progressed,the horrific truth was evident, my worst fears were materializing in front of my eyes. There was no real story-plot to follow. I was in for a Blackberry generation version of The Woman in Black. It was to fast-paced to be nothing but a video-game,the scenes kept moving forward,as if slashed with a machete,unable to create a story line. And finally, when I was confronted with the exaggerated and ridiculous "house on the marsh" of this version, I knew I was watching a pathetic blend of 'The Adam's Family meets Stephen King' for the blackberry generation. From there on it was downhill, a movie predictably drowned in unnecessary and exaggerated special effects such as the bleeding-bed, and a woman in black so unsubstantial that it looked more like a Japanese-anime figure running amok the Adam's family house. The end was not only too much of a travesty,but a corny and childish idea,unworthy of Susan Hill's work.
For those unfamiliar with good literature, or a good reading, this 'video-game' version might do. But for those who are familiar with real stories and good scripts, my recommendation is:AVOID this waste of money and time like you would the plague. For me this was THE WASTE OF A GOOD CHANCE...
If you want your intelligence to be respected, stick to the 1989 BBC version. It might be too slow for those whose attention span can not survive anything beyond 60-seconds bytes,or nothing deeper than a video-game plot,but for those able to enjoy true suspense and a good literary build-up of the plot, the story IS THERE,and its good!
If you like classic Gothic horror stories, with well written scripts and literary style, I recommend movies like:
The Changeling,Haunted! The Reincarnation of Peter Proud,The Uninvited,and even The House Where Evil Dwells. And the wonderful literary ghost stories of Japanese films like KWAIDAN and Ugetsu,

It's one of those movies that you have to watch alone. Daniel Radcliffe had great acting as usual and the movie just felt realistic compared to other horror movies that just have blood/over-acting/screams and stuff. This movie doesn't have any nasty scene or any like disgusting scene. It's a clean horror haunted house movie and I had alot of fun watching it. Ghost stories are quite popular in England, probably because the weather and the winters give an optimal spooky atmosphere. The Woman in Black is just such a ghost story. It was first a novel, then made into a TV movie, a stage play, and two radio dramas before the release of this cinema version (which I saw on DVD).

The story follows Arthur Kipps (played by Daniel Radcliffe), a young, widowed lawyer who has a four-year old son. He is still troubled by the loss of his wife. That has affected his work. The law firm sends him off to the North to settle the estate of Alice Drablow. She lived in Eel Marsh House at the end of Nine Lives Causeway. The causeway is only navigable at low tide. The house is full of paperwork that needs sorting to ensure the law firm's copy of her will is indeed the current one. This is Kipps last chance to prove he is serious about working for the firm. If he does not do well, he will be fired.

He takes a train up to the town of Crynith Gifford. He meets a local man, Samuel Daily, who is quite rich (he owns the only car for miles and miles) and is friendly enough. The rest of the town is not so friendly because of the house's bad history and the local legend of the Woman in Black. She is mostly seen either by the house or on the causeway, but occasionally in town. Whenever she is seen, soon thereafter a child dies. Typically the death is a quite horrible one. Naturally the townfolk don't want anyone around the house. Kipps insists on going (to keep his job). As he researches through the papers, he uncovers information about the Woman in Black. Oh yeah, and strange noises and apparitions start happening too. And his son is supposed to come up on the weekend for a holiday!

The movie centers on Kipps. It follows his investigation of the paperwork just enough to reveal the identity and motives of the Woman in Black. His character is well developed. His motives for staying are sensible enough and he is likeable enough that the viewer actually cares what happens to him. Developing an intelligent, sympathetic main character is critical in this type of movie. Radcliffe gives a great performance, subtle and nuanced without hysterics. He makes it more chilling.

Much of the film shows him wandering through the house trying to look around corners for what just made that noise or what he just saw out of the corner of his eye. Plenty of cobwebs, dark corners, and creepy children's toys are made even more ominous by the low-key but highly evocative score. The atmosphere is great and delivers plenty of goosebumps. The story is interesting enough and the various twists are only occasionally predictable and always effective.

The Woman in Black is a classic example of a haunted house movie, ranking with the best in that genre (The Uninvited, The Haunting, and The Changeling being the best).

There's a legend around the seaside town of Crythin Gifford of a woman all dressed in black hiding her face beneath a long black veil.  Whenever someone sees her, somewhere in town, a child dies.

When troubled estate attorney Arthur Kipps (Daniel Radcliffe of the Harry Potter fame) comes to town to settle the estate of an eccentric client, he has no idea of the hostility the town throws his way.  No one will speak to him except to tell him that it would be wise to leave.  But he is determined to get the job done or else risk losing his job.  While staying at his former client's decrepit mansion cut of from the rest of the world by a marsh, Kipps begins seeing a mysterious woman in black and soon enough, a young girl dies in his arms.  As the sightings of this woman increases, the number of dead children begins to rise and Kipps finds himself in the center of a mystery that has haunted the town over the last forty years; a mystery involving the accidental drowning of a young boy tragically witnessed by the boy's mother whom the townspeople had successfully taken the child from due to their strict moral code simply because he was born out of wedlock.  His mother died in the midst of her grief and that grief turned to revenge.  Now Kipps has three days to uncover the truth behind the legend and bring about a close to the town's curse before his own son becomes the next target for The Woman In Black.

The movie itself was energetic enough to keep you interested and really harken back to the late Brittish horror movies of the 60s and 70s.  The score by Marco Beltrami was creepy and helped added some much needed tension that the movie lacked visually.  But there are a fair amount of problems here.  The jump scares are numerous.  And while Radcliffe is a really good actor, I thought he was miscast.  He looked really to young for the part.  In fact, he looked like he was 18 with badly grown facial hair.  I also loved how the boy in the marsh body was never recovered, yet Kipps was not only able to locate it in record time, the carriage he died in looked as if it had just rolled in yesterday instead of rotting under the water and muck for the last forty years.  But the biggest complaint lies in the ending.  For a movie this grim, I found it a little too happy, a little too Hollywood. It seemed out of place and that pretty much killed it for me.  Even so, I'm still recommending it just on its mystery quality and because it's a simple ghost story that isn't complicated or burden down by too much back story.  Good for a rainy night.

An old-fashioned ghost story crafted with an eerie-eye reminiscent of classic Hollywood fright films, HAMMER Studio's THE WOMAN IN BLACK is the perfect remedy for those seeking a cure from the usual fare which passes for contemporary horror in today's overwrought shock film industry. Bravely side-stepping modern "scary movie" conventions (gratuitous gore; scantily clad teenagers being chased through dense forests by faceless phantoms) the ghostly WOMAN succeeds by playing by its own haunted set of rules which transforms what could have been a mundane endeavor into a skillful and clever take on the haunted house genre which masterfully ratchets-up the thrills until going "full-ghost" during it's fright-infested second act.

Daniel Radcliffe gives a stately and refined post-Harry Potter performance as Arthur Kipps, a late-19th-century lawyer coming to terms with the recent loss of his wife when he is summoned to a remote mansion in Victorian-era England to settle the affairs of a recently deceased woman's estate. But all is not well in the God-fearing hamlet of Crythin Gifford for upon his arrival, a series of disturbing supernatural events transpire which are revealed to be the violent physical manifestations of a vengeful ghost which is targeting the children of the populace surrounding the (supposedly) uninhabited estate.

Not long after, Kipps decides to investigate further and does so by spending the evening in the foreboding mansion (alone). It is here that the witching hour begins in earnest and the filmmakers get down to business and unleash a chilling maelstrom of terror upon the unnerved Kipps. The house shudders to life and unleashes oppressive energies which take form in the fearsome guise of shapeless apparitions and menacing shadow figures. Musty corridors become unlikely conduits for horrific screams to pierce the mansions tomb-like serenity and disembodied voices whisper evil-sentiments which reverberate throughout its cavernous interiors. Scenes depicting the titular Woman In Black are particularly disturbing and are capable of inducing nightmares amongst those (like me) susceptible to such things.

The production and set design are superlative and combine to create one of the more memorable spooky house environments of recent times: elongated hallways stretch forever into darkness; chandeliers glow diffused hues from beneath blankets of cobwebs; the obligatory grand stairway which creaks and moans with menace and spacious rooms that are adorned with faded photographs of souls long-departed. Additional tech credits are top notch with the cinematography aptly capturing the grim atmosphere and washed-out gloom of the cold and uninviting house; and the nerve-rattling score does it job as it keeps things appropriately sinister by hitting its cues and punctuating key scenes with auditory dread.

Mr. Kipps eventually uncovers the dark motives surrounding the disturbances and the film reaches a spiritual and satisfying conclusion. But in the interest of avoiding spoilers, you will have to seek out the movie yourselves to discover the truth behind the curse which has befallen the town. The Woman In Black is a welcome return to SCARY haunted house storytelling and is tailor-made for viewing on dark and stormy evenings. So put away the Ouija board for a few hours, cozy-up with your favorite malevolent spirit and prepare for a night of fright with this spectral spinster. -Ronnie Jimenez, Pumpkin Patch Gazette

The Woman in Black was an excellent ghost/house thriller.  One of the best looking haunted houses I have ever seen in a movie.  Very creepy looking and was "cut-off" when the high tide came in so it was very isolated.  What happens to the children when anyone sees the woman in black??  Watch the movie and find out.  Loved it!

I liked this movie but the ending ruined it. Minor spoilers ahead. Although the sets were fantastic and the watery setting was very nice, all the people in the film lack character. Oh, sure you learn about their pasts, but no one develops or changes much.

This is especially true for the movie's main villain. It's just an evil thing. Sure it has motivation, but there's no chance for redemption or resolution. The first 90% is good spooky entertainment. The last bit is high budget indie laziness disguised as high concept. It's more a record of events than a story.
Boring! Very slow, definitely not scary. Complete waste of time and money.  Acting was ok. Definitely would not recommend anyone to see this movie.

Having read Susan Hill's sinister and chilling tale a number of times, I had high hopes for this screen adaptation. And boy did it look good - the opening sequence, where innocent child play quite seamlessly flows into a precisely choreographed triple suicide, seemed promising enough. But from then on, I was sorely let down, or rather, irritated and annoyed with what I forced myself to watch.

It is a valid question whether or not Hill's story has the potential to be made into anything that could satisfy the standards expected by moviegoers of today; while relying mainly on atmosphere and the building effects of oppressive settings/landscapes, the plot is simple, with maybe just too little action to be found. So the temptation to make it "bigger" must certainly be there. Now changing a few details isn't necessarily a crime (I did like the parrot!), as long as the original mood and structure is retained - but here's where the filmmakers fall pitifully short. There's no exposition to speak of; the protagonist's life context, i.e., family and work, is rushed through in a couple of seconds. No chance of getting a real sense of place either. The crucial funeral/church scene is dropped and we are plunged almost head-on into the house, where the mystery (even though not a great one to begin with) is revealed practically at once. To avoid spoilers I won't describe all the devious and near-ridiculous plot additions, including the attempt to make the progagonist a tragic hero, and - worst of all - an incredibly kitschy, Hollywood-inspired ending. See for yourself, if you dare...

It's not, however, the misbegotten script's fault alone. As remarked in another review, the settings have an artificial look about them and they are far too dark as well, with the house almost turned into some gloomy vampire castle, boasting a collection of mechanical toys that rivals the one in Joseph L. Mankiewicz's "Sleuth", ready to steal any ghost's show - in fact that's exactly what they do. And then it must be Daniel Radcliffe of all actors, who's bound to draw pointless Potter references by the thousands. He's not too bad though: if acting means putting on a grief-stricken look on your face and keeping it there for 90+ minutes, he succeeds.

Notwithstanding a much lower budget and complete absence of digital effects, Herbert Wise did quite an impressive job with his 1989 "daylight" TV version (it's not perfect, the woman herself being the problem); he wouldn't even spare us the "evil" ending (although again slightly changed), which is disturbing in the extreme, but consistent with the story. An ending apparently too hard on audiences of today. - Who then is expected to believe that the book's author actually approved of this concoction? Probably she had no choice.

For those familiar with the novel this film is simply unbearable; and for those who aren't, even taken as standard horror fare it should be disappointing, given the chain of stereotypes presented. That bit of period feel just can't be enough.

While England is god's chosen country of spooks without a doubt, there'll always be exceptions: see F.A. Bayona and his 2007 "El Orfanato". The Spanish know how to do better these days.
I found this movie to be odd and very disappointing. Not scary at all and the story was just plain.

What's it about?

Young lawyer Arthur Kipps is a widower with a young son. After he is dispatched to a remote village by his employer, he discovers that the vengeful ghost of a scorned woman is terrorizing the locals.

Is it any good?

If you can ignore the barrage of haunted house cliches, this old school ghost story has some genuine chills. `The Woman in Black' is based on the 1983 Susan Hill book of the same name and is also an on going play in London's West End. The dark tone is set right from the start as three young girls having an innocent tea party, get up in a trance, walk to the window and jump to their deaths...woah! That tea is some strong shit!. But it quickly becomes clear that this movie isn't about powerful hallucinates, it's about a pissed off dead lady who hates kids. As `The Woman in Black's' vengeance is slowly revealed, so are the cliches; rocking chairs, freaky porcelain dolls, ghostly children, dark corridors and window apparitions, just to name a few. The thrills come mainly from a handful of jump-out scares, which are sharpened thanks to some nice pacing and lighting. Daniel Radcliffe is also sharp, this is his first role since `Harry Potter' and he shows some serious emotion as a young father and widower, he tackles the role with plenty of maturity and seems well beyond his 22 years. `The Woman in Black' may not shock serious horror buffs, but the jump-out scares will guarantee a close quarter nestle from your lady.

Best bit?

The dark ominous atmosphere stays consistent throughout the film.

Did you know?

The vehicle driven by Ciaran Hinds's character is a Rolls Royce Silver Ghost.
Was dissapointed in this movie. It is depressing and not really scary. Thought I would give it a try. I liked some of his other movies better.

Great Build up ,but awful let down. I was expecting more than just a ghost story that ended with more ghosts. I just don't consider dad and son dying then being reunited with mom too happy. The Woman in Black just the titled made me so eager to watch and now I feel as if I wasted my time. I will give this 3 stars only because of "Harry Potter", is all grown up. LOL

Probably would have given this one four stars for a suspenseful film if not for the really stupid ending.  Without giving much away, "they all died happily ever after".  It's Ok, but don't expect too much.

With the film The Woman in Black, Hammer Studios returns to their glory days of supernatural storytelling, invoking the Victorian-type ghost story in superb style. Easily one of the most stylish, most chilling horror films of the last couple of decades, this one also has a heart (as the best always do).The story plays on both the cards of the heartbroken young widower in grief over his wife's death as well as the both sad and frightening vengeful ghost whose mystery plays out and creating a truly terrifying build-up.

For his part, Daniel Radcliffe shows he can work as a reliable adult lead, supported by a highly experienced ensemble cast led by Ciarn Hinds. The film itself glories in its dark, broken beauty and makes one reminisce about haunted house classics like The Innocents (1961). There are also fairly potent visual reminders of other classic films such as The Phantom Carriage (1921) and Hammer's own Night Creatures (1962). The colors, though by no means absent, are mostly muted (making a great contrast in the few instances where they exist as striking). The music is minimal, unlike most American horror films that overwhelm with score from beginning to end.

The story, adapted directly from the Susan Hill novel of the same name (itself also the source of one of the most iconic, longest-running English plays) features all of the classic elements of a haunted house story: the large, imposing mansion, the foggy, stormy atmosphere, a background in tragedy... it's all there. The tragedy compels us to listen to the story and to open our minds to it. We each experience tragedy and loss in our lives, and that seeking to connect with what (and who) we've lost can lead us down a path of desperation, but we don't know what doors and to what horrors that desperation can lead to. That is one of the great appeals of the gothic ghost story, and it plays out in excellence here. As a traditional ghost story film, The Woman in Black may be "by the book," but the book is as chilling as anyone could imagine.
Was not sure what to expect when I ordered this movie, but just had to see it. My husband and I both enjoyed the movie. It was pretty intense and suspenseful. We give it a "Thumbs Up".

London, the turn of the century. Widowed lawyer Arthur Kipps is sent by his office to deal with the legal affairs of Eel Marsh House, whose owners wish to sell it. He finds the local village folk uncooperative and fearful of the house, apart from rich landowner Samuel Daily (who owns the only motorcar in the village). As Kipps investigates the mystery of Eel Marsh House, he learns of a spate of unusual deaths amongst the local children and starts seeing a woman dressed in black watching his activities.

The Woman in Black is an adaptation of Susan Hill's 1983 novel of the same name. It was produced by the resurgent British company Hammer Film Productions, who in an earlier incarnation produced numerous horror films in the 1950s and 1960s. Unlike most of those films, which were noted for their use of blood and gore, The Woman in Black is a taut, claustrophobic piece which relies on tension and things glimpsed out of the corner of the eye.

The film's casting is superb, with a post-Harry Potter Daniel Radcliffe starring as Arthur Kipps (coincidentally, a role previously played by his on-screen father Adrian Rawlins in a 1989 TV movie based on the book). Radcliffe arguably risks more typecasting than any actor in film history, but his canny choice of stage and screen roles has seen him so far avoid that fate. In The Woman in Black he convinces in the role of the world-weary, grief-stricken father whose career as a lawyer is in doubt due to his growing disillusionment with the world. The only other major character is Samuel Daily, played with conviction by the always-excellent Ciaran Hinds.

The director, James Watkins, handles the material well. His depictions of a village consumed by fear, the huge and rambling Eel Marsh House and of lonely and windswept marshlands are all excellent, giving the film a real sense of place. Knocking in at just 95 minutes, the film also doesn't outstay its welcome.

Unfortunately, the movie shows its hand a little too early. Upon arriving in the village, Kipps is immediately greeted by fear, suspicion and terror, letting the audience know that All is Not Well. It's not long before just about every time we get a close-up on Kipps we also get some sinister stuff going on in the background, or every other time he turns around we get a shot of the Woman in Black hanging about for a moment. The first few times this happens, it's unsettling. Somewhere around the twentieth, it loses its power. Viewers will soon find themselves predicting when something 'scary' is about to happen and will, by and large, be right. The film does succeed in achieving a few genuine shocks despite this issue, the movie's second half is overall weakened by this predictability. Given writer Jane Goldman's solid form (Stardust, Kick-Ass, X-Men: First Class), it's surprising that she doesn't put more genuine twists into the script, especially given its deviations from the source material.

The Woman in Black (***) is well-made, excellently-acted, concise, focused and well-directed. The film is let down by its script, which relies a little too much on a single scare tactic and overplays it to the point of boredom. In this manner, The Woman in Black is the film equivalent of the computer game Doom 3: well-made, great in short bursts, but a little dull over the long haul. It is redeemed somewhat by a startling ending, however, and is certainly worth watching.
My roommates and I kept on jumping and screaming throughout the whole movie. Its definitely a good movie to watch at night and get freaked out.

Based on the book of the same name by Susan Hill (which I have not read), this movie is good-scary. Creepy-scary. The kind of scary I like and can't often find. It's not gory, and it only has a couple of cheap-ish, jump-out-of-your-seat scares.  And it's a really good story to which I hope they make a sequel.  (UPDATE: They're making a sequel for 2014!)

My husband and I rented this expecting it to be bad, to be quite honest. We hadn't heard much about it and figured it was because Daniel Radcliffe hadn't been able to pull out of Harry Potter-mode. In the very beginning, he actually is very Harry-ish when interacting with his character's son, and I almost wrote the movie off right then. But after that, he made me forget that he was Potter and I was glued to the TV.  The atmosphere is great (anything with possessed Victorian wind-up dolls creeps me right out), the acting is great (after those first few bumps), and it made for a believably scary story that entertained my socks off (which is a feat, considering how much I love wearing socks.)  Radcliffe made me believe his mourning and desperation without going over the top, and I absolutely loved the ending. I am super excited and can't wait for The Woman in Black: Angels of Death.

Watched this twice in one night, with two different sets of family members. Second time through it was easy to see plot holes. Untied, or shabbily tied ends.

For me, the basis of WHY just wasn't strong enough. That said, I'd still recommend the show -- it's fun spooky, not gross or so creepy you have nightmares. I'm glad they still make movies like this, since I don't watch the extreme other horror flicks that stick to your bones.

The story for Woman in Black is mysterious and begs the viewer for their attention. The opening scenes are depressing and sad, but good building blocks for the over all story. As the movie continues you are filled with questions and suspense. Why do people seem to shun him away? What's their problem? Why is no one cooperative when it comes to dealing with the house and estate? Then, when he finally gets to the house, the subtle creepy sounds, look and events are perfect. Not over the top scary, but enough to put a shiver in your spine. The entire movie is suspenseful, intriguing and creepy-the story line is creative, believeable and heart tugging (especially if you are a parent). I was surprised to see Daniel ratcliff in such a dramatic role so soon after his epic Harry Potter movies, but was pleasantly surprised at his performance. This was a very mature role for him in the wake of his "harry" image. And i must say, I commend him. He did well. A standing ovation! (But it doesn't stop one from screaming "pull out your wand, Harry!" during threatening parts of the film. Ha ha.) Overall, a good movie for horror, suspense and thriller film appreciators alike! I highly recommend The Woman in Black.

I loved this movie.  There were several times during the movie that scared me so much I jumped out of my chair. My husband and I watched it together and we were both wondering how it was going to end. I believe it ended the only way it could possibly end. Great entertainment!

Dead ghost lady who lost her son seeks revenge on all the towns children, holding somekind of unseen power over the children she convinces them to kill themselves, and no one can stop this vengful ghost, so this story makes no sence to me, the background scenses are very nice, acting is desent, but thats it, has a bad ending that frustrates you, and the killing goes on, boo

First of all, Daniel Radcliffe is a first class actor. Not for one minute during the movie was I thinking "Harry Potter!". This was really my kind of thriller, I like to be scared by the story but I don't like to be nauseated by blood and gore. The storyline in The Woman in Black is what scares you, the realness of the characters and the misery of the town Arthur Kipps (Radcliffe) finds himself in. Yes things will jump out at you but not so often that you want to stop watching.

The Woman in Black is a supernatural thriller in all the right ways. An unknown energy haunts the town that Arthur Kipps finds himself in at the order of his law firm. He is to investigate the estate of a woman who died who apparently had quite a bit of paperwork in her mansion located a few miles out of town. The people of the town are uneasy and unwelcoming when Kipps arrives, they try to make him leave before his work is complete. It appears to be some sort of conspiracy until more is revealed about the town's residents. They have all lost children to an unknown force which is somehow associated with the mansion left behind by the dead woman. Kipps presence in the town awakens the horror inflicted on the town by the woman in black.

I've watched this movie a few times since I first saw it and it still hasn't lost its appeal. The plot pulls you in and holds you until the movie is over.

On a side note though, it did remind me vaguely of The Ring. Anyone who's seen it will have to let me know whether they agree.

I was hoping that I would like this movie more, but I found it almost unwatchable. Only Daniel Radcliffe would have gotten me past the first fifteen minutes. I'm not a big horror fan, which may be part of the problem; I'm probably out of synch with what horror fans like. But I always feel that well-done horror has some kind of point beyond nihilistic unpleasantness. Often it's a very moralistic point, which you could argue is the case here, with the evil ghost being a "wronged woman." But the victims of her wrath are wholly blameless of any complicity, past or present, in her sufferings, and there's never any resolution to her pain or theirs. On top of this, the events of the film are less horrific than merely sadistic. I don't like stories that exploit the suffering of children or animals and the people who grieve for them. That's just cheap manipulation and disturbing on a whole other level--writers and filmmakers who do this seem more pathological themselves than their characters. The movie works very, very hard to be "scary" and it's so obvious about it, the artifice shows. The scary old house is a really, *really* scary old house...but why was it so decrepit when its owner had died so recently that her papers were still in probate and being sorted out by lawyers? Just how long had that house been empty? Then, not only is the house already scary, it's out on a sort of point which turns into an island at high tide. Why would anyone build a big expensive mansion in such a location, and why didn't it just sink, since it's surrounded by quicksand? There are lots of scary bits with ghosts (or visions, at least) suddenly appearing or sneaking up behind, but it's like a carnival funhouse. The ghosts literally "leap out and yell boo," and even as you're jumping out of your seat, you have this annoyed sense that you're just the butt of a practical joke. Since this is a movie about dead children, of course we have lots of Scary Toys, too. The contrivances are just too apparent. I didn't read the book on which this is based, so I don't know how much the scriptwriters are to blame. You could extract a psychological mystery out of this; the protagonist, Arthur Kipps, lost his young wife when she died giving birth to their first child. Four years later, he is still so consumed by grief that his son draws pictures of him wearing black and crying because "daddy always looks like that," and his bosses are fed up with him and about to fire him if he doesn't get over himself. But if Kipps has conflicted feelings toward his son, which might cause him to unconsciously hate children, the movie never implies this, so the sudden uptick in child deaths after his arrival in the village has no explanation. I won't spoil the ending, but let's just say it's a head-scratcher, and ultimately frustrating. You also see it coming from miles away. I only watched this movie because Radcliffe is in it, and unlike some reviewers, I think he does a great job. If he seems a little monochromatic, it's the fault of the script, not his performance. He works hard but he's given nothing to do except be grief-stricken, scared or desperate. He's choosing unusual roles post-Harry-Potter, and while that can be a good thing for an actor, he needs to allow himself more range than *The Woman in Black* allows him to display. There are some other fine performers in this movie, especially Janet McTeer and Ciaran Hinds, and all the cast does a good job, but most of them feel wasted. The movie is so grim, pratically the only emotion anyone is allowed to show is grief. This movie is one of the new offerings from the revived Hammer Films Productions, and it reminded me of a few of its earlier, sadder movies, in particular *Blood on Satan's Claw.* It's also very reminiscent of *The Sixth Sense (Collector's Edition Series).* But unless you're suffering from crippling happiness and euphoria and need to bring yourself down (and this one will do it), I can't recommend *The Woman in Black.*
