This movie was OK, not great.  The visuals were good, and the gothic feel was perfect for a ghost story......but it was slow and the ending was SO predictable that is was irritating.  I knew how this was going to end halfway through.  Daniel Radcliffe was good in this and has a great look about him for this type of story.  Just wish there had been more substance to the movie and more of a twist here and there.  There has been no good ghost story out there since The Others.  And we need one!
I spent half the movie looking for my nerve pills, and the other half wondering where Harry's glasses were.  The plot was predictable, and the ending left me stupefied.  Um, not in a good way.

This is a scary movie be cause it is has some very disturbing scenes of children being influenced to kill themselves in some very horrendous ways. Daniel Radcliffe's performance is exceptional. He has to be on the screen for over Ninety
percent of the film. He plays Arthur Kipps a widower with a young son, who is played by Radcliffe's Godson Misha Handley.  This film boasts a fine cast of players Ciaran Hinds
who was in the last  "Potter" film; here plays a man who lives a little bit in denial about the happenings in the village near the old house on the moor. His wife is played by Janet McTeer. Mention should also be made of the chilling performance of Liz White who portrayed Jennet "The Woman in Black" There are really no bad performances in this movie at all. While the film relies on a few old horror film tricks to get a few scares out the the
audience it manages to tell the story quite effecively. The ending which is good and a little different I will not divulge. I will say that this is a film that parents or  others should watch first before letting younger Radcliffe fans view it.
It carries a PG 13 rating for a good reason.

I was stunningly surprised at how wonderful this film is.  It is modern, yet classic, moody, atmospheric, and memorable.  I could honestly go on and on listing the moments and the scenes which stand out to me, and there are many.  It's just wonderful.

I proudly give a round of applause to James Watkins, Daniel Radcliffe, Ciarn Hinds, and Janet McTeer.

Wow!  Wow!  Wow!

My fear with this one is that Daniel Radcliffe wouldn't be able to convince me he wasn't Harry Potter. How wrong I was! The character he plays is such a departure from Harry Potter that I didn't even think about it after the first 10 minuets or so. I also have to say that Mr. Radcliffe is such a great actor. I never really paid much attention to the acting in Harry Potter - that wasn't what I watched those movies for anyway... But I think Radcliffe has really proven that he's a great actor with this one.

This is one of the better "horror" movies that I've seen in a while. It used sound and light to create suspense, while the story was being built up. There were quite a few "jumpy" moments, which even though I was expecting them got me. My dog even woke up with a start twice.

The story was pretty good. A young man must go to a village where he's unwelcome and while there he uncovers their secret. As he's putting the pieces of the puzzle together children in the village start dying. The young lawyer is trying to figure how all this connects together while he accepts the hospitality of one of the wealthy families in the village. The wife appears to be a bit crazy, but she does help put some fire into plot.

The only reason this did not receive a 5 star rating was the ending. It wasn't a horrible ending, but I was expecting something different. After the puzzle is "figured out" I thought that would be the end. But the ending is much more sinister than I would have imagined.

I would have to say despite the PG-13 rating that it shouldn't be watched by younger kids. I think I would have to say 15 or 16 rather than 13 as the appropriate age limit. There's some graphic scenes, although they aren't necessarily violent they are disturbing none the less. There's not much in the way of strong language, I honestly don't remember any but it could have just slipped my mind.
Much better than I thought it would be. Not sure I can ever really see Daniel Radcliffe as anyone but Harry Potter, but I thought he was good in this film, and it was scary!

The movie was full of predictable situations.  Daniel Radcliffe was a lifeless character encountering a mysterious ghost who's intention seems to be centered on the proper burial/reunion with her son.  I gave it a two star only for the movie set location.

I missed seeing this movie when it was playing in theaters. So I was happy to watch it here on Amazon. Daniel Radcliffe's performance was excellent just as it was when he played Harry Potter. Really enjoyed movie. I love the "Spooky" movies,always have. This version of The Woman in Black was an  improvement in my opinion over an earlier version no doubt because young Daniel was the principle actor. Movie certainly worth watching.
An over-reliance on repetitive cacphony, loud and irritating, to create an atmosphere of suspense is a sure sign of a director who doesn't know how to create it otherwise.

This was a pretty scary movie. It's a little hard to get past the Harry Potter thing, but there's a good twist at the end and we did jump several times. All in all I liked it enough to watch it a 2nd time with a friend.

So many times I am disappointed with scary movies...mostly because they tend not to be scary.  Not this one.  I jumped several times (and so did my husband).  Main character acting is not that great - he should just stick to Harry Potter, but other than that I would highly recommend if you like thrillers.

This flick is a good start for Daniel Radcliffes' post "Harry Potter" acting career.  Though slow moving, we are treated to a  forboding,  foggy,  English countryside atmospheric style photography throughout.  Radcliffe plays his investigator roll low key and dosen't become bigger than the picture itself.  A mothers' lament for the avoidable death of her son, takes its' toll on a small remote village, after her death.  Be prepared for a few sudden shock sequences!  This is thought provoking horror, with minimal blood and gore, akin to pictures made in the 1940's 50's and 60's.  The CGI contibution is mainly for background, rather than creating overblown fantasy creatures.  For an hour and a half Radcliffe must hold our attention.  His fans and those who enjoy ghost stories should both be satisfied.  The films ending packs an unexpected punch!

I liked the original woman in black - wasn't happy to see a remake being made - and really wasn't happy that Daniel Radcliffe was in it.  I apologize.  Daniel does a fine job.  The movie is a good, solid remake of old time horror films where imagination provides the chills more than gore and shock (though there was a bit of both).  Our family all really enjoyed it.  If you are a fan of the old movie you'll probably like it.  If you liked the original version of THE HAUNTING you'll probably like this.  It was a good ghost story, and I'll probably buy it for my collection.  If you like slasher movies, gore, or shock-fests this will be too slow for you.

We loved this movie!  It has been a very long time since we have seen a great scary movie.  The story line keeps you guessing all the way till the end. And, on the edge of your seat.  Daniel Radcliff was superb.
this movie totally SUCKED big time...it's a waste of time and money. I couldn't stay awake to save my life.
I am very upset it said dvd and it is blue ray the main thing is the region is wrong so we cant watch it even on the ps3.

If I were young, or hadn't seen very many ghostly horror movies, this might have been pretty good. But I'm not, and I have, so this was a real yawn fest.

Here's the scoop. Radcliffe is a solicitor in Jolly Old. He's depressed because he lost his wife during the birth of their only son. His job performance is getting worse and he's in debt. His boss gives him one last chance. He needs to go to an old, dilapidated house in some town and straighten out the paperwork after its final owner has passed. Weird stuff starts to happen and kids start to die. He gets sidetracked and needs to get to the bottom of things.

This is all so old. The creepy looking dolls, the creepy wind-up toys. The cob-webs and gloominess. Things half seen. Clues behind wallpaper. I can't believe they're still using this stuff. There are a couple of jump scares which, as any film maker should know, no longer cut it. The music score was too obvious. It underscored the on-screen happenings with a thick, black magic marker. There were a couple of genuinely creepy scenes in the third act but, by that time, it was too late.

On the production side, they DID try. The sets, though old news, were done well. The costuming was decent and good attention was paid to period detail. The acting was decent enough, though I found Radcliffe to be rather stiff. And I liked the way they ended the story. They could have sapped it up but they chose a higher road.

This isn't bad. Maybe it's made for a younger audience that hasn't been through the decades of horror films as have I.
Good thriller.  We enjoyed it as a family and my wife had a blanket pulled up to her eyes at several points.  Glad I didn't pay to see it at the movie but well worth the PPV cost.

First off, I want to say that I enjoyed Daniel Radcliffe in this movie. I don't think anyone could have done a better job with the script he had to work with. I like watching serious movies, and he played this troubled character well, without overdoing it.  However, the movie moves too slowly in the beginning and waits too long to provide some necessary explanations. Also, some of the special effects are too mechanical--cheap maybe?

I didn't read the book, but the idea in this movie of what the woman in black is doing and why, and the way Radcliffe's character seeks to appease her made for a good story-line. While the ending could be called satisfying by some, I don't understand why the story ended that way.

As is the case with almost all ghost stories from the UK, the skill in crafting an eerie and surreal version of the book by Susan Hill is palpable. As is evident by Susan Hill's book, and M R James' stories, the British  skill of the things at the periphery of one's vision is amazing. I would not recommend reading the book before seeing the film, however, that being said, if you have, it will not destroy your enjoyment of the film if you do. Daniel Radcliffe delivers a stellar on camera performance, and the very well chosen cast makes this story a delivered work on a brilliant level. Even the lower level scares make for some great fun in the ghost story. The commentary is well worth listening to, just as the features show a lot more of the extras. I would guess that most people will mist some of the sights out of direct vision. The locations are very well chosen, and some of these are revealed in the commentary, but so long as you go along for the ride, this is a brilliant work. I watched the film in the theatre and on one "cheap" scare a young woman just about pierced my ear drums, but strangely enough on the more surreal elements, she was not scared ( I can only assume she was in shock). Excellent film, great in all respects.
  Regarding the Ultraviolet copy: Don't bother. The inconvenience of setting up two accounts, and the lack of certainty first of all of any sort of availability is a problem, and the limit of Ultraviolet access beyond a few years is farcical. Insist on actual digital copies for your portable device because the cloud is an issue that will haunt your personal details, and if they do not fix security and infrastructure, Ultraviolet is another cloud idea that is a pipe dream. For a digital copy it is not worth the problem, since there are other ways to get digital copies, and IMO the companies should provide a copy in a proper digital format.

Once again, my husband chose the Saturday night movie rental. I admit, "The Help" (my pick) was over-rated, but at least it had redeeming social value and historical relevance. Movies like The Woman in Black? Not a single interesting point. After all the hero's trouble to give the vicious dead woman what she wanted, we're left with the ol' "No good deed goes unpunished" message.

Gratuitious violence, gore and fun-house scare tactics in scene after scene. Look out the window, see a scary ghost face staring back at you. If you want to feel like a kid on a sleepover trying to experience terror, this is safer than sneaking out of the house to jump off a bridge --and young adults today are actually doing this, and one died, not from the jump, but from the river bacteria that shot up her sinus cavities and slowly killed her. Yeah. I only wish I was making this up.

So, stupid me, for the sake of cuddling beside my husband on the sofa for 90 minutes, I endured this stupid waste of good cinematography and movie sets. I wish I'd left the room and finished reading Jenna Blum's "the stormchasers," best purchase all year from amazon, and left him with the cat, but the smooth-brained furball had the good sense to disappear instead of watching this idiotic movie. He's back now. (The cat.)I'm the one who has to bury those gruesome images before bedtime: the girl who swallowed lye, the drowned boy, the three girls leaping from the attic window, and that final scene, and if this is a spoiler, stop reading now, but did you really expect a happy ending? Stupid, pointless, stupid waste of time. Arrrghhh!!!! This is why I read the endings of books if, after a few chapters, I sense it's going to be a downer. If indeed the ending stinks, I'm 98% certain to drop the novel cold. (Dr. Zhivago was one exception, but that was 30 years ago.)

If you really want to be scared, just read the newspaper.

Daniel Radcliffe, a Hollywood pretty boy can't act his way out of a paper bag, and the flim is about as scary as an M. Night Shyamalan picture. While the camera work is subpar, it can't make up for the rest of the flim. I'm glad I rented this instead of bought it.
This movie was awesome. It kept you on the edge of your seat. I would recommend this movie to any horror fan.

I enjoyed the plot, the  cameral work and suspense and  liked the ending.  It wasn't as scary as described  but it did hold my attention trying to figure out where the plot was leading.  I hope Denial Radcliffe  does more movies.

I hated this movie, way too weird.  This may suit some of the deep thinkers but did nothing for me.  They kept jumping from scene to scene and nothing really tied in or brought out the plot.  Oh wait, there was no plot, that may explain why it was boring as hell.  A waste of good money, can I exchange it? lol

And the story's not that bad. I recommend this to anyone who enjoys that feeling you get when watching horror movies especially suspenseful horrors. To avoid ruining the ending for you all, I will just say I could have called the ending almost as if I were one of the writers for the piece itself.

This movie is constantly building tension and is relatively unpredictable.  Because of the minimal dialogue the actor has to build the tension in his essence, his being and he does that superbly.  I wondered if I could forget Radcliff's previous roles and if that would taint my viewing enjoyment.  But not at all, he is the character he plays in this movie and I don't think I thought of Potter even once while watching.  Outstanding acting and the writing for this movie was supurb.

I think many reviewers were a little to generous with this film.  I give it three stars meaning it was adequate, a five out of ten.  Would I buy it, no, should you pay to watch it, no.  This movie has a few jumpy moments, but gets rather dull as the plot goes on.  The cinematography, as with so many films this days, is very professional and the setting is very dreary, reminding me much of Jane Eyre.  So, yes stylistically this film is cool and it was entertaining; however, the characters and the precarious plot ruined it for me.  The characters are rather dull, and flat, and I found it hard to attach myself to their emotions, or care about their fate.  The plot was also a letdown.  The ending seemed contrived, like the writers couldn't think of an ending so they followed the typical suit of love or death, and a lot was left unexplained.  So there you go, unfortunately a big budget doesn't seem to help screen writers pull their stories together nicely.
I bought this movie with some hesitation, I have to say.  It was really nice when I realized at the end of the movie that "Harry Potter" never crossed my mind while watching this!

I saw this movie last night.  I was slighty entertained but there wasn't anything really noteworthy about the film.
It wasn't scary at all, but I did enjoy seeing Daniel Radcliffe in a different setting.  I thought he did a good job!
The atmosphere and scenery were also done well.
Daniel Radcliffe is struggling to act in this movie. It is not scary, the plot is lame, and the ending is just dumb. Phltttt.

I spent a good deal of the time watching with my hands over my eyes. The scenes in the mansion were very creepy. I found Daniel Radcliffe to be a surprise as a grieving father, once I was able to get images of Harry Potter out of my head. It was a very mature choice following the completion of the Harry Potter series and he pulls it off rather well. It reminded me a little of The Ring. I don't want to say how and spoil the ending. Over all, a good, scary movie. This one will be on my list for Halloween movie night.

This movie was one of the best scariest movies I have seen in a good while.  Had me jumping in different areas of the movie because I was just  no expecting what happen.  I also feel they will not see this actor as Harry Potter anymore.

Though there was not much laughing or dancing there was some candles.  Yes, that was a Cher reference.  The movie however was suspenseful and entertaining.  The overall darkness lent to the overall feel of the film.  I thoroughly enjoyed it... the surprise ending was a nice touch.
The movie basically followed the book, however there were some ommisions and changes but they did not alter the story line. Acting was good. Setting was great.

I loved the movie.  I haven't been startled by horror movies in a while and I watched this on my laptop on the plane and I nearly jumped out of my seat.  Daniel Radcliffe is a good actor and sometimes I know it's hard for some to see him as other than Harry Potter but I think he did an excellent job on this film.  Ciaran Hinds is also one of my favorites.  The story is not a very complex one, that's true, but it was well played out. I also like that the ending was atypical.  This British period drama fanatic is very satisfied and I will buy this movie to add to my collection.

I've always been a fan of ghost stories and enjoyed scaring the heck out of myself when I was a kid, so it only seems natural that I would recommend this movie. This movie won't have you sitting on the edge of your chair, but it will make you jump back in your seat...At least I did anyway (a few times).  The acting is convincing, the story is entertaining, the scenes are spooky, and the characters are eerie.  I gave this movie four stars because it wasn't too clever, but the ending had an interesting twist.

This is my very first review for any product or movie on Amazon. I never write reviews, because I feel like 1 opinion won't make a difference in the long run. Despite that, this movie touched me so deeply that I just had to share my experience with those looking for an opinion.

I am an avid fan of supernatural horror. I strongly dislike slasher movies, especially since the blood and gore is often as fake as the horrible acting. Needless to say, I've pretty much seen every ghost and "haunting" movie that I could get my hands on. Because of that, I expected this to be another "run of the mill" ghost story. I will agree with some reviewers that the plot of the movie isn't revolutionary. However, the techniques and scares used in this film are a pleasant surprise.

Daniel Radcliffe truly made me connect with his character. He does an astounding job in this movie. His deep, straightforward, blue eyes add to the atmosphere of the movie. In most scenes, he is alone, but that doesn't detract from the mood of the film at all. He carries the movie to new heights with his brilliant performance.

The effects are amazing. The graphics and "old-school" techniques used for the scares here work wonders. I am not an easy scare, yet I found myself so enraptured and entranced by the tension that I was gripping the seat and biting my nails at some points. Even an hour after watching the movie, I was still remembering parts of it and rubbing my arms to get rid of my goosebumps. The only other movie that scared me this much was "The Haunting", a film that was incredible and worth watching many times over.

To the reviewers leaving such poor scores - Yes, of course everyone will react differently. Not all movies will please everyone. Some will see "fake" effects, while others don't "connect" with the characters. In the end, it's all a matter of opinion. Still, I hope that those trying to decided whether this movie is worth it or not will consider giving this film a fair chance. Just decide what sort of you person you are - are you willing to relax and put yourself in this character's shoes, or will you spend the entirety of the film looking for "fake" effects? If you are the first, then this film is definitely for you!
its an okay horror film but i felt it still had a lot to be desired but definitly not bad you should rent it

There are only a few really good "old fashioned" ghost story movies and this is the best one that's come out in a long time. Others on my list are: "A Ghost Story" (with Fred Astaire), "The Changling" (with George C. Scott), "The Lady in White", and of course, "The Others". If you like really good old-fashioned ghost stories (that aren't about blood, guts, and torture), this one is for you. I wish they would make more like this!
The movie was ok. Plot was so-so, story was same as many others I have seen. Overall I gave it a 3 because it was not a total bore.
I thought it was a good movie that keep you on the edge of you seat. I was not sure about this movie at first but gave it a try and was surprised on how good it was.

Rated R and rightfully so. Scared the heck out of me and well worth seeing if u LOVE GHOST stories. I love Ghost stories and this was very well done and full of one ghost who put me so much on edge ,I did not sleep after watching the movie.
NOT FOR anyone under age 16

Not that I'm a believer in the realm of the dead.  But I do enjoy watching the "realistic" possibilities of a paranormal event.  There is nothing that screams "GHOSTS" more than the old haunted house with spirits of the dead ingredient.  Unfortunately, too many new horror films jump into the realm of monsters rather than stick with the basic ingredient containing the spirits of dead people.  The latter gives me a more realistic feel.  I know monsters won't come through my walls, but spirits of dead people?  Well, not that I believe, but it's still way creepier since you can walk around your own house wondering about its history and who has died in it.  This movie is finally a new movie, which sticks to the "real" haunted house feel.  Sounds of footsteps, rocking chairs, dolls that seems to come to life, spooky spirits of once living people, graves, and a very old large empty house... all good ingredients.  They left Godzilla and Freddy Krueger out, which is a good thing.  Not since the Exorcist played with people's "realistic" religious images of the devil did I find a movie sticking to a person's true expectation of what is scary not only on the screen, but also off screen.  The fear jumps off the screen into your room because it sticks with the same things you would expect to see and hear should you believe your own house was haunted.  I loved it.  But it does come down to what you personally find scary: (1) A film that sticks with what you would expect if you "realistically" thought your house was haunted or (2) a film with gore, blood, and more monstrous creations.  Those expecting the latter would be disappointed, while the former would probably enjoy this.

By the way, in that reference to the Exorcist, just to clarify things, I am not comparing the two.  Nothing will probably ever compare to the original Exorcist.  I only bring it up to indicate that at least this movie is a step in the right direction to keep "haunting" movies in the realm of the spirits and paranormal (like the Exoricist) rather than always jumping into the commission of "unrealistic" monsters.
If you want to fill a hiatus in your course of living through the day, this is an entertaining movie, like an old time ghost story I give it a 4 star rate for that purpose.
If you love horror movies like me then this is the one for you. The Woman in Black will keep you on the edge of your chair.

This new version of The Woman in Black is appropriately scary! I thoroughly enjoyed it and recommend it to anyone who loves Gothic-type movies. The return of suggestion and glimpses of a ghost and not the blood & gore of so many modern-day movies make watching this a real pleasure! Wonderful atmosphere, setting, dark images, and haunting music are all in place for a scary experience. Excellent!

It's nice to have Hammer Studios back making horror films. This was the stuff I grew up on watching creature-features on Saturday afternoons with actors like Peter Cushing, Christopher Lee and Ingrid Pitt in their stable of stars, and a low-budget sensibility with a particular affinity for day-for-night shooting, busty ladies in tight corsets and pea-soup-thick atmosphere.

However, THE WOMAN IN BLACK is not quite a horror film as it is a supernatural mystery. And it sadly doesn't have the tightly-corseted ladies, but as far as atmosphere, the cup runneth over. Endless mist, sunless days, torrential rain, candlelit hallways and always something lurking in the back of the frame.

The plot of the film is very standard for a turn-of-the-20th-century haunted village story. A young widower (Radcliffe in a very mature performance) is sent on behalf of his law firm to clear up the estate of a wealthy recluse in a remote British town. The villagers in the town want him gone for unknown reasons, but he goes to the old mansion called Eel Marsh (sounds like a nice place, doesn't it?) and uncovers an unearthly presence and a mystery that has been taking the lives of children there for years. With his own child coming to visit him, he endeavors, with the help of a kindly man (the always great Ciaran Hinds) and his troubled wife (Janet McTeer, great in a small role), to give the ghost what he believes it needs to end its reign of terror.

I'm always a little leery of ghost films because the cause of the haunting is usually far too mundane and that always leaves me wishing that it's not such a mystery as to why it's happening, and rather just have it HAPPEN. It lends a greater mystery and discomfort to the viewer and leaves us to ask questions after the film ends. That was my biggest problem with Robert Zemeckis' WHAT LIES BENEATH. That's also a bit of a problem here, but because of a nicely twisted ending, we find that their solution to the mystery isn't enough.

Radcliffe really leaves Harry Potter behind in this film, and it's wonderful to see him really embrace this role. He's someone who is very wounded deep within his soul, and it makes sense that he would be more willing to explore the world of the unknown searching for answers. Hinds is once again great at a supporting role as the only man in the village who seems to be unafraid of what Radcliffe's character is doing, but there's a deeper weariness to Hinds as is revealed later. McTeer is wonderfully manic but not over-the-top loony as the still-grieving mother to a child long dead.

This film embraces mood and atmosphere in favor of blood and shock, keeping with the tradition of Hammer Studios well. There are three or four really cheap but effective jump scares in the first act, and this is honestly the first film in years that I actually did feel my heart skip at some of those moments. Once that calms down, the cheap scares make way for a sense of genuine dread, which is something director James Watkins handles pretty deftly. Most of the film is very quiet, which makes the frightening noises that come out of that quiet much more effective. He also is adept at framing his shots. Many of the moments of the film look as though they could be gothic-era paintings.

Sadly, the film becomes pretty sluggish in the third act as they feel they've found the solution to the desires of the spectre and do what they can to sate those desires. If the film had more of an adult appeal, I feel that this would have been more of a character study rather than a film of actions and consequences, but since it's Daniel Radcliffe, they had to make it more teen-friendly. I don't feel that those roles are far off at all for Radcliffe, having done a play like the extremely dark EQUUS, and they suit his seemingly perennial five-o'clock shadow and his intense and piercing eyes.

Radcliffe is a young man who, even if he hadn't been in one of the most successful franchises of all time, would still have eventually become a star, and THE WOMAN IN BLACK is decidedly good evidence of that.
Suprised how decent this movie was a good thriller. Worth a watch if you like Suspense type movies Hammer Productions is always a safe bet

Daniel was great, as usual, but after fighting the dark forces of the wizard world, this type of black hearted villain (The Woman in Black) doesn't measure up to "Harry's" standards.  The movie will keep your attention, for sure, but I would like to see Daniel in a different type of movie and in settings that don't include dark, massive, eerie places.  Not bad for his first movie after the Potter series though.

Fairly typical, formula-like, ghost-in-a-house story except that it had enough twists and surprises to keep you engaged. Usual special effects of ghostly images in the usual places (dark hallways, basement, cemetery) with appropriate sounds and music with very effective sudden scene shifts with sound to frighten the unwary viewer. Beautiful location, authentic sets and props; one of the best I've seen for this genre. Very good acting, dialogue, characterizations, editing and cinematography. Attention to detail is usually a good indicator of a well crafted movie and the studio fulfilled that obligation to the highest degree. Surprising ending  so don't read any spoilers.

In an age where the idea of horror is suppose to be one bloody gruesome scene followed by another more bloody and gruesome scene, there is a horror movie out there that relies on the old fashion way of scaring the crap out of you. With suspence and excellant film editing that will make you jump out of your seat. That movie is "The Woman In Black". It harks back to 40, 50 even 60 years ago to the golden age horror movies. I love a good horror story as much as the next person but over the last couple of decades I have found the horror movies made during this time to lack imagination and have no story or plot to it. They just try to gross out the audience with more blood and guts with every scene.

"The Woman In Black" has restored my faith that there are people out there who still remember the way to make a great horror film. I won't bother to get into the plot of the movie. There are plenty of reviews written here on Amazon that go into what the story is about. There is nothing I can add there that hasn't already been mentioned. I just want to add my 5 stars to this movie and say to all those out there who like me have longed for a good old-fashion thrilling spooky movie like the days of old but had grown cynical that such movies could even be made anymore to go see "The Woman In Black"! I am sure your faith will be restored like mine has. This is a movie I can watch again and again and not tire of it. if you're a horror movie fan too like me I bet it will be the same for you as well.

If you're like me you grew up watching horror films made by Hammer Studios. These were not your run of the mill horror films but classily made films that featured some of the classic horror icons like Dracula and Frankenstein but in more of a gothic location. This was a world of castles and mansions, of men dressed in fine clothing and women in low cut laced gowns. The horror films made by Hammer had style and class and a certain amount of eeriness to them instead of gore. The studio fell on hard times but is in the midst of a return and their first major entry is a grand one called THE WOMAN IN BLACK.

It's the turn of the century and Arthur Kipps (Daniel Radcliffe) is at his wits end. A solicitor by trade Kipps has fallen on hard times, having great difficulty in dealing with the death of his wife several years earlier during childbirth. His son has grown but Kipps' melancholia remains these years later. So much so that he's fallen on hard times. The firm he works for gives Kipps a last chance to redeem himself by sending him to the small town of Cryphin Gifford to the Eel Marsh House where the estate of Mrs. Drablow, a recently deceased woman, must be settled. Kipps heads out hoping to reunite with his son and his nanny on the weekend.

On his train ride to the town Kipps meets a gentleman by the name of Sam Daily (Ciaran Hinds). Sam is also en route to the same location and offers Kipps a ride to the local inn. But what greets Kipps when he enters is not what he expected: a cold shoulder from all but the inn keeper's wife who offers him a small room in the attic. He receives more of the same when he contacts the local solicitor who's been handling the affairs of the estate. Given the brush off and a carriage to take him to the train station, he pays the man to take him to the estate itself.

If the creepy factor weren't already oozing off the screen it does so in spades as Kipps makes his way to the estate. The mansion is located on a small island with a causeway that twists and turns up to it. All along nothing but the marsh can be seen, a gooey water trap if ever there was one, with plenty of sea beyond. The tides rise and close off the causeway throughout the day and the carriage driver agrees to return later to take Kipps to Sam's house for a dinner invitation.

Walking on to the house Kipps is greeted by the best of gothic sights, a mansion in disrepair covered with vines on the outside and cobwebs within. He lights some candles and gathers what paperwork he finds and begins working. But noises within the house cause him to stop and seek what is creating the sounds. As Kipps passes from one room to another, we have the chance to see the woman in black as her spectral image lingers over Kipps without allowing him to see her. She's everywhere yet nowhere in this house and the director of the film does a fine job in creating the atmosphere of her presence without seeing her at all times.

Kipps eventually goes to dinner at Sam's and meet's his wife. She begins to tell him things that will lead him to discover the truth behind the town's fright and the reason they want him gone. Her tale and other clues lead Kipps to find out about the sister of the Mrs. Drablow who was sent away while her son was adopted by Drablow and her husband. On a trip home one night, their carriage slid into the marsh and the boy was drowned, his body never recovered. Now when the woman in black is seen a child in the town dies.

Kipps continues his work, dealing with both the house and its foreboding inhabitant and continuing to deal with the loss of his wife. The intrusion of the woman in black in his business as well as the lives of others becomes too much and he seeks a way to appease her and put her soul to rest. This becomes all the more important as he has no way of reaching his son en route to the town to possibly be her next victim.

The movie does a wonderful job of offering us teasing scares that never go over the top. The chilling moments are found from start to finish, the locale's offering the feelings that something bad is going to happen and the acting complements the storytelling that delivers chills rather than one jump scene after another (though there are those). Best of all is seeing Radcliffe in a role other than Harry Potter, proving that there is a chance of his becoming an actor that can handle more than the namesake that brought him to attention.

The movie is one of the old time scare films that doesn't rely on gore, doesn't rely on a hatchet wielding menace or a nightmare creation that sucks out your soul as you sleep. This is good old fashioned ghost story that makes your skin crawl while you wait for the next scare and that's a good thing to see. Welcome back Hammer.

IS this one of the super scary, gory ones?  No.  It's more of the traditional kind that leaves you on the edge of your seat and anticipating what's coming next.  It is rather predictable but that doesn't lessen the enjoyment of it.  And I did enjoy it a great deal.  It didn't live up to the fully, out and out scary I think it was going for but it's good nonetheless.  Daniel Radcliffe did give a wonderful performance in it and the acting was quite good.  My only real issue is a problem that some of us older folks have; the really dark scenes (as in lighting) were hard to see and to be able tell what was going on.  Even watching during the day I had a hard time seeing what was going on in some of it.  That, most assuredly, does affect the enjoyment level of things.  I understand what they were going for with some of it and to set the mood but that doesn't help when you can't see enough of what is going on to tell what they are doing or see something they are reacting to.

Overall, though, it was a decent movie.  Far better than what Hammer usually puts out.

This movie looks pretty awesome and I'd love to see it, but I won't buy another Ultraviolet movie. Ever. Find this review not helpful? Then you're not paying attention.  Ultraviolet is a scam and that makes the item suck.  Nuff said.

The Woman in Black film version pales in comparison to the book by Susan Hill, as it not only uses typical Hollywood gimmicks to get scares, but has deficiencies that lessen the creepiness factor. The biggest problem in the film is that everything is obvious, blatant and upfront, given to us in the initial stages of the film on a silver platter so we know what to expect. There's little in the way of true build up to give any heightened suspense; they just kind of rush Kipps (played by Daniel Radcliffe) to the house as soon as possible, and then the residents and locals try to rush him out of the house. Another problem is simply that we don't quite get into the head of Kipps as much in the film. Seeing things from his perspective as he sees them--as he slowly realizes the history of the house and the woman-- makes the novel much more effectively atmospheric, something not accomplished as well in this film. There are a few scares scattered a few places, and the story does come into focus aptly in the second part, especially as he finds out the woman's history, but mainly this film just felt too rushed and lacks any subtlety. I think you are better off checking out the other version of The Woman in Black, Woman in Black. That is, renting it, as the sellers are asking outrageous prices for that version.

It is rare to find a true horror picture without all the "slash-n-gash" of so many today.  It is ever rarer to find a horror picture that will give me goosebumps.  Add those two to Daniel Radcliffe and a sure fire winner has been made.

This movie had my husband and myself spellbound from the get-go.  The spooky setting, the period piece, it was all well done.  The acting was superb.  The entire movie was very intense, but I advise you not to watch it alone.  We did a second viewing a week later, and it still gave us goosebumps, and we watch many horror/ghost stories.  The ending was wonderful, it....well, you'll just have to watch it and see for yourself.

This film captures a similar effect as Shirley Jackson's "The Haunting" and the "The Inocents" based on Oscar Wildes' "Turn of the Screw". It does drag a
little in the middle but the cast performances are solid and the tension is great all the way to a surprise like ending. Loved it.

Lots of sluggish background noise.  Arthur Kipps (Daniel Radcliffe) is sent on a mission to a foreign village (The Causeway to Osea Island, Maldon, Essex, England.) Never mind that it is the same scene from Dracula when they toss John Harker to the vamps. The screen writer was thinking more of the apocalypse now mission. He is to wrap-up the paperwork of a deceased client of the firm. Little did he know that he was going to suffer (along with us) a series of "things that go bump in the night?" and Lots of sluggish background noise.  The native rabble at least did not carry torches and hunt him down. Soon he takes the threat personal.

In association with Hammer Films, Who would have guessed?

"Good Lord deliver us" from this film

I really enjoyed The Woman in Black. It didn't use excessive gore or violence to scare me. Instead, The Woman in Black builds tension through creepy imagery and mixes it with jump-out scares. The scares are so well balanced! There is a segment in the film that will have scare after scare. The creepy atmosphere was also great. Acting was fine and so was the music. The only problem I had was the predictable third act/ending; I felt like I had seen it done many times before.

Overall, this spooky film is highly recommended.

I love scary movies. The problem is hardly any scary movies are made any more. Slasher flicks, torture flicks, gross flicks, stupid moronic flicks, yes. Genuinely creepy, scary flicks, no. The Woman in Black is a genuinely creepy movie. It has great atmosphere and subtle creeps that build into a goosepimple-inducing conclusion. I love that some of the scares are so subtle that, if you're not paying attention, you may miss them. I'm 48 and, if I think about this movie too much before going to bed, I have to leave the light on for awhile until I quit thinking about it because it creeps me out. I know some people don't like the limited dialogue but, since Arthur Kipps (Daniel Radcliffe's character)spends much of his time at Eel Marsh House alone, limited dialogue is logical. I'd think it strange if he wandered around spewing  a constant monologue (just because I talk to MYself, doesn't mean NORMAL people do.) Also the dialogue isn't needed or missed, as everything is explained if you pay attention. Even without the extensive dialogue, Daniel Radcliffe does a wonderful job of projecting his character's loneliness, heartbreak, and growing worry that he's losing his grip on his sanity. The very last shot before the credits gave me the shivers. I LOVE the shivers! Great, great movie.

A film can never make everyone happy, let alone a horror one. Some like jump scares while others don't and think that they are ridiculous. I'm someone who really enjoys them! This movie had me on the edge of my seat for a large majority of the movie! Especially when -spoiler alert- Arthur goes into the marsh to retrieve Nathaniel's corpse and then when he's trying to summon the Woman in Black. I got a big jump out of what happens next. That one scene, along with the window scene, left a big impression on me. -Spoilers over-

Daniel Radcliffe's acting was excellent! I say that it was a step forward from his Harry Potter roles. While others say that he was emotionless, I disagree. I thought that his face conveyed enough emotion to sum up the suspense. I rarely thought of Harry Potter in this movie, but one of my friends did. He screamed "Use your wand, Potter!" during the summoning scene.

Anyway, most "Horror" films rely on blood spraying every five seconds such as Scream. I think that this movie is a good sign for horror films, and I hope more scary movies like this come out.

There can be too many "boo!" moments in a film, I realized as I watched "The Woman In Black." A "boo!" moment, of course, is when the camera pans across a room and, just for a second, we see a demon watching our hero (in this case, Daniel Radcliffe), or, the camera lingers upon an object (a window, say) while our hero looks outside, and then...a face appears in the window next to him! Noooo!

Save for these moments (and there are a lot of them), "The Woman In Black" is a quiet, effective ghost story set in Victorian England. A woman with a secret past dies, and leaves a mansion behind that must have been built by architects related to H. R. Giger. Needless to say, the mansion is haunted, and poor Daniel Radcliffe, besot by financial problems, must try his darndest to sell it so that he can make a life for his son, even as the local villagers give him the evil eye for daring to step foot in the mansion. Why one of these villagers never simply runs up to him and says, "There's a crazy ghost-witch in that house and she does awful things to people when you go into her house!" I'll never know, but instead they hang back and scowl at Radcliffe's character as he just tries to go about his day.

If it all sounds rather generic, well, it is. But the movie, crafted by a reboot of the old Hammer Films Studio, is technically well-done and written competently enough to create a decent experience out of an overdone genre. There are too many "boo!" moments, yes, but the overall mood of the film is rather somber and creepy. The set design is great, and the clattering little tinker toys that fill up the mansion shelves are among the most horrid toys I've ever seen in my life. The plot moves smoothly and never gets bogged down in unnecessary exposition or bloated pretension. The movie knows what it wants to be. It is a haunted house movie, through and through, and while that lack of ambition makes it somewhat mundane, it also ensures that the movie never overstays its welcome. There's a horrible mansion, a cruel ghost, and an awful secret, and that is as far as the narrative extends. Radcliffe is likable, the ghost is appropriately furious, and the ending, while obvious, doesn't cheat.

All in all, a competent piece of genre fiction that will entertain you and then quickly fade from your memory. You could do much worse.

The only good review I have about this movie is that Daniel Radcliff was great in it. He nailed the character!! As for the movie itself, it was a disappointment. Too many "scare tactics" to appeal to a younger audience. If the movie would have stayed true to the book, it whould have been much better.

I rented this movie from Redbox because the trailer had looked interesting. The acting and premise of the movie were promising, but the story seemed underdeveloped. Daniel Radcliff ventures to a mysterious small town where the people seem to want to get rid of him as quickly as possible. We learn this is because of a local superstition that results in the death of the town's children. Sounds interesting enough, but the story tends to drag, and there isn't really anything to differentiate this movie from others in the genre. Throughout the movie we see similar sequences played over and over--a good portion of the movie is just Radcliff walking around a house.

The story falls short and does nothing to invigorate an already stale genre. This movie is worth a rent at best, which is unfortunate because I was looking forward to seeing Radcliff in a new role.

The atmosphere infusing every scene and setting for "The Woman in Black" is so heavy, unrelenting, and smothering, that it is hard to just watch the movie or delve into the story. I've never seen a film that so unrelentingly reminds its audience of its intention through such a thick slathering of motif, artifice, lighting, and gloom.

Yes, this is a ghost story, a horror tale that should be frightening. There are long hallway shots in the haunted mansion that mimic Kubrick's corridors in that mammoth hotel in The Shining, shots that should build even more dread and anticipation than they do. The rooms are filled with so many oddities and antiques (someone really had a thing about monkeys, perhaps a homage to those flying terrors from the "Wizard of Oz") that these inanimate curiosities stole the scenes from the actors.

The actors---chiefly the male leads, Daniel Radcliffe and Ciarán Hinds---all seem to be walking through the sets as though they had been dropped into a carnival fun house and left to improvise reactions and lines. The ghostly woman in black startles more than she frightens, and most of the remaining characters seem stricken with dread and grief, making one wonder why they did not leave this dreadful place.

The plot trajectory, alas, moved in a straightforward, if slow, line to the inevitable conclusion, which suggests that the studio was more interested in potential sequels than telling a good story the first time out.

James Watkins' "The Woman In Black" is a superb, bone-chilling return to the freezy tradition of Hammer Studios. Daniel Radcliffe (of "Harry Potter" fame) turns in a fine performance as London lawyer Arthur Kipps. An impoverished father haunted by the loss of his wife during childbirth, his employer gives him a make-or-break assignment by sending him to the remote village of Cryphin Gifford to examine the documentation of the Eel Marsh House that belonged to the recently deceased Mrs. Drablow. Mrs. Drawblow was a disturbed woman. Her child was lost tragically, not unlike the protagonists', by drowning in a marsh. The locals are particularly unreceptive to Mr. Kipps' presence and he is shunned by all but one man, determined to help him see the job through. The pacing and atmosphere of this movie are damn near perfect. Reminiscent of much of Hammer's later work (From Beyond the Grave), the cobwebs and impoverished area add to the suspense. What really clinched it for me were the scenes in which Kipps is alone in Mrs. Drablow's house and reads her letters, the scary voice overdubbing and the creepy puppets moving all at the same time. One thinks of a malevolent Emily Dickinson or something, it's just really fantastic. The only problem I had was with the ending. While I won't spoil it for anyone, they should have let it happen raw without the fluffernutter. That said, this is recommended for anyone who still cherishes Hammer's legacy, and just a fantastic horror film amongst the dross.

Eureka!!!  Finally a modern day Horror film which discards CGI as an overwhelming crutch and goes for the jugular as Director James Watkins updates Writer Susan Hill's chilling ghost story 'THE WOMAN IN BLACK' and shows how true Horror films have been sorely missed over the past few decades.  The gothic Horror tale has long since been left in the dust by the supposed chillers of hacks such as Wes Craven , M. Night Shayamalan, Rob Zombie , to name but a few. With cheap tricks, gore effects,and screenplays which seem to succeed with modern audiences , none have even touched the terrifying sequences within this film.  Yes, they have their fans and supporters but they wouldn't know true Horror if it bit them where the sun don't shine.  Mr. Watkins, however, has done his homework by creating a beautifully chilling nightmare with such incredible atmosphere, you can feel the mist and fog come right through the monitor.  Daniel Radcliffe, who was criticized as being too young for the role, is excellent and Ciaran Hinds lends great support as Director Watkins glides his camera through an absolutely terrifying encounter with a haunted mansion. With a bone chilling score by Marco Beltrami and superior cinematography by Tim Maurice-Jones, this is a film that truly lives up to the cliche, 'Don't watch it alone'.  I happened to view this film with at least four other Horror fans who have seen countless ghost films over the years and I counted no fewer than 8 times that they jumped right out of their skins, something modern day Horror tries to emulate but never succeed.  The film is released by Hammer Films of England who were responsible for a literal Horror renaissance beginning in the mid fifties and lasting to the early seventies but not even those photoplays have the class of this true Horror masterpiece.  If you love the films of Val Lewton and think that the champion of all ghost stories, Director Robert Wise's 'THE HAUNTING'- 1963 is the definitive haunted house thriller , you will be surprised. If ever a film was perfect for the Blu-Ray format, this is it as Sony releases it in a beautiful 2.35 transfer with jaw dropping 5.1 DTS sound.  Ignore the negative reviews that many gave to this film and experience a truly terrifying tone poem, one that the 'PARANORMAL ACTIVITY' films try to succeed at but ultimately fail.

Being a fan of the less blood-more story gothic thriller, I picked up a copy with not a lot of expectation.  It simply seemed a little too hyped in my area.  However, I was quite pleasantly surprised and happily put it (once viewed) on the top shelf alongside similar vein movies such as "The Others", Half Light", my myriad Hitchcock gleanings... I agree with some of the other esteemed reviews in that there is no sense of "Harry Potter" in Mr. Radcliffe's performance and he does a perfect job is "being" Arthur Kipps.  This movie has stayed with me and it has prompted me to read the novel, even if it and the movie likely do not follow so closely.

It is indeed a "spine-tingling tale" and well worth adding it to your collection, in my humble but particular opinion.
I expected more. It was just ok. I am glad I saw it was a low key horror. Not something that kept you on the edge of your seat.

This isn't a particularly original or innovative movie, just a good old fashioned ghost story which has you wondering if you saw what you thought you did. The location is superb and the filming is atmospheric. There is a little bit of gore, but for the most part the thrills are of the 'what's going to happen next' type.

I'm a little surprised that so many reviews comment on Daniel Radcliffe as though he is a revelation in this movie. He was an accomplished child actor before Harry Potter and has done a number of things during and since the Potter films. He's a thorough professional and in this movie he needs to be, since he is in practically every scene.

This is a good creepy movie for those who like mind games rather than more obvious horror.

I read through many of the reviews until I found one I totally agrees with -Viewer (USA)- the movie does not really follow the book at all, but I sat through th show waiting for the ending, which to me made the book worh reading more than once. The true ending (book) is unsettling, unexpected and creepy as I imagine the author intended. This movie is a watered down version of the book. Now I remember why I don't go to see movies based on  books I enjoyed; they are not up to the written word.

The storyline for the movie was awesome, but the ending was horrible. Very impressed with Daniel Radcliffe. Thought I'd see him as Harry Potter throughout the movie,but his acting was very good that it made his character very believable. Awesome movie,but hated the ending.

I purchased this item from Amazon.  Reviewer Linda Pagliuco says it very well. Yes, there is the creepy house -- very well done  -- excellent lighting, or rather, non-lighting. The Gothic theme played to the hilt. But it seems like there is very little acting for Daniel Radcliffe to actually do. Yes, his Arthur character is brave to the point of being foolhardy. And Radcliffe plays the part well. But there doesn't seem to be much to it. I bought it mainly to see him, but I also wish to give credit to the other actors. Ciaren Hinds especially is very sympathetic and I like the job he did. But I still was underwhelmed with the story as a whole.  Finally, I was dissatisfied with the ending -- too awful in some ways, too "Hollywood" in others.

When reading my movie review, I'd like you to please consider the perspective of an individual who has seen many films in his life - most especially the horror genre has always fascinated me since I was 7-8 years old. There is nothing like the exhilarating feeling of a good scare whether you are watching a serial killer storyline unfold or a supernatural narrative take place. Having had the rare pleasure, but more often the discontentment, of having viewed many a Horror movie, I have instinctively learned to anticipate the plot of a story or predict the scenes. It isn't only that I've seen so many films with a similar scheme, but rather that there a lot of film studios that are only interested in making a profit and fail to make a good effort at hiring decent screenwriters, cinematographers, directors and so on. After all, it is a business and financing films for a profit is worthy of concern.

I'll end this involuntary history lesson by briefly acknowledging the return of Hammer films as producers of The Woman In Black - since the 1930's, Hammer has come to be known as a well-respected institution. Imitation being the highest compliment possible, other film studios began adopting a `Hammer formula' and churned out films like there was no tomorrow, unconsciously causing Hammer to collapse and shut down amidst the sea of Hammer "wanna be's". Marking Hammer's return to film from its deep slumber is the gothic supernatural thriller The Woman In Black.

I would like to echo what has been already stated about the film - disturbingly moody, palpable environment, eerie soundtrack, etc. but also offer a comparison between The Woman In Black and The Changeling. No, not the Angelina Jolie movie, but the George C. Scott film from 1980. The most striking aspect of these 2 films is the obvious fact that both Radcliffe and Scott play widowers males still grieving over the loss of a loved one. What follows is the collapse of rational thinking through a fractured emotional state of being into the belief of an afterlife and everything that comes with that notion. Both films allow the suspense and scares to build to a crescendo instead of implementing scenes of gore or devices of carnage. Both characters become infatuated, almost to the point of being spellbound, by the mysterious goings-on respectively but whereas Scott is adept at allowing the physical and emotional out pour to connect visually, Radcliffe is only capable at portraying a sense of melancholy. Even at the end of the film, he seems slightly impassive and misses an optimal opportunity to come about full circle with the destiny of his life via his actions.

Bottom Line: There is plenty to like about The Woman In Black and if you go into it armed with patience (the action unfolds slow but deliberate), the firm awareness that Radcliffe will not be portraying his trademark wizard boy alter ego, and a firm acceptance that horror can be defined in many varied ways (that includes Justin Bieber's music), then you will be handsomely rewarded with a clever, well fashioned film. Radcliffe has done well and I'm confident he will find his footing in the world before too long, but special note that bears mentioning is Ciarn Hinds who is in great form as Radcliffe's new friend in town.

I like horror movies, but it seems like most horror movies these days are really slasher films.  The more blood and guts, the better.  The Woman in Black doesn't follow this formula and it is most appreciated.

Mr. Kipps (Daniel Radcliffe) is a young attorney sent to a small rural town with only one objective: close out the account of a recently deceased widow.  When he arrives in town, people treat him coldly and you are left wondering why.  Only one man (the most wonderfully talented Ciaran Hinds) offers to help him while he attempts to gather documentation at the widow's house.

Soon after he arrives, children in the local town start dying.  Not only are they dying, they are committing suicide in the most horrible ways.  Does it have some connection with a woman in black seen at the old house?  Of course!

The story is a little slower than most thrillers but it all comes together in the end and there are plenty opportunities to jump out of your skin.  The director goes for psychological scares instead of gruesome kills and it's totally worth it.  Excellent story, excellent cast.

I really enjoyed this film. The ambiance was eerie and beautifully crafted.
The acting was well done and subtle. So nice for a change to embrace the silence
of a space and let that be a force unto itself. Loved that choice by the director in
this day of sound tracks over running a film.
This is a marvelous gothic tale. Loved it!

I watched the 2012 version of The Woman in Black after first watching the one from the 80's. In the 2012 film, the storyline is superb. It made sense, details and background were all covered and the ending couldn't have been better. This version of the film had more ghostly images throughout, doors opening and closing (why is that so terrifying?!) and a real sense of mystery. Daniel Radcliffe's performance was without a doubt admirable and after the first 10 minutes, I actually forgot about that whole Harry Potter thing...hehe.

Before watching this film, I heard many people overly criticize Daniel Radcliff's performance, these comments coming mainly from those who were die hard Harry Potter fans who were saddened by the end of the franchise.  I, for one, enjoyed Harry Potter, but loved that Daniel Radcliff was so easily able to come out of the roll of HP and play Arthur so beautifully, he is definitely a true talent and I look forward to seeing his later works.  As per Woman in Black, we have a classic haunting story, with far more twists and turns as the haunting is not isolated to the single location or family, the involvement is deeper, this is not just about the bumps in the night.  The location and era were very well done, the entire cast, and character development was believable.  The "lulls" in the film are not drawn out time killers, but if you pay attention, they are clues to the characters and what is to come, making them, to me, interesting.  I found the film to be excellent, especially in a time where the best box office films have included unrealistic craziness such as Saw and Paranormal Activity films.  The only reason I have chosen 4 and not 5 stars is because I felt the film could have been longer and added more to the back story of the family, and maybe more to the ending, even.  But all in all, I would give Woman in Black an 7.5/10.

Forget that it's Daniel Radcliff...even if he does deliver a fine performance.

Get past that.

It's the story.

A young lawyer, severely depressed since the death of his young bride during childbirth, is given a last chance to succeed at his job. He is to settle the affairs of a deceased wealthy widow near a remote coastal village.

Upon arrival in the village he is greeted with disdain and is made most unwelcome.

It would seem that the widow's house is believed to be haunted and the villagers don't want him stirring up problems for them.

Set in the Edwardian era, this film is full of great Hammer Films atmosphere: fog, cool colors, damp, excellent sets and costumes.

You will not find a single four letter word, no nudity and no double entendres, but you will find it full of chills and spooky goings on.

While the ending of the film is ultimately a bit derivative, everything leading up to it is edge of your seat British classic horror.

I highly recommend it!

This was not a perfect movie. The pacing was odd with a very slow drawn out beginning and an all too abbreviated finish. Almost as if the director decided the he needed to wrap the movie up quickly after some point. There was much that could have been done to prolong the suspense and foreshadow the conclusions. The ending had a slight Disneyesque feel to it that I didn't like. I almost expected animated birds to pop out singing.
That said this is a movie worth watching (but not alone). I do not get frightened very easily but this movie scared me to pieces. Daniel Radcliffe was very much able to step beyond Harry Potter in this movie and I am impressed by that. His facial expressions, vocal tone, and responses were very unique to the character and allowed him to become immersed in the role. C. Hinds is an outstanding actor and does a fabulous job here too. I would recommend this movie to anyone but it could be too intense for smaller children. Also because children are the victims in this movie it could be traumatizing  to younger viewers.

Daniel Radcliffe has shed his Harry Potter persona in this scary victorian-era thriller.

Radcliffe stars as Arthur Kipps, a lawyer who has recently lost his wife during childbirth.  Kipps has been given one last chance to prove his worth to his employer.  He is assigned to travel to Crythin Gifford to resolve the affairs of a recently deceased woman.  Upon arriving, Kipps receives a chilling response from the townspeople, except for Sam (Ciaran Hinds).

Journeying to the remote mansion located deep in the marshes, Kipps begins to uncover a gruesome tale of death as well as the mysterious "Woman in Black".  Many of village's children have died, and each time, the mysterious woman has been present.  While in the mansion, Kipps has seen ghostly apparitions and heard mysterious noises.  Soon, Kipps is engulfed in a terrifying quest to discover the truth about the deaths of the children while trying to unlock the mystery of the woman in black.

I thought this was a good movie, but I did have some difficulty following it in certain parts.  Radcliffe and Hinds give good performances, and there are some very scary scenes, but there were parts where I couldn't follow along.  I originally saw this movie in the theater and I was hoping that by watching it on DVD, I would get more clarity.  I was able to pick more up by watching it on DVD, but there were still parts that left me confused.  However, there are some very scary parts in the movie, and the story is good.  I recommend this movie, but just be prepared to watch closely.

Daniel Radcliffe was terrific as Arthur Kipps a Lawyer given a last chance from his employer to keep his job. Arthur Kipps lost his wife during child-birth of their son 4 years ago, he is still grieving for her and has been down on his luck ever since. He is to get the paperwork of the recently deceased Mrs. Drablow of Eel Marsh House sorted and look to see if she made a will. But when he gets to the village of Cryphin Gifford his reception is anything but pleasant or welcoming. Lucky for Arthur Kipps he befriended Mr Daily on the train who gives him a ride to the Inn. As Arthur moves around the village children are pulled into houses, doors and windows are shut and curtains drawn. Where ever he goes people want him to leave and when he finally gets to Eel Marsh House the gloomy and very spooky house is haunted by the vengeful ghost of a woman that is dressed in black. The more time he spends at Eel Marshy House the more afraid the villagers and Arthur Kipps become. The longer he stays the more fearful the villagers get and the more accidents claim their children. This movie is one that will scare you out of your seats, the atmosphear builds and builds and releases to make you jump and scream. I loved this movie and the ending is one that surprized me. This is a movie that will not dissapoint you. The Woman in Black (+ UltraViolet Digital Copy)
This movie was surprisingly good. I was not sure how Daniel Radcliff would transition from Harry Potter to this role.

This movie had its moments. Tense. Moody. Creepy. Decent acting, a decent plot, a decent ending...but overall, this film was mediocre. For horror fans, it's worth a watch, but this film is like many of the cookie cutter horror films that have become the norm these days. I don't see myself adding "The Woman in Black" to my collection.

I love horror movies, particularly supernatural horror movies, but I wish that a review would have warned me about the on-screen child murders.  At about eight plus another tragic accident, this movie grossly exceeded my limit.  It was even worse for my husband.  Be warned.

The movie was good as ghost stories go.  Gets you jumping a little and gives you the creeps a little but for die hard scary movie fans maybe not so much.  Story line is slow to become to clear, not a bad thing, but is still unclear.  The solution seems to come to easy.  As for Daniel he does a good job with facial expressions but dialog is thin and makes wonder if he could act in a speaking part.  Overall it's OK but needed a little more meat on the bone.

Went into this with blind expectations and came out about as scared as I could be as a grown as* man.
Great scary movie.

Only the very beginning got my attention, after that with the film's minimal dialogue, very sloooow pace, unsuspenseful direction, and the annoying
time-consuming camera shots of Radcliffe's expressionless face. (See the photo of the DVD, that's the face he holds throughout the movie, except when he speaks) No scares, no suspense, no connection to characters.  One of the most boring ghost movies I have ever spent time viewing (result=dozing off).

I usually like somewhat dark movies, but this was definitely not one of my favorites.  The movie seemed to go for screaming in your face type scares instead of trying to be a deeper psychological thriller.  It had the makings of a good movie, but the scares were too heavy handed and not thought provoking.  This reminded me of going to a carnival haunted house.  Not really my thing.

I wanted to like this movie, but.... I feel Radcliff was a poor choice for the grieving widower. He seemed unemotional and unafraid which did nothing for the character in the movie. I loved him in the Harry Potter/Lord of the Ring movies. I think he could be a good actor but not in this part. The flashbacks to the character's lost wife should have brought a tear or two to his eye but nothing but a blank stare each time. The scenery was gloomy, the house pretty scary, the idea of the waters covering the road gave the house a creepy air of isolation. The scared villagers were somewhat interesting but weren't enough to make it a good movie. I love a good horror mystery but this was not as scary as advertised.

This movie almost put me to sleep from the beginning.  It builds up as a great thriller only to let down as a non-horror/thriller.  They could have further developed the plot, characters and made it much scarier that it is.  Plus the ending is horrible!  Save your money and wait for this to come to TV!

The wife and I watched this movie over the weekend, my thoughts.... there were a few good moments, the acting was sub-par at best, I kept seeing Daniel Radcliffe and thinking to myself it's Harry Potter. I can say without feeling bad this is one of those movies you can watch once and not hate yourself after.

I thought that all I would see was Harry Potter, but was surprised that Daniel Radcliff pulled off a role of grieving father and curious laywer.  This movie had all the makings of a good suspenseful horror movie. Not one that was gruesome, one that had plot twists and good character development and amazing scenery and costumes (I want that house).  This was the best horror movie I've seen in a while!

I'll admit I watched this movie to see how Daniel would perform. He was very believable in character.  The movie is your typical "period" supernatural thriller. I enjoyed it, as it was very well acted and the plot kept my attention.

This movie was well made and I thought Daniel Radcliffe done a wonderful job with this. Which he has done lots in theatrical since Harry Potter but I have not seen anything but this. I really thought the movie was thought out well it is based on a book and I loved the ending. It was suspensful and was not what you would say scarey by no means but creepy. I knew I had to see it when my son walked in after watching with his mouth open and could not say anything. I like the time period which I am guessing is 1918-1919 not sure though. The house is beautiful propes were great and Daniel done an awesome job and was no Harry Potter, He played his part and he played it well. I think this one is definatly worth you time to check out.

I usually Love Daniel Radcliffe, and his movies are always very good, but this one was not on the "Good List". I was very disappointed with this movie. I tried to make good out of a bad situation, but for me, this was a miss. The movie had a few startling moments, but that was it. I found the story line interesting, but the movie was very boring in my taste.

Beautifully filmed and well acted -- the entire cast works very hard to sell this story -- but you never feel connected to any of the characters and the story is ridiculously bad. Save your time and watch something -- anything -- else.

This was such a disappointment.  On the upside, there were a couple of good scares, but you sure had to wait for them, and the costuming, location and sets were spectacular and absolutely appropriate for the era.  Otherwise is was really long and dull.  Way too many gloomy stares and pregnant pauses.  I was expecting something with a bit more pizzaz and excitement, but there was none.

We enjoyed the movie when it came out and was excited to get the DVD.  When I saw you also received a digital copy, I thought great I can watch it on my portable devices.  Unfortunately, the service you have to use is Sony's Ultraviolet download service.  After installing their downloader and attempting to download the digital copy, I was met with your DRM settings in Silverlight were not correct.  After checking the setting in Silverlight and they were correct, I tried uninstalling the downloader and re-installing it.  Still same error message.  So I contacted Sony's service group who told me to uninstall both Silverlight and their downloader and re-install them.  After doing that and receiving the same error, they suggesting uninstalling both, reboot machine, re-install, reboot, and then it should work.  After doing that and receiving the same error, I sent them a response that it didn't work and I wasn't happy.  So they sent me a reply that basically started the help process all over again.  So after many uninstalls and re-install with many reboots scattered about, I still do not have my digital copy.  Thank you Sony for a useless online experience.

I'm sorry, after Harry Potter, this guy has no acting career. He's absolutely terrible in this movie. He's basically playing himself in a bad mood after a bad meal at a restaurant. You get the impression, like any movie Channing Tatum also is in, that the film would be better with a different actor. Whereas Robert Pattinson was amazing in Water For Elephants and proved he wasn't just another teen heartthrob with no acting ability, Radcliffe looks spoiled and frustrated in this film. He just doesn't have what it takes to be an actor, nor the desire, it seems. I would never watch another movie with him as the lead.

Definitely not Harry Potter. Even if you think you've seen a movie just like this you haven't.  Its old school but with eerie touches that keep you engaged.  The atmosphere of the movie sets the stage and becomes a character in the film.  There are frights aplenty but not in the way you would expect.  The director builds suspense quickly in the movie and doesn't let go.  He masterfully scares you with what you think you see, what you see and what you don't.

Four stars because it did drag on a bit, but the acting was flawless and the suspense was palpable. Even my dog was at the edge of his seat. They actually managed to surprise us with the ending, something rare these days. I give it a double thumbs up, but be prepared to be scared out of your wits.

Not a big fan of horror movies but did enjoy this one since it was in the tradition of "Turn of the Screw".  I like the Victorian style ghost story that takes its time in presenting the plot and characters.  This film had nice sets and great costumes.  Also loved the ending.  If you are a fan of modern horror this will probably not be your cup of tea.  If you like your James then you will probably like this film.

This movie was better than I was expecting. It had some very creepy moments and gave me chills. It has a very old skool gothic look. Daniel Radcliffe stars as Arthur Kipps, a young lawyer in charge handle the estate of Alice Drablow. After he arrives, eery things begin to happen and ghosts begin to appear. If you like gothic haunted house stories, you'll like THE WOMAN IN BLACK!!!

I don't really like horror movies. I find them generally predictable and kind of stupid. Plus the gore in most modern horror does nothing for.

The Woman In Black, however, is an old fashioned ghost story. And much better for it. It also relies very heavily on a single actor. In this case Daniel Radcliffe.

This is the first time I've seen anything other than the Harry Potter movies and it is a little difficult to move past that image of him. Indeed at one point I found myself wondering where his glasses were, before realizing he didn't have any. But his understated performance was perfect for the role and he was able to capture my attention for the large portions of the film where he was the only character on screen.

As I mentioned this is an old fashioned sort of ghost story. And it moves at an old fashioned pace that may not be to everyone's tastes. I loved the slow build up though.

There are a lot of ghost story tropes here. Faces in windows; dogs barking; unwelcoming villagers. Some may say it's unoriginal I suppose. I think of it more as using the familiar elements to build suspense and fear. The movie is particularly good at giving you moments of quiet and then making you jump. Which is exactly what a film like this should do.

I'd say this one is a definite watch.
I have not seen the original or the stage version but the story line was great!  Definitely watch it alone and in the dark.

Read the various reviews here on Amazon and you'll find that, for the most part, people were either very impressed or incredibly bored with THE WOMAN IN BLACK. Put me in the former category for I love a good ghost story and there are way too few of them these days especially in the movies. THE WOMAN IN BLACK does exactly what it sets out to do, give Daniel Radcliffe an adult post-HARRY POTTER role and craft (that word is key to the proceedings) an old school Victorian style ghost story in the tradition of M. R. James (if you don't know the name, Google him. It will explain a lot).

I have never read Susan Hill's book nor been able to jet over to London to see the long running play but I do have the 1989 TV-Movie that was adapted by Nigel Kneale (of QUATERMASS fame) on VHS. That version stars Adrian Rawlings who, ironically, would play Harry Potter's father James in the HP movies. I liked that version very much but have read elsewhere that the author didn't care for it. Apparently there are wholesale changes in that version including giving the characters different names. It was well done for a TV film with one very effective jump-out-of-your-skin moment.

Back to this newest incarnation which is a co-production of the recently revived Hammer Films whose earler efforts (THE RESIDENT, WAKE WOOD, LET ME IN) have met with limited success.
