This WOMAN IN BLACK restores the characters' names and is apparently closer to what the author intended as she has given this version her blessing. However it too has its own share of differences including changing the central character into a widower with a young son and beefing up a character (Janet McTeer) who somehow has a link to the beyond.

For those of you unfamiliar with the plot of the film, here it is. Young solicitor Arthur Kipps (Radcliffe), whose wife died giving birth, is sent to a remote English village to tidy up the affairs of a recently deceased woman. Once there he is greeted with hostility by the locals and is befriended by the local squire (Ciarin Hinds). Staying in the decaying house that was her home, he is subject to strange sounds and visions that include a woman in mourning and a number of dead children. These are the children of the villagers who are systematically being driven to kill themselves by this woman. After arriving at a solution Kipps hopes to implement it and stop the strange goings on.

Director James Watkins and screenwriter Jane Goldman have carefully crafted an old school ghost story with all the classic elements. There are sudden sounds, quick cuts, and an effective music score that help to deliver some genuine shocks. There is even a lengthy sequence in the middle of the film that runs for half an hour without any dialogue which will either have you on the edge of your seat or will put you to sleep depending on how you respond to it. After you have watched the film, watch it again with Watkins' and Goldman's bonus commentary and you can see exactly how well crafted the film is. The performances by all concerned, not just the principals, are all first rate and this only adds to the overall impact.

The one sequence of the film that I didn't like is the ending. I won't give it away but it forgoes the central element of the Victorian ghost story and that is the power of redemption. Once the wrong has been righted, the results should have been different. It is possible to interpret the ending as a thank you gift of sorts but in the commentary the filmmakers state what they intended and it is that which I disagree with. Nevertheless I found THE WOMAN IN BLACK to be top drawer entertainment and I plan to return to it on several occasions. It can take its place along with THE HAUNTING (1963), THE CHANGELING (1979 - George C. Scott not Angelina), and THE OTHERS (2001) as one of the handful of great cinematic ghost story adaptations.

This is the second cinematic adaptation of Susan Hill's novel of the same name (the last was made in 1989), this one written for the screen by Jane Goldman and directed by James Watkins. As with many British ghost stories (termed Horror, Drama, Thriller by the press) the themes remain the same - just the locales and the names of the characters change. Not that that is a bad thing, but it is nothing novel and if such stories are your cup of tea - shadowy images in darkened house windows, incidental dead children, a suspicious group of townspeople, a lots of candles flickering out because of mysterious doors opening and closing at will - then this incarnation will please. There is very little dialogue and very little character development, but the locations are magnificent, the cinematography is glorious (Tim Maurice Jones) and the musical score (Marco Beltrami) is chilling. THE WOMAN IN BLACK is an elegantly creepy, atmospheric, British period style ghost story.

When a friendless old widow dies in the seaside town of Crythin, young solicitor Arthur Krips (Daniel Radcliffe), who lives with his four-year old son Joseph (Misha Handley) - Arthur's wife Stella (Sophie Stuckey) died in childbirth) - and Joseph's Nanny (Jessica Raine), is sent by his firm to settle the estate. Arthur finds the townspeople reluctant to talk about or go near the woman's dreary home and no one will explain or even acknowledge the fact that he inadvertently incurs the wrath of a malevolent spirit, the woman in black. She is no filmy, gauzy wraith, but a solid black silhouette of malice and evil. The viewer only sees her a few times, but you feel her malevolent presence in every frame. Ignoring the towns-people's cryptic warnings (they are trying to conceal a deadly secret), he goes to the house where he discovers its horrible history and becomes ensnared in its even more horrible legacy.

Along the way Arthur is befriended by Dailey (Ciarán Hinds) and his strange insane wife (Janet McTeer) and Dailey is the only man willing to transport Arthur across the tide covered marshes to the haunted estate. The story is basically dealing with life after death - in the person of ghosts who stay around to wreck vengeance for their deaths - and the many events that suggest that indeed there is a place after death is borne out by story's strange ending.

Daniel Radcliffe manages to carry his role well (the designers keep him with a fashionable 5 o'clock shadow to prove he has outgrown Harry Potter) and the subordinate cast is strong in the miniscule parts they are given. This is a mood piece, a ghost story of the old-fashioned sort, and it doesn't pretend to be otherwise. You either like these films or you don't. Grady Harp, May 12

This is the second cinematic adaptation of Susan Hill's novel of the same name (the last was made in 1989), this one written for the screen by Jane Goldman and directed by James Watkins. As with many British ghost stories (termed Horror, Drama, Thriller by the press) the themes remain the same - just the locales and the names of the characters change. Not that that is a bad thing, but it is nothing novel and if such stories are your cup of tea - shadowy images in darkened house windows, incidental dead children, a suspicious group of townspeople, a lots of candles flickering out because of mysterious doors opening and closing at will - then this incarnation will please.  There is very little dialogue and very little character development, but the locations are magnificent, the cinematography is glorious (Tim Maurice Jones) and the musical score (Marco Beltrami) is chilling. THE WOMAN IN BLACK is an elegantly creepy, atmospheric, British period style ghost story.

When a friendless old widow dies in the seaside town of Crythin, young solicitor Arthur Krips (Daniel Radcliffe), who lives with his four-year old son Joseph (Misha Handley) - Arthur's wife Stella (Sophie Stuckey) died in childbirth) - and Joseph's Nanny (Jessica Raine), is sent by his firm to settle the estate. Arthur finds the townspeople reluctant to talk about or go near the woman's dreary home and no one will explain or even acknowledge the fact that he inadvertently incurs the wrath of a malevolent spirit, the woman in black. She is no filmy, gauzy wraith, but a solid black silhouette of malice and evil. The viewer only sees her a few times, but you feel her malevolent presence in every frame. Ignoring the towns-people's cryptic warnings (they are trying to conceal a deadly secret), he goes to the house where he discovers its horrible history and becomes ensnared in its even more horrible legacy.

Along the way Arthur is befriended by Dailey (Ciarn Hinds) and his strange insane wife (Janet McTeer) and Dailey is the only man willing to transport Arthur across the tide covered marshes to the haunted estate. The story is basically dealing with life after death - in the person of ghosts who stay around to wreck vengeance for their deaths - and the many events that suggest that indeed there is a place after death is borne out by story's strange ending.

Daniel Radcliffe manages to carry his role well (the designers keep him with a fashionable 5 o'clock shadow to prove he has outgrown Harry Potter) and the subordinate cast is strong in the miniscule parts they are given.  This is a mood piece, a ghost story of the old-fashioned sort, and it doesn't pretend to be otherwise.  You either like these films or you don't. Grady Harp, May 12

This is a great way to get into the feel of a classic horror flick! No gore just a good story with lots of suspense and a few good thrills along the way. You need to watch it in the DARK!  Of course my wife may not agree as she spent most of the movie hiding under the blanket!

A young grieving lawyer, Arthur Kipps (Radcliffe) is sent to a remote village to settle the estate of a recently deceased woman who had a quite large English manor. It is very clear from his first arrival that the locals do not want him there, and that they are hiding a terrible secret. As child deaths start to occur in the village, the hatred of the villagers is set against Kipps, and he must, with the help of his friend Sam Daily, seek to unravel out what happened at Eel Marsh House, and who is the woman in black.

Based off of a novel of the same name by Susan Hill, and set in the early 1900's England, this unique film was, to me, a very welcome surprise. Out of a very wide genre filled with generic and sometimes pathetic offerings, this one stands out as one of the best horror films I've seen a good while. While keeping the tension, gradually building the dread and at the same time intensifying the mystery, this film is a superb piece of entertaining, thrilling and engaging storytelling. Backed by great acting on Radcliffe's part, (which frankly, I wasn't sure about at first either, he surprised me) and snap directing by Watkins,  the film kept my interest, and kept me in suspense the whole time. It does have its jumping moments, but do not get the idea this is a movie filled with cheap thrills, it is an intelligent and fine example of suspenseful storytelling, one that can be enjoyed by a wide audience.

Also, I must comment on the filming of it. The lighting and framing of the shots in this piece was absolutely brilliant. Props to them for building such a great atmosphere throughout the film in that regard.

As for content, there's not much to list. When it comes to the disturbing content, I'd say the PG-13 was well earned. The deaths of children occur infrequently throughout the movie and the ghostly woman in black is a quite frightening figure as well. Add in a couple of scenes of extreme tension involving ghosts and it's for sure this is not for the kiddies. There is only perhaps a couple mild profanities, (no more than Sherlock Holmes) and absolutely no sexual content. All in all a pretty clean film.

So what's my verdict? As a horror movie fan, I must say four and a half out of five stars. With this level of acting and the brilliant filmmaking, I must give this one a high rating. Not particularly everyone's favorite genre, but this one is well worth it in my opinion.

The costumes were great. The acting was mediocre. I gave it a three because the ending was good. There were some good parts and I was greatful for fast forward through the long drawn out, supposed to be suspensefilled, scenes of anticipation.

For those jaded by haunted house movies and their typical jolt scares, this one serves.  The Woman in Black proves to be an important outing for Radcliffe as he assumes mature roles, and he delivers in this piece.  Well-directed, atmospheric and creepy with all the right elements, this film is worth repeat viewings.  Things you didn't notice earlier are apt to appear a second time if you look closely.  And it retains it's transition from big to small screen with little loss of intensity.  Great for a midnight distraction.
Cast performed quite well. It was true to the period and creepy enough to make my palms sweat. It didn't seem as predictable as most scary movies.

While there were definitely deaths, there wasn't all of the gore you see in most so called horror movies these days.  I have to say there were a couple of scenes where everyone in the theater jumped.  Very suspenseful and well done, if not as close to the book as I would have liked.

I was pleasantly surprised that Daniel Radcliffe was able to carry a large percentage of the movie essentially by himself.

Well done and very enjoyable.
Nice period piece. Good costumes. Steam punk horror. Nice build up of spooky. Overall a good horror movie. Don't think my wife will sleep for a week.

....if you're 10 years old or less.
Daniel Radcliffe did a very good job on the acting...the special effect were few and far between, but were okay.....the story line was good, but just lead up to and lead up to and lead up to a not so scary movie.
I was disappointed in the movie overall, but maybe for those really young kids this might keep them in suspense.
worst movie seen in a very long while Daniel made me waste money.  don't be fooled.  total exploitation of his potterness.

Many people undoubtedly asked themselves the same question I did when they
heard of this movie. Can Daniel Radcliffe break from the Harry Potter character
he has portrayed for so long? Ladies and Gentleman after viewing the Woman in
Black I can safely say............Yes.

The effects in this movie are simple and practical; there wasn't much, if
 any, CG that I could see and I am very open to that. The effects work and they
 do their job in combination with the atmosphere of the movie to scare the
 freaking pants of you. The movie does not go for jump scares, also known as the
 "OMG CAT" scares, or if you are me, jump startles, but instead slowly
 builds it up and relying heavily on the atmosphere to scare you when the ghost
 does show its face. Part of the beauty is you never know for sure when the
 scares are coming.

I seriously cannot think of a single complaint I have with this movie.
 People looking for a high body count and gore for the sake of gore, you know
 like Saw, will not find it here. the movie relies on suspense to create fear in
 his audience. It scares you and creates a knot in your stomach that doesn't
 have to do with making you sick or disturbed from the amount of blood on
 screen. This is a different kind of horror movie, and it is one I hope to see
 more of because this genre hasn't seen a horror movie like this in a while.

for my full review of this movie please visit Macabremark.com

Some parts were a little boring but the storyline was VERY spinetingeling! I LOVED the acting and thought that the characters played off of each other very well. I HATED the ending(although you kind of see it coming) but other than that this is an EXCELLENT horror movie!
Two Thumbs Up! :)

WOMAN IN BLACK is an eerie, atmospheric ghost story reminiscent of the Hammer films of the late fifties, early sixties.  No gore or overwrought violence, relying on its spooky storyline and moody frightening to propel its effect.
Daniel Radcliffe leaves Harry Potter behind as Arthur, a young attorney on the verge of losing his job and recovering from the death of his wife who died in childbirth.  Radcliffe has to carry the weight of the film and while not a totally convincing performance, he is committed and sincere and should have a promising career.
Ciaran Hinds offers his usual stalwart support and two-time Oscar nominee Janet McTeer is chilling in her brief role as Hinds' disturbed wife.
I liked Marco Beltrani's haunting score and the cinematography is extremely effective.
It's good to see Hammer's rebirth--I grew up on their Dracula/Frankenstein movies!

It's a shame that this atmospheric retelling of Susan Hill's superb novel is so bloodless. Both an earlier British TV film and the long-running London stage version outclass it in sheer chills. Less is always more in a ghost story, but in this THE WOMAN IN BLACK the reasoning seems to be "If one wind-up Victorian toy is scary, seventeen of them will be terrifying!" With apologies, no, it doesn't work that way. The central set-piece, Arthur's aural "witnessing" of a long-ago fatal carriage accident in the dangerous, all-encompassing and impenetrable mist of Eel Marsh is rushed through, but there is seemingly endless footage of a game but green Daniel Radcliffe wandering around the haunted mansion. The movie is way out of proportion, and the ending (SPOILER) seems to want to have it both ways, both gloom and happiness. Buy it for the superb production values and the sterling supporting cast, but this version of THE WOMAN IN BLACK will not haunt your dreams.

Having loved this play over the years, I was a little hesitant about the film.  But it did not disappoint.  While there is no good way to replicate a two-actor stage production, the movie does a good job staying true to a fascinating story, with a nice balance between well-done scares, without being too in-your-face and ruining the creepiness of the setting.

A great adaptation overall, and the ending is a much-watch for any fans of the play.
I'm not sure if Daniel Radcliffe was the best actor for this, but the story was very good. it was very atmospheric and spooky, it would be great for a rainy October night.
oh my god! this movie taught me that in the end it's better to be dead then to watch "the woman in black"

Oh dear, they just cannot get this one to translate to film.

I love this play, I've seen it in London three times and really, there's no way to translate the brilliance of three actors, very sparse stage design and an old theater. The story is extremely simple and effective. The use of disturbing sound design and ONE ghost is used sparingly and with very creepy results. It works brilliantly and always sells out. I'm clearly biased. My bad.

The original movie isn't particularly creepy and this one is only slightly better. They should have kept this story pared down. The more superfluous embellishment you add onto a story like this, the more weighed down it becomes. I don't like the addition of the clairvoyant, a ressurected carriage, ghost children, or the body. It's all so unnecessary. An effective ghostly tale makes your mind wonder at what's in the dark? What are the motives, when and how will the next manifestation begin? You have to use more than just visual senses. Goading the imagination, sound and keeping the story tight are so important.

Anyway; great sets, costuming, acting: that kind of thing. If you're easily scared, like spooky or love Daniel then you may enjoy this.

I gave it an extra star because you have to admit, the storyline and the ending is good. But the overall graphics and display reminded me of the TERRIBLE graphics in a cheap B rated horror movie where you get drunk and laugh at it with your friends. This movie had so much potential, but it was definitely a let down. I wish the director and producers made more of an effort of effects, props, and graphics; this is the 21st century. Usually, even with movies done to display such a time period, still has good effects, props, and graphics. Movie fans...don't waste your time.

This is a ghost story, pure and simple, with a haunted house, a curse, a vengeful spirit, all that good stuff.  Daniel Radcliffe elicits sympathy as an investigator who uncovers a secret about the former occupants of the house in question.  Creepy effects and production design add to the film's strengths.

The movie has a okay story line, the creepy and haunting music gets your heart pumping and the woman in the black dress is a poorly animated scary person, they could have done better. The story line is weak and goes by fast. The movie got two stars instead of three because of the ending. The ending is stupid and weak. What kind of ending was that? Could there be a part 2? Who knows, this movie wasted my time and my money.

The reason for this is because Paranormal Activity (parts 1 - 3) relies of jump scares while this relies on four things, suspense, creepiness, disturbing imagery and good pacing.... Seriously, it had brilliant pacing, to tell you the truth, I didn't feel like watching the movie right away, but it was a fun way to start off my morning, in fact I felt like turning it off on account of me being tired but another superb thing about this movie is that it gets into the story right away!

Plot: Arthur Kipps (Daniel Radcliff) has already lost his wife and feels her presence everyday even when she is absent. 4 years after her death he is assigned to a house that is practically cut off from the remote town that sits next to it, in fear. There he will do some paper work and mumbo jumbo but, on his first day he soon realizes that something is wrong. It turns out that a spirit (a woman dressed in black) Is haunting the premises of the haunted house. Can Daniel Radcliff stop the terror or will he become another victim in the woman in black's scheme!

Review: I never heard of the original until I saw the first trailer back in late 2011 and unfortunately I haven't had the time to watch it but I hear it is chilling and scary as all hell! This movie was intense, but I do wish we saw more of the woman in black but when we did, let me tell ya... she wasn't pretty. In fact I am so sick and tired of witches that are pretty, we need a movie with an ugly witch, but we aren't technically talking about a witch, we are talking about a woman, a woman in black that just so happens to be a ghost! This film was never tame and one thing that it did have that paranormal activity also had was that feeling to look in back of whom ever you should be focusing on but instead your attention is drawn to the background and I feel that it is hard to do, especially when it is not shot entirely on a hand held camera!

Acting: It was just wonderful to see Daniel Radcliff in something besides an over-hyped wizard movie (and you know what I am talking about). His acting was pretty awesome but I just couldn't shake the feeling of him playing a father.... damnit, I've watched to much Harry Potter! The other actors were above average as well.... let's just say I was pleasantly surprised!

Gore: Some blood coughing and blood on a sheet is all we get here and I do wish it had more atmosphere like the first trailer gave off, but what we got was good enough!

Bottom Line: I believe that I have said everything that I wanted to about this movie. It was over decent but I still do adore insidious more because it is more of my taste!

Warning This Film is Rated: Rated PG-13 for thematic material and violence/disturbing images

Is it worth the Buy on a scale of 1-10: 7
For the Movie itself on a scale of 1-5: 4

I have looked forward to seeing this movie since I first saw previews when it was in the theater and I REALLY wanted and expected to like it.  But I was sorely disappointed.  About 30 minutes into it, I was wondering WHEN in the heck it was going to end.  It was one of the most boring movies I've seen in quite a while and the entire story could have been told in a 15 minute short film.  The atmosphere was creepy as was the old mansion....that's about it....

The "thrills" in this film feel like you're going through the horror tunnel at your local fair, which is to say lots of loud sounds and things jumping out at you for no good reason other than to make you jump. This is neither creepy nor scary; it's just annoying.

The plot of The Woman in Black is pretty weak to begin with, and the film does nothing to add substance to Susan Hill's shallow tale in which the weather is the most interesting character of all. Radcliffe is unimpressive, and while he is good enough to portray the one-dimensional Harry Potter, as Arthur Kipps he simply goes around moping the entire movie, failing to make us believe in the supposed heartache he is experiencing.

On the production side, the film is well made; The cinematography sets a good atmosphere, and the house is perfectly creepy as the main location for the plot. In the end, however, The Woman in Black is a poorly acted dull-fest plagued by incessant formula horror cliches.
This remake was ok but not as scary as the original movie. Didn't show enough of the ghost. Acting was good but many scenes were too dark to enjoy the scary intent.
I liked the flick.  Dan sure does like the dark stuff but then again it suits him.  This is a classic scary movie.  It reminds me of the 1950, 60 scary movies.  Basic, Dark, Scary, Best ending ever.

Started out kinda slow and confusing, there were some flashbacks that left me wondering where the heck did that come from? Well that doesn't really make any sense. Part way into the movie I went back and started from the beginning to see if I might have missed something important. I hadn't, so I continued to watch hoping it would pick up.  As the movie progressed the story did unfold and started to come together. I won't give away any spoilers or storylines, needless to say although it wasn't action packed or thrilling it did manage to scare the hell out of me more than a few times. I was pleasantly surprised with Daniel Radcliff's (Harry Potter) acting in this role, he did a supurb job.

Nice to see the actors/actresses breaking away from the spell of typecasting. This is a great scary movie, and a wonderful story line. The graphics are amazing, and the general sense of creepiness and uneasiness of the entire movie is all over the place, and is an amazing and enjoyable movie to watch, considering the stuff that has been coming out in the last 10yrs or so. Its an original story, done by a good screenwriter, done by a great director, and has some amazingly great acting in it. I am amazed at how good Daniel Radcliffe is, and wish all the Harry Potter actors/actresses all the best of luck in the years to come.

Cliche ghost flic.  Strangers chasing ghosts that only appear to him, doorknobs rattling, chairs rocking on their own, innocents (and innocence) at risk . . . been done, been done better.  Very poor editing and slow storytelling, hard to stay with it, I've put it on pause about 10 times already to take breaks as there is no real suspense to hold my attention.  I'm a theater director.  I know my craft.  Beautiful visual vehicle for Ratcliffe, but nothing more.

The Woman in Black is a pretty traditional haunted house story that focuses on atmosphere and the lingering feeling of dread instead of CGI gore and horror. If you've read the book, you'll be familiar with the unsettling nature of the story - a general sense that translated well to the stage play and here to the film. The filming locations capture the remoteness of a house cut off by tide and tragedy and the general production design makes great use of a set to spring some fairly major jumps.

Daniel Radcliffe is well cast in bringing an innocence to a pretty dire situation where children keep dying every time the woman in black shows up, and he's clearly going to keep going beyond Harry Potter. The rest of the cast do well to portray the town that doesn't want Radcliffe there too. All of the tension and surprises rise from the situation and some clever camera shots and even the most hardened horror fan should get quite a few scares.

It's all a fairly solid production until the ending. Susan Hill's book transcended the genre with the end of her story (which has since been copied many times) but this movie doesn't stay faithful to the original material in an attempt to spare the audience the downer. Considering the whole tale is about multiple violent child deaths, I think the filmmakers underestimated the audience here.

Arthur Kipps was dealing with loss, after his wife passed away from childbirth and his employer who wasn't very pleased with his recent responsibilities on the job, sends him out on field work to travel to a remote village to organize a deceased client's paperwork. The young lawyer arrives, but wasn't welcomed with open arms. It was quite obvious that the people in town didn't want him there, but worse yet, there was much more to worry about than just feeling unwanted in the forbidden village. I highly recommend this classic goth story to all thriller and mystery lovers, who enjoy intense suspense throughout with fear and dread instilled from beginning to end. This dark mystery with its silent screams, ghosts and faces in windows will have you biting your nails right up until a shocking ending! The flickering candlelight mood with slamming doors and fog outside will give you that same eerie feeling as if you were viewing 'CAPE FEAR.' The atmosphere is perfect as Daniel Radcliffe gives a superb performance in his role of fright, while something real scary continues to hover over the town. How many children died mysteriously, how many couples were grieving and who was the woman in black, was revenge among the chilling air?

This movie was more than fantastical awesomeness !!!!!!!!!
I screamed & jumped so many times it's incredible, bravo for this A1 film for Daniel did an excellent job as well as it was above standard directed, casted and produced!!
The perfect brake out film for the lad :-)
Amazon prime rocks with instant movies!!!!!!!!

This poor boy will probably never fully breakaway from Harry Potter even though he's done fabulous theatre work. This movie had a decent story line, and was well acted by Radcliffe. However, this movie is filled with jump scares. It was a slow film, but I kept watching in hopes of getting a good ending. I think the ending was unexpected. Overall, I would rate this as a "Red-box Night" film and not a film to add to your collection unless you're a Radcliffe fan.

There are two kinds of horror films.  The first depends for its scares on graphic gore, unrestrained violence, and blood -- lots of it.  The second relies more on mood and an escalating sense of terror than gruesome images to get under the skin.  "The Woman in Black" falls into the second category.  It's a film rich in atmosphere that takes its time getting underway but, once it kicks in, never lets go.

In pre-World War I England, Arthur Kipps (Daniel Radcliffe), a young London lawyer with a small son, is grieving over his dead wife.  His employer is fed up with Arthur's dour attitude and sends him to Yorkshire to handle the sale of an estate.  Arthur is warned that this will be his last chance to distinguish himself for the firm.

Arriving after a long journey, Arthur is met and befriended by a local squire, Daily (Ciaran Hinds), though the other townsfolk are not thrilled with the visit of an outsider.  Arthur is brought to the house of the deceased, which lies quite a distance from town.  It is the textbook example of the House of Gloom -- grey, run down, surrounded by overgrown shrubbery, broken gates marking its entrance -- a place that immediately foreshadows bad things to come.

For much of the movie, Arthur is alone in the house -- or is he?  Many of the trappings of a traditional ghost story are here -- the rainstorm, shadowy corridors, a dog barking at something not seen, an endless number of rooms, each with creepy and unsettling contents.  And then there are the sightings: a darkly attired female figure, a face at a window, a fresh handprint on a window, a corpse rising from a muddy grave.  Whether these are real or only figments of Arthur's imagination is left to speculation -- at least for a while.

"The Woman in Black" is from Hammer Studios, famous for a series of highly profitable Technicolor horror films made between 1957 and the early 70's.  Those features always had great production values and good actors, giving them far more style than their competitors.  "The Woman in Black" is true to that tradition.  Instead of a collection of young and pretty 20-somethings who will be disposed of in messy ways, it boasts a first-rate cast.

Mr. Radcliffe's character is the focus of the movie and he is totally convincing as the lawyer hoping to make good while under a cloud of depression over the loss of his beloved wife.  He infuses his performance with a sad determination, as if he is running a track meet with his feet encased in cement blocks.  He forges on, knowing his livelihood depends on successfully delving through a myriad of papers, settling the estate, and seeing to the sale of the house.  Yet he misses his wife and the life they had together.  His Arthur Kipps is as far removed from Harry Potter as Hamlet is from the Nutty Professor.

Mr. Hinds's Squire Daily is on hand mostly to provide balance to the inhospitable townsfolk, who would be equally at home carrying torches up a hill in a Frankenstein movie.  He prides himself on not being superstitious and refuses to believe the many deaths of children in town are anything more than unfortunate coincidence.  He also provides some exposition, filling us in on what happened in that gloomy house and why Arthur will undoubtedly fail to find a local buyer.  Hinds has a patrician look and never smiles. He suggests a careworn aristocrat who has seen much and prefers to trust his senses to belief in the otherworldly.

Janet McTeer appears briefly, but unforgettably, as Mrs. Daily, a woman who is either an amusing eccentric or a looney, depending on how you interpret her actions.  Ms. McTeer adds bizarre contrast to a film in which the expression of choice appears to be glumness.  Dressed in frills and smiling pleasantly, she enjoys hosting Arthur for dinner.  It's not until we see some of her odd habits that we realize she may have a few cards missing from her deck.

Director James Watkins has fashioned an entertaining horror film.  It's the kind of movie those who are turned off by bloody mayhem can embrace, since it's more about dread and terror than horror.  We experience the house and its history through the eyes of Arthur Kipps.  Watkins knows how to use sound and silence to enhance mood.  Long stretches of silence will precede a loud noise that will make us jump, but those stretches of silence are filled with suspense and anticipation.  We know that something -- anything -- might happen unexpectedly.

Ample credit must be given to those responsible for the film's creepy milieu.  Art director Paul Ghirardani, production designer Kave Quinn, and set decorator Niamh Coulter have decorated every nook and cranny of the old manor house with Victorian furnishings, faded paintings, large carved cabinets, countless  candles, cobwebs, and eerie old wind-up toys.  One can almost smell the mustiness.

Rated PG-13, "The Woman in Black" takes itself seriously and never resorts to self-deprecation.  The characters behave intelligently and have actual motivations.  It is in the league of Jack Clayton's "The Innocents" or Robert Wise's creaky-old-house melodrama, "The Haunting."  Like those earlier films, it shows what happens when a person is confronted with the supernatural and reality seems to spin wildly out of control.

Hammer Films, well known in the past for their Peter Cushing and Christopher Lee Dracula films, returns with Woman in Black (also see the excellent home adaptation for TV, if you get a chance), starring Harry Potter's lead actor, Radcliffe, who plays a real estate agent sent in to collect the papers of a deceased old woman, who died in her mansion in the middle of a wide open marshland.

The tide rolls in as our lead investigates the hell house, and experiences many chilling moments, leading to a boiling finale that will make the hair stand on the back of your neck as only any horrific sequence of images and sound can do.

Many frightful moments build the tension as Arthur grudgingly explores this hellish home of the dead woman, with an ominous, evil presence determined to end the lives of any one foolish enough to trespass. A well told, building horror tale not to be missed by any fan of haunted ghost movies. Many dark, very disturbing moments abound.

Highly recommended.

My kind of movie!  No blood, guts, or gore like the movies they make now.  Just nice and scary!  The Woman is Black is one of the BEST movies I have seen in some time.  Daniel made you forget about him being Harry Potter is this movie.  I hope that he makes more movies like this one for those of us who are not of the Harry Potter age.  While watching this movie, I could see Daniel portraying the character of Quentin Collins from the Dark Shadows ORIGINAL TV series.  David Selby played that character.
Great job Daniel!  I jumped several times throughout the movie!
daniel has shown that he can make them leap from harry to be an actor who can play many different parts. good luck daniel.

I normally don't write reviews, but I've got to say after watching this film that this film was wonderfully done.  I won't get into details about the movie as others have done so.  This film does not have any gore or blood which does loose its taste.  It relies on its creepiness and suspense using darkness and its surroundings. You just have to imagine or pretend that you are Daniel Radcliffe's character exploring the haunted house. Once you do so, then you will feel what he feels throughout the movie. The scares did really give me a jump or goosebumps. I felt the acting was wonderful. You can feel the tense and suspense throughout the film as well as some emotions. I recommend this film highly for anyone who loves hauntings and ghost films. It is hard to come by a good ghost film nowadays and this is one of my favorite.  Enjoy!

This flick was a total waste of my time. a "suspense" film should be full of twists and turns, surprises and secrets. "The Woman In Black" is anything but. It is about as straight line as a freeway, and about as exciting and intriguing as the same freeway during rush hour traffic.
If you like Harry Potter, I'm sure you'll love this.
If you'll watch anything once, go and watch this...however, if you like quality flicks, you'll regret this one.

This movie is a good old fashioned ghost story.  If you are into blood, gore and horror, this is not your movie.  If you love the old hitchcock and tales from the crypt-type shows, this is the one for you.  Arthur Kipps (Radcliffe) had lost his wife during childbirth a few years prior.  He must leave his child behind with a nanny in order to sort out a deceased client's copious amount of paperwork at her house.  The house and grounds are haunted by the deceased.  The fury of losing her young child while she was living remains with her in death; so she wreaks vengeance on the community as a ghost.

The acting is superb and the effects are chilling.  I was so excited that they gave Daniel Radcliffe a chance to break free of the Harry Potter mold...and boy did he ever deliver.  Wonderfully done.  I highly recommend it.  Caution with children under the age of 13 due to disturbing images and intense creepiness.

I have to say first that I LOVE movies about ghosts and hauntings and have seen as many as I could find. The fact that this movie is set in the early 1900s (I believe- don't quote me on that) gives it an old fashioned kind of spookiness that really added to the film. I thought the pop-out scares were decent but the storyline is what I thought made the movie superb. I'd recommend it to anyone, including those that shy away from horror movies, because it's unlike any I've seen- no gore, no dumb teenagers, no cheap scares, etc. Must-see.
I truly loved this movie, i think it goes back to the original thriller...granted it was not to scary but still amazing

SPOILER ALERT!! SPOILER ALERT!!!
The woman haunting the house is not the drowned child's mother. The haunting was going on, before the child ever drowned. The Woman In Black was in the photo taken of the family, while the child was still alive. She is in the background, in one of the windows. The drowned child is one of her victims! We do not know who the woman is or why she has cursed the village, as far as I can tell. The movie is different than the book. There has to be a reason why the children must die, when the woman has been seen. A taken and then drowned child makes absolutely no sense, as being the reason. The woman tried to let our hero know that the parents in the photo were not in any way involved, by scratching their faces off. The woman was enraged, when our hero left the boy's body on the bed, and did not solve the mystery. She, obviously, wanted his help. To do what, I just don't know, but there is something much more sinister behind this tale. She did not need or want the body of the child. Our hero missed the whole point.
The village has been cursed, for something that happened long before the boy drowned.
And, if not ... then why are they making a sequel. According to most of the reviews, the story has been told.
It has not!

As an avid Harry Potter fan, I decided I would watch this movie when I first heard he was doing it simply so I could support Daniel as an actor, life Post Potter. I figured it would be ok. It was fantastic. I ABSOLUTELY LOVED IT. Radcliffe as Kipps is amazing and you really get to see Dan stretch his legs as an actor. I'll definitely be getting this when it comes out on dvd.

this movie was awesome, completely blew me away with its haunting atmosphere and tragic characters. this ones going right in my movie gallery on blu ray. this my secound favorite ghost movie right after INSIDEOUS.

This was one of the best movies in this genre I have seen in some time.  Since I love the genre, this should be noted.  The sound track is a great compliment to the thrilling suspense and I adored the screen shots that actually allow the viewer to see the apparitions, not only guess at them.  I would higly recommend this movie to everybody.

"It's not natural to lose someone so young, but if we open the door to superstition where does that lead". Still trying to recover from the death of his wife, Arthur Kipps (Radcliffe) leaves his young son in order to settle the estate of an English manor. The village residents do all they can to make him leave early because of the legend of the house. When Kipps discovers the secret he vows to stop it. I have to admit that I was looking forward to this movie mainly for the fact that this was "Harry Potter"'s first major non-potter movie. I was a little disappointed because of my high expectations. This is still a very good movie and there are some very very creepy things to keep you on your toes. I really just think that more could have been done with it. Some parts of the movie are very intense and keep you watching while others seem to drag and slow the movie down. The ending however really changes the way you feel and is a little shocking which to me made the movie better. I do recommend this one, but lower your expectations. Overall, a good movie with a great ending that is worth seeing. I give it a B.
This movie was great he really is very talented. I was so scared that my husband couldn't leave me to use the bathroom. But Im Counting down to buy it on blue-ray.

Me and my friend went and saw this movie together. If you want to be scared then get this movie! It is one of the most scariest movies I've ever seen. I love this movie and when it gets to be a better price I am going to snatch it right away. Yes Daniel Radcliffe is alone a lot of the time in the movie, but that keeps you on the edge of your seat. What would you do if you were stuck in a haunted house all alone, for a whole night, and couldn't leave? Well see what Dr. Aurthur Kipp(Daniel Radcliffe) does in this horrifying movie, The Woman in Black!

This movie was produced with shocking the audience as its' goal.  Every trick in the book is used to send chills down your spine.  Very well made ghost story.  Recommended for those who want to experience that foreboding feeling of eminent, inescapable danger but want to have the experience from the safety of their theater seat.  Imagine you are alone in a haunted house with no way to leave the area.  Imagine spooky sound effects and music is playing in the background.  If you like getting scared, you will like The Woman in Black.

I love gothic horror -- big cobwebbed houses, squawking ravens, rolling mists and mysterious sinister figures that are only glimpsed. "The Woman in Black" has all of those. In fact, this slow, haunting movie loads on the Edwardian ghost-story atmosphere so thick that it practically chokes you -- and while it tends to move slowly, it's beautifully creepy.

Young lawyer Arthur Kipps (Daniel Radcliffe) has a life in tatters -- his career is in jeopardy, and he's still in mourning over the loss of his wife four years ago. He's sent to sort through the personal effects of Alice Drablow, who left behind a decayed mansion set in the misty marshes -- and when visiting the house, he sees a veiled woman in black.

The locals are also desperate to get rid of him, even blaming him for the death of a child who drank lye. And soon Kipps begins to understand why, as he unravels the secrets of the Drablow family, and the madwoman who lost her child long ago. With the help of his new friend Sam Daily (Ciarán Hinds),  Kipps will set out to stop the Woman in Black before she claims what's dearest to him.

I haven't been too impressed with the output of the revitalized Hammer Films company. "The Woman in Black" is probably the best horror movie they've produced -- it feels like a modern version of their shadowy, gothic old movies. It's also not very scary, although director James Watkins tosses in a few jump scares (a raven, a faucet, etc).

Instead, the movie just makes you uneasy. We're constantly aware that SOMETHING is hovering over this town. But for most of the movie, we only see fleeting glimpses of the Woman and her power.

The biggest problem is that the movie moves rather slowly, especially in the first half. But for me, it's compensated for by Watkins inserting some truly unnerving scenes, like a hysterical Mrs. Daily carving into the table. And the gothic atmosphere is so heavy and dark that it practically drips from the screen -- vast mildewed houses, foggy marshes, half-forgotten letters and old photos, and a grey rainy light that seems to wash the colors from the world.

There's not a trace of Harry Potter in Daniel Radcliffe's performance here. His Arthur Kipps is a haunted, broken figure who seems strangely detached from the world around him, except when it comes to endangered children. The only problem is that Radcliffe looks a little young for the role -- whenever Arthur is with his little son, he looks more like the kid's big brother.

"The Woman in Black" is rather slow at times, but the gothic atmosphere and a strong performance from Radcliffe almost make up for that. Well, I'll gladly take it over rotten slasher remakes.

Of all the Harry Potter alumni, Daniel Radcliffe is probably in the most tenuous position now that the blockbuster franchise has ended it's decade long run. He's dabbled in other projects outside of the boy wizard's adventures before, and has generally shown to be a talented and more than capable actor. But he's also most likely to be pigeonholed, with people unable to accept him as anything other than a kid with a magic wand and pet owl. Even so, he's still in a better position than poor Rupert Grint. So what's the best decision Radcliffe can make? To star in another film that has him dealing with big houses and supernatural forces. Probably not the wisest move, and his Harry Potter fans who follow him into the tedious The Woman in Black may start wishing for someone to cast a spell and speed up time.

Based on a Susan Collin's dreary but effective novel, the deliberate pacing is one that plays out better on the printed page than on screen. Daniel Radcliffe plays Arthur Kipps, a gloomy lawyer struggling to cope with the death of his wife, who passed tragically years earlier after giving birth to their son. Arthur apparently hasn't smiled since, so much so that his son draws depressing pictures of his Dad(to comical effect). His demeanor is so bleak that Arthur is on the verge of losing his job. Nobody wants a stick in the mud as a colleague. Given one last shot to redeem himself, he's sent to the depressing village of Yorkshire to settle the affairs of a recently deceased woman.

Upon arriving, it's pretty clear nobody wants him there, and the reason has to do with the woman's creaky old home, which as you probably suspected is plagued by an evil spirit. Aren't they all? In this case it's of a woman, wronged in life and separated forever from her dead son. As retribution, her malevolence has plagued the entire village's children, and the streets are littered with the ghosts of her victims who stare blankly out of windows and hang around the woods like creepy stalkers. The town itself is little more than a mudpit with a bit of smog surrounding it, but it's like heaven compared to the house itself, which is full of every horror cliche in the book. Creepy marionettes that look extra spooky in the dark, the type no parent would ever buy their child. Every corner is a blind hazard, every step another rickety shriek of worn out wood, and behind every door lies the possibility of a vengeful poltergeist. Shutters flap, people knock on the door at the most fearful moments. Let's just say that Arthur doesn't get a lot of work done.

Radcliffe may seem like an odd choice to play a grieving widower, but he proves to be the film's greatest asset. His youthful features appear appropriately hardened by years of overwhelming grief, and you can tell his every action is labored by life's meaninglessness. But when faced with immediate danger, some of the old Harry Potter spirit comes through. In contrast to the rest of the cast, including veteran actor Ciaran Hinds, Radcliffe is the only one who seems to be bringing everything he has to what is a very understated role.

It's just unfortunate that so much of the film is completely conventional. Despite director James Watkins' skillful depiction of smog and soot filled Victorian England, the script by the usually reliable Jane Goldman doesn't take us anywhere we haven't been. Atmosphere can only get you so far, and some of the film's old school horror charms wear thin from overuse. How many times are we expected to leap from our seats at a close-up of a toy monkey? Without genuine scares, the glacial pace becomes an even bigger problem. Watching both chapters of Deathly Hallows feels more brisk than this film's plodding 90 minutes.

I really liked it actually! I heard it wasn't getting good reviews, but I don't know what those people expected.

It was a good horror movie! It wasn't filled with gore and faux-blood spillage everywhere, but it was scary and perfect to bring girlfriends (but prepare for high pitched shrieks)!

I brought my brother along and he thought it was very scary! And he's a horror movie buff! Just for the record, my brother wasn't cowering in a corner, he meant 'scary' as in 'well-done' for a horror movie.

That being said, none of the scares were new ones, but they were very effectively used and that's better than most horror movies and movies in general.

The acting was great; the cinematography was great, it was both beautiful and desolate on Isle Marsh; the spooks weren't original but well-done.

The clothes were amazing. Daniel Radcliffe should wear something like this all of the time and he will never have to worry about going home alone ever again.

It felt like a short movie, which is great because I think it's close to two hours long.

Overall, I enjoyed myself, I feel as if my hard-earned cash was spent properly, and I would definitely subject myself to this movie again!

As of now, I shall just have to content myself with reading, "The Woman in Black" by Susan Hill, the book on which this movie is based.

After seeing the long running stage show I  was looking forward to seeing the film version. What a huge disappointment it was. It  was very slow moving and I was expecting some shocks in this ghost story. There were none. Beautifully photographed and acted. The mood was there but  it was missing any scenes that  should have make me  jump in my seat. One thing puzzled me is that when the leading character decides to spend a very long  day and night at the haunted mansion,all he takes is a little food that he is gven and  (it appears) nothing to drink.  You know there is no  drinkable water in the  deserted mansion. Also a dog is left to keep him company but no food or  water is provided for the dog. There was nothing  in this film at all that was original or scary.

A young man travels to a small town set in the 1890's, where young children have been dying. He begins seeing images of a deceased woman and looks for a connection with the deaths. The movie contains certain predictable elements of the horror genre, like faces in the window, doors slamming, creepy music, and a rocking chair with no one in it. The late 1800's setting is effective, but this attempt at a combination of a horror film and a murder mystery falls a bit flat as the film is just not very frightening and the investigation into the deaths is only mildly interesting.

Daniel Radciffe  stars in this haunted house film called the Woman in Black. The title has been taken from Susan Collins and is about Arthur Kipps,  a London based lawyer with a 4 year old son, who has reached rock bottom since the death of his wife. His firm has sent him for a job to the estate of late Mrs. Alice Drabow to settle her affairs. The town residents greet Arthur with hostility and the house that he lives in full of strange happenings, which start the moment he arrives. Radcliffe is okay but the movies relies too much on mood and atmosphere to do the job of scaring us but that works only to a certain extent because things progress at a snails pace
Too much mood, alarming sound effects and dreary atmosphere cannot make a movie watchable. Three stars. 2/10/2012

I saw the prior 1989 film of this book made by British tv.  I've read the book.  I've heard it performed as an audio book.  I haven't seen the stage play of it.  This work thus exists in many, many forms and is very popular in almost all of them.

This time the movie had a very lavish budget and starred Daniel Radcliffe as the lead. As a solicitor, he is called in to visit a distant village in order to settle an estate.  There he sees a ghost of a woman wearing funereal black. She is furious at everyone because her son drowned on the marsh and no one even bothered to dig up his body.  They are scared to death of her because certain disaster looms every time she makes an appearance. Sure enough disasters start to take place with the first one being a young girl who falls into his arms at the police station because she just drank lye.

There is a bit of a rewrite on this version of the film towards the end. It resolves the ghost story more than it has been resolved in any other incarnation.  I am not sure that this is needed or necessary.  It does not ruin it though.

It is a very good ghost movie.  It is scary.  The visual effects are great. However, I can't give it the 5 stars I gave the 1989 version.  That version, with a fraction of the budget, scared me so much that I was turning on lights, keeping my dog nearby and such whenever I was alone in the house. This version does not have that kind of horror punch, It seems the scariest movies often are made on a small budget.  Perhaps the lavish special effects make us too aware that it is a movie.

Radcliffe does a fine job.  He is a fine young actor but then again he has been since he was a small boy. I think he will do fine now that the Potter films are over and he is no longer Harry Potter to us.  He is beginning to look less and less like Harry Potter which should help.

Visit my blog with link given on my profile page here or use this phonetically given URL (livingasseniors dot blogspot dot com). Friday's entry will always be weekend entertainment recs from my 5 star Amazon reviews in film, tv, books and music. These are very heavy on buried treasures and hidden gems. My blogspot is published on Monday, Wednesday & Friday.

The movie hits on all the classic stereotypes of a ghost story. There is a haunted mansion in an isolated marsh thick with fog. There is a past of a haunted suicide and a recent will. The village has a secret. The house has ghostly images, squeaks, creaks, whispers, things that move on their own, and a raven that enters it.

Our main character has a wife who has died in child birth and for some undisclosed reason this is his "last chance" with his firm so he just can't walk away. In the beginning, Radcliffe wears his hair down over his forehead leading me to suspect he really does have a permanent mark in the shape of a lightning bolt.

There is a mystery that is supposed to draw you in, but having seen so many clichés you wonder if this film will offer you anything new.

As the poorly developed Arthur (Daniel Radcliffe) sorts through the papers in the house he uncovers letters which sheds some light unto the situation, and we get to see his bolt free forehead. Radcliffe was neither an asset nor a liability. His agent did him well, but I thought he mustered more fear and terror as that Potter guy in the late sequels than he did in this film. He seems to have trouble with convincing facial expressions.

The strength of the film is in how well it utilizes all those haunted mansion clichés, the lighting...or lack of it, and the detailing of the era. Arthur is played as a rather dull character. There are things that happen to him which would have made me leap out of skin and run out the house, yet he does very little. Also Arthur is quiet as he encounters the unknown, perhaps done to build up the scare factor, but I wonder how that would have worked with a character who talks to the ghost while searching about, maybe with a comical line or two taken from "Hold That Ghost" or someone like Joe Pesci swearing obscenities at it.

Parental Guide: No f-bombs, sex, or nudity. Safe for the kids to watch on a foggy night if you want to scare the bejesus out of them.

I really expected more from this movie as a Radcliffe fan and after watching the trailer. Sadly the trailer was the only thing that I ended up liking about this awful film. At the theater, as the movie tried to progess, I realized that it would never going to get any good. All my friends felt the same disappointment at the end of the screening. Trust me and do not waste your precious time and money with this garbage or you will be as disappointed as me.

Forget all the nonsense surrounding this being Daniel Radcliffe's first film outside of the mega franchise that is Harry Potter. Yes Radcliffe is in the movie and does a serviceable job in the role of Arthur Kipps but everything to me exists out of Radcliffe and to speak of him does disservice to the best component of the movie, that being James Watkins the director who creates and excellent amount of suspense over trying to use musical stings or jump scares to hit his audience. This isn't a classic haunted house film like Robert Wise's The Haunting or The Shining but its a fun little film with a flaw holding it back from greatness.
I mention Radcliffe only in saying that every actor in the film outside of acting talent which they have seems more to have been cast for their faces. Its odd seeing Radcliffe playing a father sure, but Kipps isn't a character like Jack Torrance. Radcliffe main use in the film is to either appear haunted or scared which He does well. He's joined by the excellent Ciaran Hinds playing a local landowner who doesn't believe all this woman in black nonsense despite having a mentally unstable wife played by Janet Mcteer.
The Woman in Black herself is a beautiful creation, a ethereal image that plays like English Freddy Krueger, a vengeful spirit who causes the death of children when she's seen in the town of Crythin Gifford, gathering the spirits of her victims around her as sort of a haunting troupe.
As I said the real star of the film is James Watkins not to take anything from the work of the cinematographer or production designer. Watkins does pepper the film with jump scares from the Woman's screech to a bird in a chimney but He also tries the approach of John Carpenter in Halloween with hidden glimpses of the woman over the shoulder of a character or moments of an agitated dog to signal her coming. The film does use sound to create more measured bits of suspense included a bit lifted Susan Hill's novel involving a rocking chair behind a locked room and it works well. Then there's the house on Eel Marsh itself is a beautiful creation in keeping with the period setting of the film, a reclusive decaying mansion surrounded by marshes and a tide that cuts it off from town in order to strand Radcliffe.
It all adds up to a really good horror film, one with a dark edge to its action and one worth seeing in theatres to get the experience from the sights and sounds created to drive the suspense. There's just one true negative for me and that's the ending of the movie perhaps put in the film for Radcliffe's star power, or perhaps the result of negative testing. Hopefully not spoiling the end at one point the movie seems to go for a dark ending only to have some bit of happy schmaltz that tries to lighten the mood and doesn't work at all. Watkins previous film Eden Lake contained a twisted bit of glumness in its finale so it feels like something to fit with the fact that the movie has Harry Potter in the lead. Thankfully though for me one minute of blandness didn't kill a great ninety minutes that preceded it.
The disc from Sony Pictures doesn't have much in the way of great extras for fans of the film relying on an EPK making of and a bit about Daniel Radcliffe. Susan Hill pops up for a bit in the making of but the best bit bonus is a commentary from Watkins and Jane Goldman. What the disc has going for it is a superb audio visual package that works for the film. As I've said this beautiful looking ghost film where most of what drives the film are the images and the sound. Sure you could make a game out of all the scary sounds that are trotted out but there are other moments like a scene in a bog covered in fog that work well.
For fans of gothic horror films and ghost stories this is a recommended disc an excellent highlight for the format.

In "The Woman in Black" Daniel Radcliffe, otherwise immortalized as Harry Potter, plays Arthur Kipps, a struggling lawyer, on his last ditch assignment from his law firm to settle the estate of a friendless old widow. He leaves his 4-year old son behind for four days to travel to a remote village called Crythin Gifford, UK. Once there, he finds himself unknowingly walking into a legend and a legacy of tragedy and unexplained events that have had a stranglehold on the village for decades.

The first thing to be said about "The Woman in Black" and its star, Daniel Radcliffe, is that this was a brilliant move by him as an actor to do something so quickly after the Harry Potter series came to a close, and something so different as well. Never once while watching this movie did I think about Harry Potter. Radcliffe may be one of the few actors who has become so well known for one character that will be able to make the transition into other things.

"The Woman in Black" is a remake of a successful television movie that came out in 1989. It is a ghost story, pure and simple, although, it is not simply described as a ghost story, because there is so much more to it than that. It isn't for the viewer looking for gratuitous violence. Maybe its greatest asset as a movie is its ability to turn ghost story in to mystery, slowly walking you through a haunting situation and revealing the secrets behind the strange happenings a little as a time, just as Arthur Kipps is discovering them.

The villagers are opposed to Arthur Kipps visiting the mysterious house across the vast marshlands and Kipps soon finds out why. He is quickly greeted to a mystery and a story that holds the audience in place and never lets up. The movie is never slow and always interesting. Yet at times, some of the things that move the story along can be considered a little hokey, but that placed aside, the mood and delivery are effective.

"The Woman in Black" is a campfire tale and a campfire tale at its finest. It is a successful leap for Radcliffe who is trying to separate himself from being Harry Potter, and it is certainly a movie that will keep your eyes wide open because the things that haunt the mysterious house are not shy.

*A Brief Note to Readers: If you find this review "not helpful", please take a moment to tell me why in the comment section. Thank you.*

Stories about vengeful spirits never fail to fascinate, and during one of the bleakest months of the year, the release of "The Woman In Black" is welcome entertainment for a bored and mostly housebound populace.  Adapted from a horror fiction novel originally published in 1983, author Susan Hill's tale comes to life on screen, raising hairs on the backs of audiences' necks in new and disturbing ways.

Arthur Kipps is a sad man.  Even his four-year old son Joseph draws pictures of him with frowns.  His melancholy stems from the loss of his wife Stella, the joy of their son's birth forever marred by her death after a difficult labor and delivery.  So when the law firm under which he is employed assigns him to the estate of one Alice Drablow, it is a convenient distraction and a solution to recent financial troubles.  Surmising he can put her affairs in order in just a few days time, he surpasses his deadline after encountering horrendous piles of disorganized papers as well as strange sounds and voices within Eel Marsh House, Drablow's former home.  Things quickly go from bad to worse when Arthur begins seeing a woman in a black dress in the house and on the grounds, the deaths of several children coinciding with her appearances. Faced with angry, superstitious townspeople and an unraveling mystery, Arthur's problems, once inconsequential, become the stuff of nightmares.

"The Woman In Black" is, in a word, creepy, director James Watkins achieving the tale's ubiquitous gloom in many ways.  The archaic town that Arthur visits is comprised of dank and mossy stone structures populated by frowning denizens.  Costumes are simple and drab, moors are perpetually misty, the marshland is black and oily, and the film is punctuated by lots of beauteous stills of a roiling gray sea.  Porcelain dolls and tattered antique toys are always good for upping the creep factor and Watkins utilizes them to full effect, their wide glassy eyes engulfing the camera lens, unsettling the viewer with their unblinking and penetrating stares.  The foreboding of Eel Marsh House comes to life, its creaky floorboards, dirty and faded wallpaper, and cobwebs adorning every picture, chandelier and wall sconce sure to thrill fans of Susan Hill's novel.  What will make the biggest impression, of course, is the incarnation of the restless and vengeful spirit of the movie's title, one that slinks through the shadows in the background, whose raspy breaths reverberate through the hallways and rafters, and whose dark silhouette comes skulking (sometimes shrieking) out of the darkness time and time again.

With the exception of its star player and fellow Harry Potter alumnus Ciarán Hinds, the movie is cast with actors largely unknown to American audiences.  Radcliffe, in his first role since the conclusion of the Harry Potter series, could have been judged on his potential as a leading man but the role of Arthur Kipps doesn't allow him to exhibit his range.  He is instead restricted to long somber gazes and a handful of moments of wide-eyed terror, a performance in favor with the film's ambiance and tempo.  The supporting players are on par with their A-list co-star, Hinds the biggest standout for his affecting portrayal of Sam Daily, a man whose life has been torn apart in more ways than one after the untimely death of his young son Nicolas.

As with most films of its ilk, "The Woman In Black" has its share of scares, the amalgam of music, sound effects, and on-screen action creating moments that make the audience jump out of their seats in fright.  Thankfully Watkins doesn't overdo it, his translation of Hill's tale doing most of the hair-raising work.  It is an admirable adaptation, though I'm sure some readers will take issue with the changes that have been made, the finale in particular.  If you haven't read Hill's novel (I didn't) and love a good ghost story, it's recommended.  If you have read the book and you often find that adaptations of books you've read don't meet your expectations, you're better off passing this one up or at least waiting until it's available on home video.

For a description of the plot, etc., read other reviews.  I just want to say a few things about this movie...

The Woman In Black (2012) is a remake of the 1989 TV movie of the same name and based on the 1983 book by Susan Hill.  I reviewed that movie last July and gave it 4 stars.  This remake is actually better than the original, a rare feat.  From my experience, usually remakes of horror movies are nowhere near as good as the original.  This is an exception.

The things that this movie have going for it are the dark, chilling, spooky atmosphere and the genuine creepiness of the haunted house from the Victorian era.  You'll see classic components of a haunted house - cobwebs, paintings hanging on the walls, lit candles, a rocking chair rocking by itself, creepy looking dolls, music box melodies, and of course ghosts.  Throw in the thunderstorm and the movie feels complete.  This is definitely one of the creepiest and best ghost story movies I've ever seen.  There are a lot of sudden scares that might make you jump out of your seat.  There is an occasional dose of comic relief sprinkled throughout the movie.  The musical score by Marco Beltrami is decent.

This movie was my introduction to Daniel Radcliffe (I've never seen the Harry Potter movies).  He does a commendable job acting.  This movie is a triumphant return for Hammer Horror.  Who can forget the classic Hammer horror movies from the 1950s, '60s, and '70s?

Overall, this is a good Victorian ghost story that I highly recommend.

You have to be in the mood for a good, authentically creepy ghost story to fully enjoy the quiet chills of THE WOMAN IN BLACK. It's only after the story ended that I realized I'd been taken by something I should have seen from the beginning. At any rate, the ending did come as a twist for me--but in view of all the preceding events, it was indeed foreshadowed by information given about the title character.

Daniel Radcliffe has to carry the weight of most of the film on his own shoulders and he does a very strong and satisfying job as a young lawyer whose firm sends him on a mission to a remote village accessible only when the tide is low enough to permit horse and carriage to enter. The story depends on the musty atmosphere of a decaying mansion full of shopworn dolls that seem to come to life in a nursery where three girls met their fate years ago.

Radcliffe's only friendly neighbor is Ciaran Hinds, who helps him get to the root of the troubled village and the death of numerous young children. The extremes to which Radcliffe is willing to go (as in the marsh scene where he recovers a dead boy's body) are improbable, to say the least, but so graphically enacted that you have to believe it. It's one of the most suspenseful moments in the story. Radcliffe is willing to recover the corpse to give it a proper burial next to the mother, whose spirit is evidently haunting the old mansion.

The surprise ending fits the story but came as quite a shock to me, although with hindsight I can see that there was some preparation for it if you paid close attention to the script.

For lovers of Gothic tales full of mist, suspicion, brooding townspeople and dangerous marshlands, THE WOMAN IN BLACK is your ticket. Good production values are in abundant evidence. Hammer is certainly making a good comeback in the horror genre with this delicious ghost story. Fine cinematography is another big asset.

Radcliffe makes expressive use of his penetrating blue eyes framed by bushy brows that confirm his qualification for more adult roles in his future.

In the early 1900s, young lawyer Arthur Kipps (Daniel Radcliffe) is sent to a remote village to go through the papers of a recently deceased old woman. He finds the villagers oddly hostile, but sets about his work in the woman's creepy, old house. There, he begins to unravel the story of a mysterious woman believed to haunt the place.

 If you're looking for a scary movie, look no further. There are scares every few minutes once Arthur starts (stupidly) exploring the house, endlessly going from dark room to dark room while the eerie music and sound effects build to get-ready-to-shriek-levels. The movie has little dialogue, with Arthur alone most of the time just looking for the ghost.

This kind of alone-in-the-house part is usually played by a beautiful, helpless, young woman but Radcliffe does a good job, coming off as serious, mature, and fairly brave. If you saw the movie without sound, it wouldn't be nearly as frightening, so a great deal of credit must go to the music and sound effects. Ciarán Hinds is good in a rather undemanding, supporting role. The titular character disappointingly resembles a mannequin in a high school haunted house.

The movie makes the most out of people' primal fear of the dark and genuine shocks come on a regular (one might say, predictable) basis. I found the movie just a bit unsatisfying, though, because Arthur's character is so wooden and stoic and the story is unrelentingly unpleasant. 3.5 stars.

I took by three nieces to see this movie and was very surprised as to how good it was.  I went in with an open mind with no knowledge of what the movie was about and I really enjoyed it.  My youngest niece was the one who enjoyed it the most as it was scarry to her.  I highly recommend this movie for anyone wanting a quick entertaining experience.  Never a dull moment during the film.  Always something happening.

To tell the truth, I'm not really a fan of the horror genre, excluding the classic Universal monster films from the 20's and 30'; but especially not modern horror, with people being tortured and slashed to ribbons and all that (why so many people seem to love that stuff is beyond me). That being said, I found "The Woman in Black" to be a masterpiece of Gothic horror, simply overflowing with psychological terror and creepiness; in short, an old-fashioned ghost story for the 21st century.

Susan Hill's wonderfully atmospheric novel is what sold me on the idea of this film in the first place. Before that, I could have easily passed this off as just another disgusting horror movie under the guise of a ghost story. The film's production company, Hammer, was best known throughout the 50's and 60's for producing genuinely scary horror films with lots of gore and blood. With the company's decline in the 1980's, it seemed that they, like so many other studios, would just go out of business, but in 2008, they were revived. "The Woman in Black" is the first ghost story that they have ever produced, and for their first supernatural outing, they didn't do too shabby.

Moody and foreboding from the very first scene, the story concerns Arthur Kipps, a young lawyer from London who is sent by his firm to the rural Yorkshire town of Crythin Gifford with the purpose of settling the estate of a recently deceased client, Mrs. Alice Drablow. From the first moment he arrives there is a sense that something sinister is going to happen: The village is separated from the mainland by a causeway which floods over at high tide, and the house itself, Eel Marsh house, is surrounded by a mysterious bog that holds many secrets, some darker than others. As he catches his first glimpses of the woman in black herself, children in the village begin dying violent and unexpected deaths, caused by apparent suicide. Arthur's job suddenly takes a more serious turn as he begins to uncover the secret behind the mysterious hauntings and the true identity of the one woman who seems to be behind it all.

While I found several additions by screenwriter Jane Goldman to be a little wanton (Zombie children wandering the marshes, two very graphic death scenes, a ghostly reenactment of a suicide, some very creepy Victorian wind-up toys, and a rather mad Mrs. Daily who rears her two pet Chihuahuas like children and claims to channel the spirit of her dead son), the film stays very true to the Hill's book and faithfully brings that same unsettling, suspenseful atmosphere to the big screen. There is no doubt for fans of the novel that this is the definitive adaptation, far surpassing the 1989 BBC version.

Perfectly evoking the flavor of the old dark house pictures from glory days of cinematic horror, it's a great example of what all good ghost stories should have: things that bump, creak and rock for no apparent reason, flitting shadows, flickering candles, bone-chilling shrieks, and enough thrills and jump-scares to keep you leaping from you seat whether you want to or not. As the film progresses, the scares keep building, so that by the time you get to the real chills, you're so worked up from anticipating what's coming that you are, to put it mildly, scared right out of your wits.  A handful of scenes aside, this film is wonderfully old-fashioned in its simplicity, psychological effectiveness, and lack of gore. The real scares are built on our fears of the unknown and the fact that what you can't see or don't know is oftentimes scarier than what you can. Sure, there are some really creepy things that you'd have to be blind as a bat to miss, but I find that the moments of almost oppressive silence are the most nerve-wracking of all, a good example being early on in the film when Arthur is exploring the house, alone -- no dialogue, no screams -- just the nail-biting experience of not knowing what's going to be around the next corner. The fact that this is so frightening is even more amazing when you realize that most of this sequence takes place in broad daylight!

Shot in a predominantly monochrome color palette of dusty greys and dreary blacks, visually, it is one of the most stunning films I have seen in a long time. The colors, or lack of them, go a long way into creating a bleak and brooding atmosphere to stage the story and perfectly enhance the inherent creepiness of the film itself. Even the style in which it was filmed, most noticeable in the scene described above, is quite scary: It puts you right into the character's shoes, and makes for a very visceral and haunting theatrical experience.

Being a relatively low-budget film, director James Watkins chose to rely mainly on "in-camera" effects rather than touching up scenes with massive amounts of CGI, which aside from being costly also looks phony if thrown in too often. I'd have to guess that about 80% of what you see on-screen was what was actually filmed then and there, not added in later with a computer. This decision definitely adds realism, something not usually found in horror movies, and doesn't cause you to keep drawing yourself out of the film to think "Oh, they did that with special effects,".

One thing that sets "Woman" apart from just about every other scary movie I've seen is that it is incredibly character driven. It isn't just about the scares; it's about the people, too. I find that when you truly care about those involved, you subconsciously invest a lot more in them emotionally, so that whenever tragedies befall them, it hits you that much harder because of it. I guess you could say there is an equal measure of horror and heart, something that doesn't pop up very often in this particular genre.

While I've been impressed by Daniel Radcliffe's acting abilities in the past, here, he proves that he is well able to emerge from Harry Potter's shadow and handle other, quite different roles.
